September 6th: Afghanistan is a mess. How much is that the fault of the US and the UK? That’s not simple. Afghanistan is sometimes called ‘The Graveyard of Empires’, with failed attempts to rule it by the UK, the US, the USSR since around 1830. You’d think governments might learn from that!
When the US bombed and invaded in 2001, aided by the UK and others, there was at least some reason – to root out Al-Qaida – but even that was a more complex mission than it appeared, partly because of the support of elements in Pakistan (who shielded Osama bin Laden in exile for years afterwards). However, the installation of Hamid Karzai as President was problematic from the start. And the last election that installed Ashraf Ghani had an extremely low turnout. In a country with no tradition of a central government, but strong regional and tribal allegiances, any central power was likely to have trouble commanding respect. Unsurprisingly, these governments, installed in a simulacrum of western-style centralised democracies, have been partial and corrupt.
At the same time, US-led influences tried to instil patterns and levels of representation that were unfamiliar, such as setting a quota for female leaders that was actually higher than that in the US itself! In a society where women had had almost no power, this was seen as a step too far in the conservative rural areas, and reduced credibility. Meanwhile, the partiality and corruption at the centre also undermined efforts to set up an organised defence force.
Perhaps more limited objectives in culture change, and a more distinctively regional/federal governing structure might have taken root. Perhaps concentrating on female education and participation in sport and culture would have created less of a conservative backlash than what was seen as an imposition of leadership. Of course a fully-inclusive society was a fine ideal, but evidently the culture change expected in less than one generation, and the tribalism and corruption of a centralised and non-credible government, was too much. The Taliban, it seems, brought order and a familiar culture to the outlying regions when the government was seen as remote and hostile.
It’s tragic too that at a time of increasing nationalism elsewhere, the UK government has become less friendly and trusting, but also weakened severely those cultural influences that have given us ‘soft power’ and perhaps helped to encourage a more inclusive, honest and forward-looking style of government across many countries. That is, many world leaders (one in seven?) are British educated. Our Civil Service has been respected for professionalism and independence. The BBC is the most trusted international news source. Our governance has been seen as mature, rational, patient and honest. All this seems under threat. Very worrying.

Things are really hotting up!
Friday 1st, first official briefing for potential Mayoral candidates and their agents. Still only two declared candidates at this stage (LD and Labour), but several independents showing an interest, as well as Conservatives.
Also Friday 1st, meeting with senior staff of the North East Local Enterprise Partnership (NELEP), who are a partner in the new Authority and are working to increase investment and skilled employment.
Sunday 3rd, I spoke at a meeting of Church Action on Poverty – the local branch of a national organisation. I’ve worked with the People’s Kitchen, Cedarwood Centre and others, and lived and worked in deprived areas, and understand how austerity and poverty have affected so many round here. Brexit will hit the NE hardest – just what we don’t need! One important message: we need to involve people more in things that affect them, getting them onto councils and into meetings. Clearly one role for the Mayor is to help that, giving people a voice, even where the direct powers of the Mayor are limited.
Tuesday 5th, at a church meeting in Seahouses, I took the opportunity to ask locals how much they knew about the new Authority and Mayoral elections. The answer: patchy, some had seen me on TV and seen things in the newspapers, others nothing at all at this stage.
Wednesday 6th – a second BBC interview, focussing on Environment, Transport (public and also car-clubs), and what the Mayor can do despite limited powers.

March 2020: A while since I posted here – so much to think about. Johnson got his majority in December, so he could claim to ‘get Brexit done’, but really only just getting started. I rather hoped his monomaniac approach, including choosing such a loyal if untalented Cabinet, would give way to some realism, but it was not to be. He still has a crazy Cabinet, and an apparent belief that incredibly complex negotiations can be done in a few months. Three possibilities: 1. He’s genuinely OK with the idea of a hard Brexit. 2. He’ll extend the transition after all. 3. He’s going to cave in on most EU requirements. My own view is that ‘no-deal’ is improbable. Why? Because he likes being popular, and medicine shortages and the loss of industries like Nissan would make him very unpopular. I predict a mix of 2 and 3.

May 19th: The Met Police were reluctant to investigate lockdown parties at no. 10, presumably thinking they’d be accused of political interference whatever their findings. They were eventually persuaded to look into twelve events, and investigated eight of them, finally issuing Fixed Penalty Notices to 126 people. But Boris Johnson received just one £50 fine, despite at least ‘dropping in’ to several parties, apparently on the flimsy basis that no. 10 is his home and so he was working in most cases. However, junior civil servants who cooperated initially with the Sue Gray internal report have been issued with many of the fines, possibly partially as a result of their confessions. They are reportedly furious!
Durham police are, meanwhile, investigatingone event that Keir Starmer was at. If they find Starmer guilty of an offence (for which he’s promised to resign), that would seem grossly unfair, as there was clearly no culture of negligence in his case, at most a marginal misinterpretation of the rules. I trust that their investigation is to demonstrate political neutrality, knowing that the Government was under investigation.
Maybe the Sue Gray report will strengthen the case that the Government, and Johnson in particular, were careless, negligent, dismissive, arrogant. I do hope that the public will continue to grow in their distrust of this selfish, arrogant and dishonest man, so that either he’s forced out of office or that he leads his party to a truly dreadful result in the General Election that must come by 2024.
May 9th: A huge shock for the Government, losing 487 council seats, consistently down in the polls, and with Labour more trusted than them on almost every criterion. But bigger still, they are threatened in their heartlands, particularly the South and South-West, by the Liberal Democrat surge, gaining 222 seats and 3 councils (returning to the same number of controlled councils as c. 2010). After Chesham & Amersham and North Shropshire, there are two tasty by-elections coming up too. The Government is finally looking very vulnerable.
May 4th: Many Conservative councillors are distancing themselves from their own party in government, with slogans such as ‘Local Conservatives’ and, even further, ‘Don’t punish local Conservatives for the mistakes made in Westminster’. The North Tyneside group have published pseudo-Green leaflets aiming to get some Labour voters to switch and save a few marginal Tory councillors. A tiny imprint has ‘NTCF’ (Conservative Federation), but for most people they look like Green Party leaflets, which they’re not! After all, it was local Conservative members who voted in Johnson as leader and hence Prime Minister, when his character and history were well-known.
This distancing is not new. During the Coalition years (whatever you think of that period), many local Lib Dem councillors lost their seats owing to general unhappiness with the national policies and compromises, and some campaigned with the designation ‘Focus Team’ and no mention of ‘Liberal Democrat’. I doubt this is effective and might even be counter-productive.
By Friday morning, we’ll see if there is indeed a substantial national swing in seat numbers, but it will be measured against 2018, when Theresa May’s government was already unpopular. Locally, the Lib Dems have a strong challenge in Weetslade ward, and the Greens in Whitley Bay. We share some aims (environment, and the need for scrutiny and challenge to this Labour ‘one-party state’), but remain distinct parties, especially at national level, where the Greens try to defend their ‘leave NATO’ policy – not at all sensible at this time!
April 19th: Desperate to displace headlines about lawbreaking at Number 10, and to shore up their ’base’, this dreadful Government have proposed an appalling plan for refugees – condemned by almost everyone who’s thought about the issue at all. The Civil Service are constrained, but have said it’s unclear whether it will be effective and hence value for money. It’s dishonest in that the UK takes a relatively small number of refugees, most of those crossing the Channel are genuine, and alternative safe and legal routes have been closed. It’s ineffective, as a deterrent works only if it’s known. It’s illegal, as it fails to deal properly with refugees. And it’s unethical and cruel. Perhaps most bizarre of all, Rees-Mogg asserts that it’s ’redemptive’. My view is much as Pope Francis’.
April 11th: Rishi Sunak impressed the public with his charm, confidence and ‘generosity’ with public spending. Many (including him!) thought he might be the next Prime Minister, but I always wondered – we knew nothing of any vision for the UK, ability in managing the executive decision-making or skill in building and managing a team. We did know that he’d been a hedge-fund manager, good at making money from insubstantial investments and manipulation of markets. In the past few weeks, his fall from grace has been spectacular – a budget that failed to address the cost-of-living crisis, apparent opposition to sensible energy/climate plans, and then his wife’s non-dom status for her fantastic wealth. Then, on top of all that. questions about his US and UK status.
On Thursday I was visiting Richmond in North Yorkshire, his constituency, and was by chance interviewed by an ITV team seeking the views of local residents. They featured my views at some length: https://twitter.com/ITVNewsPolitics/status/1512098733554610187 Some of the comments following the clip are hilarious! I was quite honest with them about who I was but they evidently thought the clip worth keeping. The whole tweet was re-tweeted by Wes Streeting (Shadow Cabinet), so it had lots of views!
April 6th: Today the National Insurance increase is implemented. On top of huge rises in energy costs, and a continuing squeeze on benefits and local authority budgets, times will be hard for many families. Yes, it’s possible to manage on less, and people used to know more about how to do that, but life wasn’t very good for many in those ‘nostalgic times’, and in any case, why should ordinary families be told to put up with things by people who don’t have to? When coupled with a casual and hypocritical attitude to the pandemic rules by Downing street, it’s clear that this Government is seriously out of touch. Many people remain to be convinced that Labour is ready for government, but increasingly they (and the Liberal Democrats) are seen as a serious party who cares.
The Government is also out of touch on other issues. Most people oppose the selling off of Channel 4 – pointless except as a piece of dogma. Most people are supportive of more on-shore wind turbines and against fracking, yet the Government is against one and favours the other. People support more Ukrainian refugees, but the Home Office makes that very difficult. They appear to be completely wrapped up in their own rhetoric. It’s to be hoped that they lose power sooner rather than later!
The immediate prospect of a challenge to the Government will come on May 5th in the local elections. Although primarily about local issues, and distorted to some extent by dissatisfaction that results from national funding but which impinges on other parties, it seems likely that many usual Conservative voters will stay at home, whilst opposition voters will turn out with greater enthusiasm. In North Tyneside, there are prospects of more opposition councillors from the Lib Dems and the Greens, who both had impressive gains in target wards. Although the overall political ‘colour’ of the two is very different, we share the aims of addressing the climate change, holding the local council to account, and scrutinising plans and decisions to set better priorities and ensure value for money.
March 14th: I’ve just watched short videos of arrests in Russian cities – one of a protestor with a card saying, literally, ‘two words’, and the other with a card that was completely blank. The Russian government is afraid of criticism. Much of its attitude is even more rooted in the past than Britain’s current nostalgia of ‘Dad’s Army’ and ‘Britannia rules the waves’.
But it’s also true that our governments have failed to tell the truth, in the sense of both words and actions. The belief that economic engagement would convert Russia, China and other autocracies to our liberal democracy was naive. Of course engagement, and particularly educating foreign students, is part of what’s needed, but sterner stuff must also be shown when such trust is clearly abused, as in Salisbury, Crimea, Syria, and substantial dependence on Russian energy supplies was a real risk, especially coupled with inadequate storage.
At the same time, our governments have failed to be honest with us about the need to pay our way – in taxes sufficient to provide the services we value, and in balancing our trade so that foreign investment can be selective rather than uncritical. The ‘golden visa’ scheme was always a terrible idea (actually introduced under Gordon Brown!), but should at least have had safeguards, notably a restriction on political donations for an initial period.
It’s commonplace to say ‘they’re all liars’ about our politicians, whilst expecting unrealistic things to be done, and voting for the best promises rather than the honest but more mundane ‘we’ll do what we can’. Vision is great, exaggerated promises are not.
February 8th: I decided some years ago that I hate dogma. That’s not a particular dogma, just all of it! There might be a very few exceptions, but these would be a few ‘truths’ for me, such as statements about the importance of truth itself, honesty, the value of human beings, the need to look after the world for the sake of our children and grandchildren, etc.
Dogma means (to me) an explicit statement of a belief that the holder is unwilling to question. I have no objection to strong beliefs, strongly argued, it’s the closed-mindedness that’s the problem, the ‘black-and-white’ view of the subject or the world. Just now, it’s party politics that’s at the forefront of my mind, but I will mention one other area.
Boris Johnson shouldn’t be Prime Minister. Increasingly, that’s a view held by many Conservative voters and MPs, as well as almost all others. It’s commonly said that by continuing to support him in post, those people are ‘putting party before country’, or ‘putting their own careers before principles’. I don’t think it’s so simple, though I’m not excusing it. It’s clear to me that for many of these MPs (and voters), there is a strong conviction that a Conservative government is best for the country, certainly in the longer-term and probably in the medium-term too. That is, even with doubts and problems at present, they continue to think that a Labour government will be worse for the country overall than almost any conceivable government by ‘their’ party. In this sense, they might believe they are putting country before anything else. Of course, an element of personal career is relevant, but the argument extends easily to: ‘I’ll be a better MP for my constituency than my opponent, because of my core values.’
Whilst I understand this mentality up to a point, it’s dangerous, as it can lead incrementally to acceptance, even advocacy, of bad policy, bad behaviour, bad management, etc. Surely most Conservative MPs would not have supported Johnson so willingly in 2019 if they’d known in advance how he might behave, how little he valued them, their opinions, their values.
A dogmatic position that says, in effect: any Conservative government, however bad, is always better than any Labour government, however good, is not a rational position, it’s a black-and-white dogma and should be called out and given no power. Of course, the same would be true for the converse.
Here’s my other example: When I was young, homosexuality was unknown, then weird, then a joke, then strange, then gradually more a fact of life. However, until I was about 25-30, I wasn’t wholly comfortable with this, whilst trying hard to be accepting. What finally brought me ‘off the fence’ was this: To hold the traditional view (of heterosexual lifelong marriage) was, in effect, to judge that any traditional marriage relationship, however bad, was automatically better than any other form of relationship, however good. That is, a dogmatic traditional position was clearly wrong and untenable for me. Thereafter, I accepted the validity and value of all good, committed, respectful relationships, hetero- or homo-sexual, whilst still rejecting any relationship that didn’t meet those values, or didn’t try hard to. I could add other rejected dogmas to these two, but that’s enough for today!
January 23rd: Boris Johnson is on the ropes, by all accounts and appearances. Parties (in no.10, in the garden, in his flat), threats to MPs, Islamophobia, on top of general dishonesty and incompetence, factional strife in his Party, and a growing cost-of-living crisis contribute to, at last, public opinion that he should resign or be sacked, with someone competent and honest in his place. Will it happen? Yes! Will it happen this week? Unclear.
Who would replace him? Sunak is front-runner, but we have no idea of his vision or competence, just his manner, and he has apparently little sympathy for the poor or the environment. If he takes over, then I hope the many problems are not shrugged off by him as ‘not his fault’, as any incoming PM must be seen to do something to alleviate them. I hope too that he doesn’t take over soon enough to get the benefit of the doubt in the May elections, but late enough for his competence to be as yet unclear.
PM is a job I’ll never have and couldn’t do, as my skin isn’t thick enough even if I had the ability! However, I sometimes think of what my first priorities might be in that position. Top of the list would be to reduce hostility and polarisation in Parliament, in the UK, with our European neighbours and beyond, for without that little effective governance is possible. I’d stop the hostility to asylum-seekers, but maybe process some in France if possible, with a clearer legal route otherwise to minimise the ‘boats’ problem.
I’d maintain masks in most indoor places to slow the pandemic, and slow the NHS vaccination deadline just a little to get more acceptance. I’d have a windfall tax on energy companies to offset the recent price rises and/or other costs on the poor.
For NI, I’d agree an SPS deal to ease the customs and border issues, and with the EU fix collaborations on Euratom, Horizon, and the musicians visa scheme. I’d revisit the Australia trade deal if possible to reinstate welfare and environmental standards.
There’s lots more! Much of the above doesn’t bring massive costs, but increases cooperation and trust, and partially tackles several crises. Good governance is more about the mundane than the dramatic, but honesty, trust and steady, small steps are usually the best way forward.

January 13th: I was gripped by Prime Minister’s Questions yesterday! As many said, Keir Starmer was aiming at an open goal, and scored repeatedly. Few Conservatives supported the PM at all; just a few asked boilerplate, irrelevant questions to try to take the heat off their ‘winning’ leader.
In 2019, many Conservative MPs, most Conservative members, and then sufficient voters, thought that Johnson, for all his known faults, would do a good enough job as PM, getting the country out of the endless, boring, Brexit debate (some Remainers thought this too), and there would be enough checks and balances to keep him from doing too much harm. As with Trump in the US, that was hopelessly optimistic. Brexit is an ongoing open sore, and Johnson gets worse, not better.
Before all the stuff about parties, and wallpaper, and dodgy dealings of all kinds, I often said that my chief regrets about the past six years were the lying, the disregard of courtesy and convention, the undermining or actual attacks on our highly-prized institutions (Rule of Law, human rights, the BBC, universities, animal welfare, the Civil Service, honesty in treaties and diplomacy, democracy, …….), and the shredding of our international reputation. These bothered me more than loss of freedom of movement or economic harm, important though those were.
Is Johnson finished? I don’t know – in the next week or so many Conservative MPs will find out if their constituents get more and more angry, or simmer down. What that party (or the Conservative Work-Event, as I call it now!) won’t want is a leadership election during March and April, with local elections coming up. They’ll either act very soon, or wait until the Summer.
If the former, then it’s likely Sunak will be the next PM. Apart from confidence and presentation, we know nothing about his abilities, and his experience is of privilege. He’d at least be able to stay in the same flat at number 10 if he wanted! But there are other Conservatives with more experience who’d stand more chance of tackling the crises of the pandemic, the economy, cost-of-living, etc.

October 28th: Our Prime Minister is in a bind, but one of his own making. He loves to impress, to have adulation, rather than personal liking as such. He’d like to be seen as a statesman, in the mould of Churchill – not everyone’s cup-of-tea, not always making the right decisions, but inspirational, motivational, helping to bring the country together in its hour of need. He surely thought that his breezy confidence would do the trick, to deal with outcomes of Brexit, of Covid, of the climate crisis, as other people’s energy and initiative would be harnessed to deliver a really great and ‘Global Britain’ that would be admired by others for its originality, toughness, vigour and determination.
Thus Johnson promised Brexit would be done and done well, that we’d beat this virus, that we’d lead the World in defeating the monster of climate change.
It’s the mentality of a teenager. In fact, the only way I can even think about Johnson is to regard him as an adolescent – brash, over-confident, happy to make his bold claims and his mess and leave others to sort it out later.
But those promises are mounting up, and will surely overwhelm his premiership before long. Brexit barriers are causing problems with Northern Ireland and with exports, and would stifle imports too if rules are imposed as planned. Stimuli to private enterprise are the Conservative counter to cuts in state funding, but there are more burdens on the former and insufficient of the latter, so foodbank use grows and we have an NHS in crisis – doctors and nurses stressed out and many leaving.
But the biggest of all is climate change, where Britain’s lead role looks tenuous at best. The Government’s plans are better than before, and better than many countries, but still far short, especially when Johnson’s sceptical Chancellor declines to address any real action, and too many interviewers talk only of the costs of net-zero rather than both investment and the cost of inaction. Similarly, cuts in aid, apart from the moral aspect (and repayment for our past exploitation), are likely to increase conflict, migration and prolongation of the pandemic.
Scepticism of government, and perhaps of much traditional authority, is part of what led to Brexit and this dreadful PM and Cabinet, but almost everything Johnson does makes things worse. It is to be hoped that some recent mildly rebellious speeches and acts by his own MPs and ex ministers are a sign that good sense might yet return to the Conservative Party, and allow Britain to rebuild its reputation and actually take a leading role on climate.

May 5th: An exhausting couple of days on Friday and Saturday as I attended the Count for NE Mayor, local ward councillors, and for Police & Crime Commissioner. I was reasonably pleased to come a ‘good third’ with 17% overall, and in second place in the Newcastle and Gateshead areas. Here’s the full results:
As well as the Independent, the successful candidate agreed verbally with me that ‘This shouldn’t really be a party-political position’, but in her speech of acceptance, mentioned the Labour Party about five times! In fact, I’m against direct election of any senior position, as voting by party or by quality of public speaking neglects the qualities often needed to do the actual job. The same problem occurred with Johnson and Corbyn – both popular in the constituencies that voted for them, and neither remotely suitable to do the full job of leadership.
However, I do wish Susan Dungworth well and I’m sure she’ll work hard. I hope it works out well.
Somewhat separately, a good few days for the Liberal Democrats, with over 100 councillors gained and high hopes for the long-awaited General Election. And as well as that interesting result to come, what’s going to happen in the Conservative Party? Will it fracture? Will it unite but further Right?

October 3rd: Midst disaster and worry over the Middle East, Starmer’s acceptance of gifts is small beer, but the general cynicism about politics and politicians needs to be tackled. Genuine Government achievements in the medium to long term will be most effective, but the ‘optics’ matter too. Whilst it’s perfectly true that leading Conservatives were much worse, shameless and dishonest about gifts, lobbying and preferential treatment, it’s surprising that Starmer didn’t realise that being seen to set a good example would help his cause. Yes, he follows the rules, but Johnson’s and Trump’s successes show that this in itself doesn’t win many friends.
The Israeli government and IDF are doing terrible things, only some of which even fall under the heading of self-defence. If citizens of the West Bank were being properly treated, instead of the security forces tacitly (or even actively) colluding with aggression by ‘settlers’, it would be easier to believe that Israel was only defending itself. And UN resolutions over the years were evidently not enough – some sanctions should have enforced withdrawal from the occupied territories, and punished those who attacked ordinary Palestinians there. Moreover, Netanyahu openly favoured Hamas to avoid Palestinian unity, and members of his cabinet make clear that they despise all those people and wish to remove them all. In addition, Trump withdrew from the Iran nuclear deal, but the Obama administration should have offered more reward to Tehran for that, which might have helped the credibility of the then moderate President. I dread what might happen next.
We’re also seeing yet more film of floods and climate disruption, yet too many people still don’t take seriously the need for change. It’s not just governments, who need to see that people will agree to change and will vote for it, nor technology, which is only part of the solution. We need to reduce, reuse, repair, recycle, and to show self-restraint in use of water, energy and other resources. The world can’t afford a car for every person, even an electric one!

27th March: The North of Tyne area includes busy cities and large towns, mostly in the south-east of the area, but Northumberland is the most sparsely-populated county in England, with huge areas of beautiful countryside, villages, farms and hills. A real challenge for the Mayor will be to balance the needs of all these areas, and to help sustain rural life and industry.
Last weekend I was knocking on doors in Longframlington, with local Liberal Democrats, finding out what the residents are most bothered about in their area. It’s not the most isolated of communities, with some people commuting into Morpeth, and with some shops and cafes, but its needs are not the same as the major towns.

May 3rd: Everyone will now know that May 1st was a disaster for the Conservative Party, not forgiven for their incompetence and dishonesty over 14 years, during which they failed by every measure, whether it be financial management, migration, international reputation, etc. They weren’t even ‘conservative’, trashing our institutions and all the things that (used to) give Britain a strong reputation and so much ‘soft power’.
Of course, a local election shouldn’t just reflect the national mood, but it usually does. Local Lib Dem councillors suffered badly in the period c.2013-2017 or so. And this time, not only were Conservatives not credible, but Labour managed to skip their ‘honeymoon period’ in government too, creating an impression of an uncaring regime in their determination to be seen as financially prudent.
It was a good day for the Lib Dems, with over 300 councillors gained, and control of three councils – Cambridge, Oxford and Shropshire.
What about Reform? They are cock-a-hoop with over 600 councillors and 10 councils. But any talk of future government is highly questionable. They appear to have no real policies, a leader who hates sharing power (members get no say on policy), and minimal experience in local government. One successful candidate talked of ‘waste’ but could only think of biscuits in council meetings. It’s highly probable that within a year they’ll find they can’t do very much, especially when funding is so tight, and that waste is not only less than they think but is very hard to reduce.
The local Elected Mayor contest in North Tyneside led to a Labour Mayor again, but by a small margin of 444 votes. I did a little better than last time, but hoped for more. Here’s the results:

March 28th: Between 2004-2011, the Liberal Democrats ran Newcastle City Council. We brought the finances under control and provided value for money (Council Tax rises at or below inflation), doubled recycling rates, and strengthened communities instead of the previous focus on the City Centre. This week the Newcastle LD group launch their manifesto for the May local elections. I was happy to join them for a presentation and discussion, with just a mention of the North of Tyne Mayoral election and, of course, Brexit (sigh!).
Author: johnapplebyld
A fishy tale
29th March: Brexit discussions in chaos in London, but I had a good morning visiting the Fish Quay at North Shields, meeting Nik Hanlon (managing director) and Adam Riley to hear about their exciting plans to refurbish the quay, develop more processing facilities, and expand visitor attractions. This project has the potential to maintain and perhaps expand jobs, as well as to promote the heritage of the Tyne and increase tourism. Moving the ferry landing (likely to happen) will also help bring people to the Fish Quay, some straight off the North Sea ferries?
Sustainable villages
27th March: The North of Tyne area includes busy cities and large towns, mostly in the south-east of the area, but Northumberland is the most sparsely-populated county in England, with huge areas of beautiful countryside, villages, farms and hills. A real challenge for the Mayor will be to balance the needs of all these areas, and to help sustain rural life and industry.
Last weekend I was knocking on doors in Longframlington, with local Liberal Democrats, finding out what the residents are most bothered about in their area. It’s not the most isolated of communities, with some people commuting into Morpeth, and with some shops and cafes, but its needs are not the same as the major towns.
The next generation
22nd March: This morning I talked to Year 12 students at Duke’s Secondary School in Ashington. I explained some of the background and aims of the new North of Tyne Authority, and why I was standing for Mayor. Also why the South of Tyne authorities had been doubtful, linked to why powers here will be limited for now.
The students asked some good questions – about Environment, Transport, Brexit, Education, Representation, and why they should trust what I said! On trust, I said I’d always be honest if I didn’t know an answer, if the problem would take a long time to solve or was outside my powers, and I’m always willing to credit other individuals and parties for good policies and actions. I also said that representation, whether a school council, a Citizens’ Assembly (which I favour for setting local and regional priorities) or any other level, had to give real influence, not just cosmetic.
100,000 strong
March 19th: A very good meeting with representatives of the Federation of Small Businesses (FSB). Issues that particularly concern these often quite small companies include cash-flow, owing to late payment by larger organisations, and the difficulties of competing in procurement for public works. We talked about how information and support might be improved to help people who often haven’t time or expert knowledge. I was amazed to discover that there are 100,000 sole-trader/self-employed businesses in the North-East, generating around £4 billion in economic activity. They are also interested in how to contribute to a carbon-neutral economy, and in improving skills training for staff.
Town Centres fit for the Future
March 17th: Conference debates this important issue, summarised by the LD spokesperson:
“The crisis we are witnessing in our town centres is clear to us all. Whilst Brexit is partly responsible, at the root of the issue is our broken business rates system.
“It is only right we welcome the benefits of the 21st century economy, but we cannot ignore the plight of our high streets and all those affected. As more and more individuals switch to online retail, businesses are struggling and thousands of jobs are being lost.
“Business rates should be replaced with a land value tax that encourages businesses to invest, whilst we must also empower local areas by reforming planning and supporting entrepreneurs. It is not to late to save our town centres and these measures would do just that.”
Demanding better
Sunday 17th: Another day at the LibDem conference in York. Wholehearted resolutions to improve air quality by reducing petrol and diesel vehicles and avoiding idling engines, and another to reinstate adequate legal aid and access to justice.
Also a new Supporters Scheme to engage those with similar values but who don’t want to commit too far.
But like most conferences, the best bit is meeting people. And, as a bonus, my B&B proprietor turned out to be a former professional footballer (Man City, York, etc) who gave me a signed copy of his memoirs!
York – LibDem Conference
March 15th: The Libdems are gathered, energised about the possibility of a People’s Vote, still angry that people were so misled about Brexit. Why shouldn’t people get to vote on the actual plan? Why shouldn’t views change in 3 years? Strike ballots are invalid after 6 months – Conservative legislation!
Borderlands funding – good news!
The Chancellor’s Spring Statement included some good news, which, with the Scottish Government, means more funding for the ‘Borderlands’ initiative – a collaboration between English and Scottish councils including Northumberland.
The Press Release (full document below) includes this section:
Borderlands Partnership welcomes Governments’ funding commitment.
The Borderlands Partnership has welcomed the commitment in the Spring Statement and the announcement of a £345 million deal from the UK and Scottish Governments, describing the news as a ‘game changer’. The multi-million-pound funding stream comes just six months after the Borderlands Inclusive Growth Deal proposal was presented to the two Governments. And it will mean thousands of new job opportunities, millions of extra tourists to the area, improved digital connectivity and unlocking investment in towns across the region generating a predicted £1.3bn return on the Governments’ investment.
What on Earth – Government Brexit meltdown!
This evening, the House of Commons voted to remove ‘no-deal’ from any options for Brexit. Minutes later, the Government applied a three-line whip to its MPs to vote against this amended motion, i.e. to retain the possibility of a ‘no-deal’ Brexit, and failed. The Government was in disarray, with Ministers ignoring their leader’s instructions.
‘N0 deal’ should be described as ‘scrap all deals’, as 40+ trade deals would vanish, the proposed zero tariffs would destroy many businesses, and we’d spend 5-10 years negotiating new deals from a position of weakness.
I’ve always been strongly opposed to Brexit, whilst recognising the faults of the EU, but I hope many people now realise that leaving is complicated and brings many disadvantages, though ‘sovereignty’ and ‘control’ sound good. If the promises had been kept, then maybe it could have been justified. Those included:
Vote Leave offical statement: ‘We will negotiate the terms of a new deal before we start any legal process to leave.’ – but the legal process was started immediately.
Jacob Rees-Mogg: ‘We could have two referendums. As it happens, it might make more sense to have the second referendum after the renegotiation is completed.’ – but Brexiters have fought hard against this.
Apart from broken promises (and notice that those ‘promises’ are no longer used to justify Brexit, only the statement that ‘it’s the will of the people’), there were outright lies too:
Leave campaign: ’80 million Turks would be entitled to enter the UK once Turkey joins the EU.’ – but there was no prospect of Turkey joining for many years.

This page gives a brief outline of my views and what I hoped to do if possible as North of Tyne Mayor if elected in 2019 (always remembering the part that’s south of the Tyne – so I call this ‘North of Tyne Plus‘.
Below you’ll find information about: Promoting the Area, Working Together, Better Devolution, Europe, Environment, Air Quality, Education, Jobs & Economy, Rural Affairs, Housing, Transport, Health & Wellbeing.
Promoting the area: The Mayor will be a voice for the whole North of Tyne area – a voice within the area (ensuring people get heard by politicians and decision-makers) and beyond (with other areas, Government and internationally). We need to feel pride in our wonderful and energetic people and heritage. Too often southerners think we’re remote, we should travel to them. We even get forgotten in the weather forecast some days!
Working together: The powers of the new Mayor and Combined Authority are limited, but we can achieve much together – building trust is important. Firstly, the three Local Authorities need to coordinate what they do – the whole can be greater than the sum of the parts. Secondly, we need to work together to use the new budget and powers we have. Thirdly, we need to be much better at involving the people of the area, the employers, and public and voluntary sectors in a shared vision and purpose.
Better Devolution: The new Mayor and Combined Authority will be weaker than any other similar scheme – London, Manchester, Teesside. That’s because Gateshead, Durham, South Tyneside and Sunderland didn’t agree to join the proposals at this stage. It’s important to encourage them to do so, so we can have full powers over Transport and others areas, and much greater ability both to work across the North-East and to lobby Westminster. I’d aim to re-establish a North-East Constitutional Convention to explore this.
Europe: Brexit in any form will be bad for the UK, damaging our economy and reducing our influence on the World stage. By ourselves, we’ll be less able to negotiate good trade deals, we’ll not be listened to in political matters, and environmental progress will be harder. Our reputation and influence have already been badly damaged. Europe needs some reforms, but much that’s blamed on the EU is a result either of global change or our own government’s failure to use the rules well. For example, we’re the only country that’s allowed half our fishing quota to be sold to foreign companies. Although another referendum would be divisive, so will any alternatives, including the bad feelings and social damage from a reduced economy.
Environment: We are now in a Climate Emergency. I salute and welcome the attention now being given to this vital issue as a result of the school strikes and the Extinction Rebellion, though I do not endorse all the actions taken. Technology is part of the answer, but bold political action is needed, and also individual acceptance of the unacceptable cost of some luxuries, like taking cheap holidays abroad. Dualling the A1 is recommended by almost everyone, but more roads means more traffic – I’d approve only limited work on particular bottlenecks. Even more urgent, probably, is the dramatic fall in insect numbers owing to over-use of chemicals and climate too. This could threaten the world’s food supply and create famines in the not-too-distant future. The EU has fortunately banned nicotinoid insecticides and are considering other chemicals.
Other Environmental actions needed are to reduce the use of private vehicles, and clean up any we do use – electric cars, car-clubs (can be run in small villages!). We also need green energy – I’d support more on-shore wind power if the local community sees some benefit from it. New homes should all have good insulation and solar panels: can planning conditions be amended to require this?
Air Quality: Poor air is killing people. Some places, like Nottingham, have taken action sooner and avoided unpopular ‘quick fixes’ that merely stop people driving. We need to identify the long-term solution, then agree how to get there. For cities (but also towns like Alnwick) reduced car traffic is needed, but achieved by making the city attractive and modifying bus lanes, parking and increasing cycle lanes, not merely adding costs and restrictions. I’d set up a Mayoral Commission on Air Quality to explore this further.
Education: Educational provision is patchy, especially away from the city. The Adult Education budget needs focussing on basic skills (reading, numeracy, and IT) as employers have identified this need, and IT skills are needed also for job and benefit applications. The Mayor will help finalise and promote the School Improvement Challenge being put to Government, and which will include mental health support.
Jobs and Economy: The NE Local Enterprise Partnership, working with the new Combined Authority, has responsibility for promoting ‘inclusive employment’ and development of the economy. A key aim, in my view, is to support and promote small businesses, urban and rural, which often lack the knowledge, expertise and time to access funding and public sector procurement. An apprenticeship can be valuable to a small business, who must pay only 10% of the cost, but they might not know this. Public sector work is usually snapped up by big companies as the procedures and paperwork are too onerous. There should be support units for small businesses across North of Tyne to ensure these worthwhile firms flourish. We must also encourage lasting jobs that pay the Living Wage too.
Rural affairs: Northumberland is a very sparsely populated county, but we boast of its loveliness and want it to continue. That means supporting agriculture and rural industry, and helping to develop sustainable rural communities. Citizens Assemblies are often cited as a means of engaging people and gauging views – we need these in rural areas and not just the city. Local office/workshop space with affordable homes, and with excellent IT connectivity, are needed and might reduce transport needs. Most of all, though, we need to remember and involve these areas – ‘North of Tyne’ starts badly by missing out a large chunk of Northumberland! Some small villages have only one public building – a church or pub – so I’d support using these wherever possible for othe activities. Could IT access be supported in pubs as well as churches for those unable to access benefits, services and applying for jobs?
Housing: Every government promises more housing, but it’s expensive and often controversial to site. There is ample evidence that many brownfield sites are highly suitable for development, so a Register of Brownfield Sites is needed, with greenfield development very limited. Revised planning rules are needed to ensure that social benefits and environmental factors play a greater part in planning decisions. Borrowing powers for local authorities have recently been relaxed and should be used to focus on affordable and specialist housing.
Transport: The poor devolution settlement we’ve been offered will be much better if we can bring Gateshead, Sunderland etc. into a wider scheme. That would then include full transport powers, more integration with police and other services, and potentially health powers too (like Manchester). With or without that, we need to promote public transport, cleaner buses, cycling and walking routes, and lobby for major improvements including the East Coast main line bottlenecks near Gateshead (re-open the Leeming line), further Metro work (dualling the track near Jarrow), and selective improvement to the A1 (but more roads can mean more cars!). Rural transport needs a mix of buses, ‘dial-a-ride’ services, car-clubs (can be based in villages), but the long-term approach must be to identify and support rural sustainability overall – quite complex!
Health and Wellbeing: The Mayor will have no direct health powers, but health and well-being involve many factors. The prospect of a good and secure job on the Living Wage, exercise encouraged through cycling and walking, better air quality, and improved education leading to satisfaction can all be addressed. The draft School Improvement Challenge also mentions mental health, and support for this in schools should also be championed by the Mayor. Antibiotic resistance is a major threat to the health of society: we might not be able to do much locally but should add our voice whenever we can.

November 22nd: Many Lib Dem members are furious that Ed Davey, and the party, are saying little about Europe, and clearly not committing to rejoining at the earliest possible date. They say things like: ‘There’s no-one arguing for EU membership, even though a clear majority now believe that leaving was a mistake, and have a favourable view of the EU!’ Starmer seems to be taking a similar line to Davey, though it’s well-known that he wanted to Remain. So why are they silent on this?
Last year, although most Labour supporters, and nearly all Lib Dem supporters, wanted to Remain, once Johnson got his majority, there was no stopping him (and it’s worth remembering that the General Election was called because the PM controlled HoC business and had withdrawn the Withdrawal Agreement, making ‘no-deal’ the default), so in 2020 the debate changed. I think both Davey and Starmer calculated that Johnson could be relied on to mess things up, and their job was to help that along, with the expectation that he’d look more and more ridiculous and dishonest. Avoiding giving him ammunition was Starmer’s idea, I think – let him stew in his own juice!
As well as avoiding the ‘it’s all the fault of Remoaners!’ tag, another key aim was to get the press turning against the Government – something that’s now happening. That works provided the Opposition doesn’t offer too many easy attack lines.
Finally, we all hope that Johnson (who isn’t actually insane, completely stupid, and is probably well-advised usually) will agree some kind of deal with the EU at the last moment. As this will be a massive U-turn, and he’ll try to present that to his own party as a victory, the worst thing to do right now is to make that harder for him, almost to force him to stick to his own bad script. And what strengthens my conviction is that he is doing things to appease his right-wing (defence increases, public-sector pay freeze) that will make his U-turn less offensive to them. Much as we might despise the man, for dishonesty, selfishness, laziness, etc, surely we want him to concede what’s needed to the EU to avoid food shortages, closure of industry, the death of farming, and a general huge hit to the economy.
He’s painted himself into a corner. We might be gleeful about that, but it’s much more important just now to allow him to jump out of it. There’ll still be the pandemic, and a major shock to the economy, and I think both Davey and Starmer will pivot quite rapidly to being more ‘I told you so’ and pro-EU once the public can see the horrible mess Johnson and his shower have got us into.

January 13th: I was gripped by Prime Minister’s Questions yesterday! As many said, Keir Starmer was aiming at an open goal, and scored repeatedly. Few Conservatives supported the PM at all; just a few asked boilerplate, irrelevant questions to try to take the heat off their ‘winning’ leader.
In 2019, many Conservative MPs, most Conservative members, and then sufficient voters, thought that Johnson, for all his known faults, would do a good enough job as PM, getting the country out of the endless, boring, Brexit debate (some Remainers thought this too), and there would be enough checks and balances to keep him from doing too much harm. As with Trump in the US, that was hopelessly optimistic. Brexit is an ongoing open sore, and Johnson gets worse, not better.
Before all the stuff about parties, and wallpaper, and dodgy dealings of all kinds, I often said that my chief regrets about the past six years were the lying, the disregard of courtesy and convention, the undermining or actual attacks on our highly-prized institutions (Rule of Law, human rights, the BBC, universities, animal welfare, the Civil Service, honesty in treaties and diplomacy, democracy, …….), and the shredding of our international reputation. These bothered me more than loss of freedom of movement or economic harm, important though those were.
Is Johnson finished? I don’t know – in the next week or so many Conservative MPs will find out if their constituents get more and more angry, or simmer down. What that party (or the Conservative Work-Event, as I call it now!) won’t want is a leadership election during March and April, with local elections coming up. They’ll either act very soon, or wait until the Summer.
If the former, then it’s likely Sunak will be the next PM. Apart from confidence and presentation, we know nothing about his abilities, and his experience is of privilege. He’d at least be able to stay in the same flat at number 10 if he wanted! But there are other Conservatives with more experience who’d stand more chance of tackling the crises of the pandemic, the economy, cost-of-living, etc.

Weds 20th: The Liberal Democrat Manifesto has been published today – see: http://www.libdems.org.uk/plan . This is an ambitious set of policies that are all possible – fully costed and not a spending spree like the Conservatives. They used to be the party of financial prudence, but seem to have fallen for the ‘magic money tree’ concept they previously ridiculed. In any case, it’s hard to believe anything said by this Prime Minister, who was twice sacked for lying in his newspaper articles. His most important lie just now is that it was Parliament who blocked Brexit and forced the General Election. In fact, it was firstly the ERG and DUP (and Johnson himself) not accepting Theresa May’s proposals (bad, but better than his own), and then Johnson not allowing Parliament time to scrutinise the amended proposals.
On reflection, the policies I proposed on this site when standing for Mayor of the ‘North of Tyne’ still largely apply to what’s needed in this region, but I’m very happy to embrace those in the national manifesto. Those include (apart from stopping Brexit!): ambitious plans to address the Climate Emergency, help schools and childcare, address the social care crisis, and invest in infrastructure including in the North. See also the BBC commentary, around 1pm today, from:
“The Liberal Democrat manifesto is out. I’ve read it! This thread gives a northern take on it, so I’ve picked the bits that I think have the most regional relevance. Overall there is an emphasis on increased regional investment, and more powers and resources for councils…” and follow the whole thread.

July 18th: Boris Johnson got rid of most of the most talented moderates in his parliamentary party, demanding all candidates in 2019 and all MPs since should show total loyalty to him and the Brexit project. That meant many, less courageous, MPs swallowing their pride and principles to defend the indefensible, such as lies about ‘forty new hospitals’ and ‘Northern Ireland’s economy lagging behind the rest of Britain’, trashing our reputation for integrity and reliability, and adopting populist but ineffective policies such as increased prison sentences and the appalling Rwanda policy.
Finally forced out by his dishonesty and irresponsibility over ‘Partygate’ and the Pincher affair, Johnson leaves behind a sorry state of both UK policy and economy, and of possible successors. The debates on TV, in the press and on Twitter have brought us little honesty, few ideas, and much mud-slinging about the candidates’ own involvement and about each other. The third TV debate has been cancelled as two leading candidates could see these pubic viewings were just making them all look bad. Recall that Johnson refused to participate in all but one TV debate in 2019 and also swerved the hardest interview experienced by the other leaders in the 2019 General Election.
Whoever is chosen might get a small ‘bounce’, and might genuinely be a bit more honest than Johnson, but it is to be hoped that currently greater trust in Keir Starmer won’t evaporate, and that our new PM won’t adopt really stupid policies, rashly hoping for some populist revival of support.

May 27th: The Sue Gray report is out – enough there to destroy any normal Prime Minister, but perhaps not this one. Rumblings from discontented backbenchers and former ministers, but nervousness that an attempt to unseat him will fail and make things worse. He should never have been shortlisted for the membership to vote on a leader, just as Corbyn shouldn’t have been for Labour, giving the electorate an invidious choice in 2019. It’s nonsense to think there’s no suitable replacement, though some talented and (more) principled MPs might be reluctant to spend two years mopping up only to lose a General Election and share some of the blame.
And a huge £15bn support package, whilst essential, looks like both an attempted distraction and a complete contradiction of what’s been said and believed by this Government. Their MPs were whipped only a few days ago to vote against a windfall tax, which Labour are now crowing about, but which in fact was called for by the Lib Dems some months earlier!
May 19th: The Met Police were reluctant to investigate lockdown parties at no. 10, presumably thinking they’d be accused of political interference whatever their findings. They were eventually persuaded to look into twelve events, and investigated eight of them, finally issuing Fixed Penalty Notices to 126 people. But Boris Johnson received just one £50 fine, despite at least ‘dropping in’ to several parties, apparently on the flimsy basis that no. 10 is his home and so he was working in most cases. However, junior civil servants who cooperated initially with the Sue Gray internal report have been issued with many of the fines, possibly partially as a result of their confessions. They are reportedly furious!
Durham police are, meanwhile, investigatingone event that Keir Starmer was at. If they find Starmer guilty of an offence (for which he’s promised to resign), that would seem grossly unfair, as there was clearly no culture of negligence in his case, at most a marginal misinterpretation of the rules. I trust that their investigation is to demonstrate political neutrality, knowing that the Government was under investigation.
Maybe the Sue Gray report will strengthen the case that the Government, and Johnson in particular, were careless, negligent, dismissive, arrogant. I do hope that the public will continue to grow in their distrust of this selfish, arrogant and dishonest man, so that either he’s forced out of office or that he leads his party to a truly dreadful result in the General Election that must come by 2024.
May 9th: A huge shock for the Government, losing 487 council seats, consistently down in the polls, and with Labour more trusted than them on almost every criterion. But bigger still, they are threatened in their heartlands, particularly the South and South-West, by the Liberal Democrat surge, gaining 222 seats and 3 councils (returning to the same number of controlled councils as c. 2010). After Chesham & Amersham and North Shropshire, there are two tasty by-elections coming up too. The Government is finally looking very vulnerable.
May 4th: Many Conservative councillors are distancing themselves from their own party in government, with slogans such as ‘Local Conservatives’ and, even further, ‘Don’t punish local Conservatives for the mistakes made in Westminster’. The North Tyneside group have published pseudo-Green leaflets aiming to get some Labour voters to switch and save a few marginal Tory councillors. A tiny imprint has ‘NTCF’ (Conservative Federation), but for most people they look like Green Party leaflets, which they’re not! After all, it was local Conservative members who voted in Johnson as leader and hence Prime Minister, when his character and history were well-known.
This distancing is not new. During the Coalition years (whatever you think of that period), many local Lib Dem councillors lost their seats owing to general unhappiness with the national policies and compromises, and some campaigned with the designation ‘Focus Team’ and no mention of ‘Liberal Democrat’. I doubt this is effective and might even be counter-productive.
By Friday morning, we’ll see if there is indeed a substantial national swing in seat numbers, but it will be measured against 2018, when Theresa May’s government was already unpopular. Locally, the Lib Dems have a strong challenge in Weetslade ward, and the Greens in Whitley Bay. We share some aims (environment, and the need for scrutiny and challenge to this Labour ‘one-party state’), but remain distinct parties, especially at national level, where the Greens try to defend their ‘leave NATO’ policy – not at all sensible at this time!
April 19th: Desperate to displace headlines about lawbreaking at Number 10, and to shore up their ’base’, this dreadful Government have proposed an appalling plan for refugees – condemned by almost everyone who’s thought about the issue at all. The Civil Service are constrained, but have said it’s unclear whether it will be effective and hence value for money. It’s dishonest in that the UK takes a relatively small number of refugees, most of those crossing the Channel are genuine, and alternative safe and legal routes have been closed. It’s ineffective, as a deterrent works only if it’s known. It’s illegal, as it fails to deal properly with refugees. And it’s unethical and cruel. Perhaps most bizarre of all, Rees-Mogg asserts that it’s ’redemptive’. My view is much as Pope Francis’.
April 11th: Rishi Sunak impressed the public with his charm, confidence and ‘generosity’ with public spending. Many (including him!) thought he might be the next Prime Minister, but I always wondered – we knew nothing of any vision for the UK, ability in managing the executive decision-making or skill in building and managing a team. We did know that he’d been a hedge-fund manager, good at making money from insubstantial investments and manipulation of markets. In the past few weeks, his fall from grace has been spectacular – a budget that failed to address the cost-of-living crisis, apparent opposition to sensible energy/climate plans, and then his wife’s non-dom status for her fantastic wealth. Then, on top of all that. questions about his US and UK status.
On Thursday I was visiting Richmond in North Yorkshire, his constituency, and was by chance interviewed by an ITV team seeking the views of local residents. They featured my views at some length: https://twitter.com/ITVNewsPolitics/status/1512098733554610187 Some of the comments following the clip are hilarious! I was quite honest with them about who I was but they evidently thought the clip worth keeping. The whole tweet was re-tweeted by Wes Streeting (Shadow Cabinet), so it had lots of views!
April 6th: Today the National Insurance increase is implemented. On top of huge rises in energy costs, and a continuing squeeze on benefits and local authority budgets, times will be hard for many families. Yes, it’s possible to manage on less, and people used to know more about how to do that, but life wasn’t very good for many in those ‘nostalgic times’, and in any case, why should ordinary families be told to put up with things by people who don’t have to? When coupled with a casual and hypocritical attitude to the pandemic rules by Downing street, it’s clear that this Government is seriously out of touch. Many people remain to be convinced that Labour is ready for government, but increasingly they (and the Liberal Democrats) are seen as a serious party who cares.
The Government is also out of touch on other issues. Most people oppose the selling off of Channel 4 – pointless except as a piece of dogma. Most people are supportive of more on-shore wind turbines and against fracking, yet the Government is against one and favours the other. People support more Ukrainian refugees, but the Home Office makes that very difficult. They appear to be completely wrapped up in their own rhetoric. It’s to be hoped that they lose power sooner rather than later!
The immediate prospect of a challenge to the Government will come on May 5th in the local elections. Although primarily about local issues, and distorted to some extent by dissatisfaction that results from national funding but which impinges on other parties, it seems likely that many usual Conservative voters will stay at home, whilst opposition voters will turn out with greater enthusiasm. In North Tyneside, there are prospects of more opposition councillors from the Lib Dems and the Greens, who both had impressive gains in target wards. Although the overall political ‘colour’ of the two is very different, we share the aims of addressing the climate change, holding the local council to account, and scrutinising plans and decisions to set better priorities and ensure value for money.
March 14th: I’ve just watched short videos of arrests in Russian cities – one of a protestor with a card saying, literally, ‘two words’, and the other with a card that was completely blank. The Russian government is afraid of criticism. Much of its attitude is even more rooted in the past than Britain’s current nostalgia of ‘Dad’s Army’ and ‘Britannia rules the waves’.
But it’s also true that our governments have failed to tell the truth, in the sense of both words and actions. The belief that economic engagement would convert Russia, China and other autocracies to our liberal democracy was naive. Of course engagement, and particularly educating foreign students, is part of what’s needed, but sterner stuff must also be shown when such trust is clearly abused, as in Salisbury, Crimea, Syria, and substantial dependence on Russian energy supplies was a real risk, especially coupled with inadequate storage.
At the same time, our governments have failed to be honest with us about the need to pay our way – in taxes sufficient to provide the services we value, and in balancing our trade so that foreign investment can be selective rather than uncritical. The ‘golden visa’ scheme was always a terrible idea (actually introduced under Gordon Brown!), but should at least have had safeguards, notably a restriction on political donations for an initial period.
It’s commonplace to say ‘they’re all liars’ about our politicians, whilst expecting unrealistic things to be done, and voting for the best promises rather than the honest but more mundane ‘we’ll do what we can’. Vision is great, exaggerated promises are not.
February 8th: I decided some years ago that I hate dogma. That’s not a particular dogma, just all of it! There might be a very few exceptions, but these would be a few ‘truths’ for me, such as statements about the importance of truth itself, honesty, the value of human beings, the need to look after the world for the sake of our children and grandchildren, etc.
Dogma means (to me) an explicit statement of a belief that the holder is unwilling to question. I have no objection to strong beliefs, strongly argued, it’s the closed-mindedness that’s the problem, the ‘black-and-white’ view of the subject or the world. Just now, it’s party politics that’s at the forefront of my mind, but I will mention one other area.
Boris Johnson shouldn’t be Prime Minister. Increasingly, that’s a view held by many Conservative voters and MPs, as well as almost all others. It’s commonly said that by continuing to support him in post, those people are ‘putting party before country’, or ‘putting their own careers before principles’. I don’t think it’s so simple, though I’m not excusing it. It’s clear to me that for many of these MPs (and voters), there is a strong conviction that a Conservative government is best for the country, certainly in the longer-term and probably in the medium-term too. That is, even with doubts and problems at present, they continue to think that a Labour government will be worse for the country overall than almost any conceivable government by ‘their’ party. In this sense, they might believe they are putting country before anything else. Of course, an element of personal career is relevant, but the argument extends easily to: ‘I’ll be a better MP for my constituency than my opponent, because of my core values.’
Whilst I understand this mentality up to a point, it’s dangerous, as it can lead incrementally to acceptance, even advocacy, of bad policy, bad behaviour, bad management, etc. Surely most Conservative MPs would not have supported Johnson so willingly in 2019 if they’d known in advance how he might behave, how little he valued them, their opinions, their values.
A dogmatic position that says, in effect: any Conservative government, however bad, is always better than any Labour government, however good, is not a rational position, it’s a black-and-white dogma and should be called out and given no power. Of course, the same would be true for the converse.
Here’s my other example: When I was young, homosexuality was unknown, then weird, then a joke, then strange, then gradually more a fact of life. However, until I was about 25-30, I wasn’t wholly comfortable with this, whilst trying hard to be accepting. What finally brought me ‘off the fence’ was this: To hold the traditional view (of heterosexual lifelong marriage) was, in effect, to judge that any traditional marriage relationship, however bad, was automatically better than any other form of relationship, however good. That is, a dogmatic traditional position was clearly wrong and untenable for me. Thereafter, I accepted the validity and value of all good, committed, respectful relationships, hetero- or homo-sexual, whilst still rejecting any relationship that didn’t meet those values, or didn’t try hard to. I could add other rejected dogmas to these two, but that’s enough for today!
January 23rd: Boris Johnson is on the ropes, by all accounts and appearances. Parties (in no.10, in the garden, in his flat), threats to MPs, Islamophobia, on top of general dishonesty and incompetence, factional strife in his Party, and a growing cost-of-living crisis contribute to, at last, public opinion that he should resign or be sacked, with someone competent and honest in his place. Will it happen? Yes! Will it happen this week? Unclear.
Who would replace him? Sunak is front-runner, but we have no idea of his vision or competence, just his manner, and he has apparently little sympathy for the poor or the environment. If he takes over, then I hope the many problems are not shrugged off by him as ‘not his fault’, as any incoming PM must be seen to do something to alleviate them. I hope too that he doesn’t take over soon enough to get the benefit of the doubt in the May elections, but late enough for his competence to be as yet unclear.
PM is a job I’ll never have and couldn’t do, as my skin isn’t thick enough even if I had the ability! However, I sometimes think of what my first priorities might be in that position. Top of the list would be to reduce hostility and polarisation in Parliament, in the UK, with our European neighbours and beyond, for without that little effective governance is possible. I’d stop the hostility to asylum-seekers, but maybe process some in France if possible, with a clearer legal route otherwise to minimise the ‘boats’ problem.
I’d maintain masks in most indoor places to slow the pandemic, and slow the NHS vaccination deadline just a little to get more acceptance. I’d have a windfall tax on energy companies to offset the recent price rises and/or other costs on the poor.
For NI, I’d agree an SPS deal to ease the customs and border issues, and with the EU fix collaborations on Euratom, Horizon, and the musicians visa scheme. I’d revisit the Australia trade deal if possible to reinstate welfare and environmental standards.
There’s lots more! Much of the above doesn’t bring massive costs, but increases cooperation and trust, and partially tackles several crises. Good governance is more about the mundane than the dramatic, but honesty, trust and steady, small steps are usually the best way forward.
