May 19th: The Met Police were reluctant to investigate lockdown parties at no. 10, presumably thinking they’d be accused of political interference whatever their findings. They were eventually persuaded to look into twelve events, and investigated eight of them, finally issuing Fixed Penalty Notices to 126 people. But Boris Johnson received just one £50 fine, despite at least ‘dropping in’ to several parties, apparently on the flimsy basis that no. 10 is his home and so he was working in most cases. However, junior civil servants who cooperated initially with the Sue Gray internal report have been issued with many of the fines, possibly partially as a result of their confessions. They are reportedly furious!
Durham police are, meanwhile, investigatingone event that Keir Starmer was at. If they find Starmer guilty of an offence (for which he’s promised to resign), that would seem grossly unfair, as there was clearly no culture of negligence in his case, at most a marginal misinterpretation of the rules. I trust that their investigation is to demonstrate political neutrality, knowing that the Government was under investigation.
Maybe the Sue Gray report will strengthen the case that the Government, and Johnson in particular, were careless, negligent, dismissive, arrogant. I do hope that the public will continue to grow in their distrust of this selfish, arrogant and dishonest man, so that either he’s forced out of office or that he leads his party to a truly dreadful result in the General Election that must come by 2024.
May 9th: A huge shock for the Government, losing 487 council seats, consistently down in the polls, and with Labour more trusted than them on almost every criterion. But bigger still, they are threatened in their heartlands, particularly the South and South-West, by the Liberal Democrat surge, gaining 222 seats and 3 councils (returning to the same number of controlled councils as c. 2010). After Chesham & Amersham and North Shropshire, there are two tasty by-elections coming up too. The Government is finally looking very vulnerable.
May 4th: Many Conservative councillors are distancing themselves from their own party in government, with slogans such as ‘Local Conservatives’ and, even further, ‘Don’t punish local Conservatives for the mistakes made in Westminster’. The North Tyneside group have published pseudo-Green leaflets aiming to get some Labour voters to switch and save a few marginal Tory councillors. A tiny imprint has ‘NTCF’ (Conservative Federation), but for most people they look like Green Party leaflets, which they’re not! After all, it was local Conservative members who voted in Johnson as leader and hence Prime Minister, when his character and history were well-known.
This distancing is not new. During the Coalition years (whatever you think of that period), many local Lib Dem councillors lost their seats owing to general unhappiness with the national policies and compromises, and some campaigned with the designation ‘Focus Team’ and no mention of ‘Liberal Democrat’. I doubt this is effective and might even be counter-productive.
By Friday morning, we’ll see if there is indeed a substantial national swing in seat numbers, but it will be measured against 2018, when Theresa May’s government was already unpopular. Locally, the Lib Dems have a strong challenge in Weetslade ward, and the Greens in Whitley Bay. We share some aims (environment, and the need for scrutiny and challenge to this Labour ‘one-party state’), but remain distinct parties, especially at national level, where the Greens try to defend their ‘leave NATO’ policy – not at all sensible at this time!
April 19th: Desperate to displace headlines about lawbreaking at Number 10, and to shore up their ’base’, this dreadful Government have proposed an appalling plan for refugees – condemned by almost everyone who’s thought about the issue at all. The Civil Service are constrained, but have said it’s unclear whether it will be effective and hence value for money. It’s dishonest in that the UK takes a relatively small number of refugees, most of those crossing the Channel are genuine, and alternative safe and legal routes have been closed. It’s ineffective, as a deterrent works only if it’s known. It’s illegal, as it fails to deal properly with refugees. And it’s unethical and cruel. Perhaps most bizarre of all, Rees-Mogg asserts that it’s ’redemptive’. My view is much as Pope Francis’.
April 11th: Rishi Sunak impressed the public with his charm, confidence and ‘generosity’ with public spending. Many (including him!) thought he might be the next Prime Minister, but I always wondered – we knew nothing of any vision for the UK, ability in managing the executive decision-making or skill in building and managing a team. We did know that he’d been a hedge-fund manager, good at making money from insubstantial investments and manipulation of markets. In the past few weeks, his fall from grace has been spectacular – a budget that failed to address the cost-of-living crisis, apparent opposition to sensible energy/climate plans, and then his wife’s non-dom status for her fantastic wealth. Then, on top of all that. questions about his US and UK status.
On Thursday I was visiting Richmond in North Yorkshire, his constituency, and was by chance interviewed by an ITV team seeking the views of local residents. They featured my views at some length: https://twitter.com/ITVNewsPolitics/status/1512098733554610187 Some of the comments following the clip are hilarious! I was quite honest with them about who I was but they evidently thought the clip worth keeping. The whole tweet was re-tweeted by Wes Streeting (Shadow Cabinet), so it had lots of views!
April 6th: Today the National Insurance increase is implemented. On top of huge rises in energy costs, and a continuing squeeze on benefits and local authority budgets, times will be hard for many families. Yes, it’s possible to manage on less, and people used to know more about how to do that, but life wasn’t very good for many in those ‘nostalgic times’, and in any case, why should ordinary families be told to put up with things by people who don’t have to? When coupled with a casual and hypocritical attitude to the pandemic rules by Downing street, it’s clear that this Government is seriously out of touch. Many people remain to be convinced that Labour is ready for government, but increasingly they (and the Liberal Democrats) are seen as a serious party who cares.
The Government is also out of touch on other issues. Most people oppose the selling off of Channel 4 – pointless except as a piece of dogma. Most people are supportive of more on-shore wind turbines and against fracking, yet the Government is against one and favours the other. People support more Ukrainian refugees, but the Home Office makes that very difficult. They appear to be completely wrapped up in their own rhetoric. It’s to be hoped that they lose power sooner rather than later!
The immediate prospect of a challenge to the Government will come on May 5th in the local elections. Although primarily about local issues, and distorted to some extent by dissatisfaction that results from national funding but which impinges on other parties, it seems likely that many usual Conservative voters will stay at home, whilst opposition voters will turn out with greater enthusiasm. In North Tyneside, there are prospects of more opposition councillors from the Lib Dems and the Greens, who both had impressive gains in target wards. Although the overall political ‘colour’ of the two is very different, we share the aims of addressing the climate change, holding the local council to account, and scrutinising plans and decisions to set better priorities and ensure value for money.
March 14th: I’ve just watched short videos of arrests in Russian cities – one of a protestor with a card saying, literally, ‘two words’, and the other with a card that was completely blank. The Russian government is afraid of criticism. Much of its attitude is even more rooted in the past than Britain’s current nostalgia of ‘Dad’s Army’ and ‘Britannia rules the waves’.
But it’s also true that our governments have failed to tell the truth, in the sense of both words and actions. The belief that economic engagement would convert Russia, China and other autocracies to our liberal democracy was naive. Of course engagement, and particularly educating foreign students, is part of what’s needed, but sterner stuff must also be shown when such trust is clearly abused, as in Salisbury, Crimea, Syria, and substantial dependence on Russian energy supplies was a real risk, especially coupled with inadequate storage.
At the same time, our governments have failed to be honest with us about the need to pay our way – in taxes sufficient to provide the services we value, and in balancing our trade so that foreign investment can be selective rather than uncritical. The ‘golden visa’ scheme was always a terrible idea (actually introduced under Gordon Brown!), but should at least have had safeguards, notably a restriction on political donations for an initial period.
It’s commonplace to say ‘they’re all liars’ about our politicians, whilst expecting unrealistic things to be done, and voting for the best promises rather than the honest but more mundane ‘we’ll do what we can’. Vision is great, exaggerated promises are not.
February 8th: I decided some years ago that I hate dogma. That’s not a particular dogma, just all of it! There might be a very few exceptions, but these would be a few ‘truths’ for me, such as statements about the importance of truth itself, honesty, the value of human beings, the need to look after the world for the sake of our children and grandchildren, etc.
Dogma means (to me) an explicit statement of a belief that the holder is unwilling to question. I have no objection to strong beliefs, strongly argued, it’s the closed-mindedness that’s the problem, the ‘black-and-white’ view of the subject or the world. Just now, it’s party politics that’s at the forefront of my mind, but I will mention one other area.
Boris Johnson shouldn’t be Prime Minister. Increasingly, that’s a view held by many Conservative voters and MPs, as well as almost all others. It’s commonly said that by continuing to support him in post, those people are ‘putting party before country’, or ‘putting their own careers before principles’. I don’t think it’s so simple, though I’m not excusing it. It’s clear to me that for many of these MPs (and voters), there is a strong conviction that a Conservative government is best for the country, certainly in the longer-term and probably in the medium-term too. That is, even with doubts and problems at present, they continue to think that a Labour government will be worse for the country overall than almost any conceivable government by ‘their’ party. In this sense, they might believe they are putting country before anything else. Of course, an element of personal career is relevant, but the argument extends easily to: ‘I’ll be a better MP for my constituency than my opponent, because of my core values.’
Whilst I understand this mentality up to a point, it’s dangerous, as it can lead incrementally to acceptance, even advocacy, of bad policy, bad behaviour, bad management, etc. Surely most Conservative MPs would not have supported Johnson so willingly in 2019 if they’d known in advance how he might behave, how little he valued them, their opinions, their values.
A dogmatic position that says, in effect: any Conservative government, however bad, is always better than any Labour government, however good, is not a rational position, it’s a black-and-white dogma and should be called out and given no power. Of course, the same would be true for the converse.
Here’s my other example: When I was young, homosexuality was unknown, then weird, then a joke, then strange, then gradually more a fact of life. However, until I was about 25-30, I wasn’t wholly comfortable with this, whilst trying hard to be accepting. What finally brought me ‘off the fence’ was this: To hold the traditional view (of heterosexual lifelong marriage) was, in effect, to judge that any traditional marriage relationship, however bad, was automatically better than any other form of relationship, however good. That is, a dogmatic traditional position was clearly wrong and untenable for me. Thereafter, I accepted the validity and value of all good, committed, respectful relationships, hetero- or homo-sexual, whilst still rejecting any relationship that didn’t meet those values, or didn’t try hard to. I could add other rejected dogmas to these two, but that’s enough for today!
January 23rd: Boris Johnson is on the ropes, by all accounts and appearances. Parties (in no.10, in the garden, in his flat), threats to MPs, Islamophobia, on top of general dishonesty and incompetence, factional strife in his Party, and a growing cost-of-living crisis contribute to, at last, public opinion that he should resign or be sacked, with someone competent and honest in his place. Will it happen? Yes! Will it happen this week? Unclear.
Who would replace him? Sunak is front-runner, but we have no idea of his vision or competence, just his manner, and he has apparently little sympathy for the poor or the environment. If he takes over, then I hope the many problems are not shrugged off by him as ‘not his fault’, as any incoming PM must be seen to do something to alleviate them. I hope too that he doesn’t take over soon enough to get the benefit of the doubt in the May elections, but late enough for his competence to be as yet unclear.
PM is a job I’ll never have and couldn’t do, as my skin isn’t thick enough even if I had the ability! However, I sometimes think of what my first priorities might be in that position. Top of the list would be to reduce hostility and polarisation in Parliament, in the UK, with our European neighbours and beyond, for without that little effective governance is possible. I’d stop the hostility to asylum-seekers, but maybe process some in France if possible, with a clearer legal route otherwise to minimise the ‘boats’ problem.
I’d maintain masks in most indoor places to slow the pandemic, and slow the NHS vaccination deadline just a little to get more acceptance. I’d have a windfall tax on energy companies to offset the recent price rises and/or other costs on the poor.
For NI, I’d agree an SPS deal to ease the customs and border issues, and with the EU fix collaborations on Euratom, Horizon, and the musicians visa scheme. I’d revisit the Australia trade deal if possible to reinstate welfare and environmental standards.
There’s lots more! Much of the above doesn’t bring massive costs, but increases cooperation and trust, and partially tackles several crises. Good governance is more about the mundane than the dramatic, but honesty, trust and steady, small steps are usually the best way forward.

March 2nd: Our inept Prime Minister, shackled to an almost hysterical right-wing, and facing electoral oblivion, makes a public speech about extremism and ‘mob rule’. I’ve said before that the thing I have most hated about the Governments we’ve had since 2016 (i.e. Johnson, May, Truss, Sunak) is that they have created, encouraged, even stoked, division between people, between communities, between countries.
Surely one of the most important functions of leadership – true for managing a department or even being a parent, as well as in politics – is to reduce suspicion and hostility, to build trust, to try to bring people together in a common vision? Obviously simplistic nationalism isn’t what I mean (such as Modi’s BJP in India), but a common vision that everybody, if possible, can see the point of and feel that they or their children and friends might find good in wellbeing if not in material wealth.
February 12th 2024: The general mood right now for most people seems to be ‘Anything but this!’ For many, that means voting for the candidate most likely to unseat a Conservative, even if that individual has behaved (mostly) honourably. For many others, it means ‘I’m not voting for them, nor for any of the others!’. This is not a healthy situation.
Keir Starmer is evidently a cautious person. He’s very conscious of what happened in 1992, when Labour had a fair lead in the polls, yet John Major and the Conservatives won. The margin in the polls is far larger now, but he clearly doesn’t want to take things for granted, and also doesn’t want to promise what he can’t deliver, in case he leads a one-term government.
However, it would be good to have more of a sense of vision and hope, instead of dull competence, even though that’s what’s more important in getting our society back on track as a functioning and civil country. He no doubts wants to be radical on the climate too, but has managed to give a very confused message on that. If the markets can accept Labour’s initial plans and track record, I really hope he’ll revive that necessary huge investment before long.
But I can’t pretend that a majority Labour government is my preferred option. I’d like the Lib Dems to get 30-50 seats, return to being the third largest party (2nd largest is too much to hope, I think), and have a real share in decision-making. Let’s see.
August 4th: Why does our Government continue to do things that seem irrational and counter-productive? Why not join the Horizon programme? Why license new oil and gas fields? Why announce that shoplifters will go to jail? Why don’t they seem to care about sewage in our rivers, and doctors and teachers leaving their professions in huge numbers, or whether we are taken seriously by our international partners? Are they stupid? Are their advisers all stupid too? Are their civil-servants not pointing out the ineffectiveness (at best) of these disjointed, erratic and naive policties?
Is it just that it makes more profit for their rich mates? I think not. No doubt they are so used to spending time with other privileged people that their judgement is affected. We’re all more inclined to trust those like us, our friends and those of a type we know. We flatter ourselves that we understand them and they us, that they are more likely to deliver what we intend than anonymous corporations. This surely underlies to a large extent the system of patronage over the years in promotions etc. Not all purely selfish, but also unconscious bias.
But there is another, quite different, rationale. In 2019, Johnson perceived that UKIP might contest many existing Conservative seats, and others he hoped to win, not by winning them, but by splitting the conservative vote. He tacked to the right, and UKIP stood down in all seats held by Conservatives that supported Brexit.
For the 2024 General Election, the Conservatives must surely know that they’re likely to lose, and by a substantial margin. They could easily drop to 200 seats (as Labour has now). But if Reform (ex-UKIP) contests many seats, that 200 could instead be 50-100 – a near wipe-out for the party. That’s what terrifies the Conservative Party. If they try to appear more moderate, they might regain some votes from the centre-ground, but they might lose far more seats through that split vote.
I think our inept, unimaginative and corrupt government has realised it’s going to lose badly next year, and its strategy is to avoid a wipe-out. I really find it hard to believe there’s any other rationale for continuing to adopt such stupid policies.
June 19th: A day to remember – the House of Commons debating the Privileges Committee report into Boris Johnson’s deliberate misleading of the House, and his subsequent rubbishing of the process and the individuals bravely producing the report. A bad day – that it was necessary, and that many Conservative MPs stayed away (very few opposed the report). A good day – that the HoC could be honest about the shenanigans of Johnson’s regime and his personal unsuitability to be Prime Minister.
And, this week, a ‘stolen’ video displaying the carelessness and contempt for the public and for shared mores as Shaun Bailey’s Mayoral team at CCHQ partied on the same day we were instructed to return to social restrictions.
Honesty in politicians means avoiding deliberate untruths or grossly misleading statements, as a minimum, but also means not promising things that there is no realistic chance of delivering. One shortlisted candidate for the expanded North-East Mayor says they’ll ‘eliminate child poverty’ – a laudable but impossible aim. They should really say ‘reducing child poverty is my principal aim’ and perhaps ‘we should be able to eliminate child poverty, and I’ll do my best to reduce it substantially in my five year term’.
It’s generally understood that Cameron promised a referendum that he thought he’d be forced to drop in a hung parliament, that Clegg promised no student fee increase as he didn’t expect to be in power, and that Johnson urged a Brexit that he didn’t believe in. Only the last was a complete falsehood, but the others were rash at least, and came back to haunt us all.
May 2nd: I get on fine with reasonable members of major parties, Labour, Conservative, Green (I don’t meet many SNP members, but probably them too). I do not get on with those who hold dogmatic positions, defying logic, ignoring facts, being insulting to others.
People should vote quite separately for local and parliamentary elections, as the issues are often different and the individuals too. A local council might be doing well despite being the same party as a bad government, or vice versa. Of course there’s going to be some overlap – local parties and national parties are likely to have related priorities and assumptions about the mix of private and public, individual and state, both with respect to responsibilities and to economic mechanisms. But I respect those who vote for an excellent candidate even where that party isn’t their ‘usual’ one.
However, at present this Government is so bad, so dishonest, so incompetent, that I’d rather they got a clear signal this week that it’s time for them to acknowledge defeat and give way to others with energy, ideas and integrity.
February 14th: I’m often accused of being too charitable to those who seem corrupt or crazy. Perhaps I am. But my experience is that people are often less corrupt and/or less crazy than they first appear. Moreover, in the case of politics, those who vote for what seem stupid or malign policies are unlikely to be convinced by our viewing those representatives in the worst possible light. So this is an attempt to ‘defend’ a significant minority of Conservative MPs who continue to vote with the Government even though they seem decent enough as people. This is not any defence of the policies, nor a full justification for their continuing support.
Traditional, one-nation Conservatism, and moderate, democratic Socialism, can have constructive discussions with each other, with a fair amount of consensus on what’s acceptable both to the public and in parliamentary processes. They also agree that change must happen gradually.
They agree on a mixed economy, but disagree about the mix, the balance between public and private finance, and between individual and collective responsibility.
The Cabinet (most of them) must know that Brexit has been hugely damaging, that leaving the ECHR would be insane, that scrapping EU laws without discussion or replacement would be disastrous. The only (sane) reason for these proposals at all is that they know they’re going to lose the next General Election, badly, but think their only hope of avoiding huge losses (resulting in < 100 seats?) is to keep sufficient core voters who might support Reform. Any attempt to appeal to swing Con/Lab or Con/LD voters could cost far more than it would gain.
Meanwhile, the ‘sensible’ Conservative MPs want their party to regain its pragmatism and caution. They know they’ll lose many seats at the next General Election, but hope that they can retain enough to form a substantial Opposition, and then re-form a parliamentary group capable of governing. But if they rebel now, they might fail to prevent whatever policy it is, create even more of an impression of incompetence, and feed the populist appetite leaking votes to Reform. They might also be de-selected (as in 2019). Thus they continue to conform, hoping to keep their own seats and a future, sensible Party.
Some Ministers might feel similarly, though they’re deeper in the collective insanity of making enemies, damaging trade, reducing Britain’s influence, weakening our universities, etc. But maybe a few (like one or two of Trump’s lieutenants?) think that the UK would be even worse off without their moderating voice in Cabinet.
Of course, I might be wrong. Many MPs are just in the habit of voting with their own Government, and fearful of losing their seats, even if they’re not personally corrupt.
November 16th: Common UK views have moved from ‘In God we trust’ through ‘With Truss, “Oh my God!”‘ to a weary fatalism now Rishi Sunak holds the reins – ‘God knows what’s coming next!’.
Back in the Spring, Sunak’s wife’s non-dom status became known, and by chance I was interviewed in his constituency of Richmond as if I were a resident (but I did tell ITV!). The comments after this clip are hilarious! It got extra coverage when re-tweeted by a member of the Shadow Cabinet!
I haven’t changed my views since the early days of ‘Dishy Rishi’, when I said we knew nothing about his vision or skills – now both clearly lacking – although he does seem more decent and a bit more honest than some of his colleagues. HIs judgement though – Braverman and Williamson and Raab. How long can he last?
October 18th: What a summer! My last entry, on 18th July, ended with this: “Whoever is chosen might get a small ‘bounce’, and might genuinely be a bit more honest than Johnson, but it is to be hoped that currently greater trust in Keir Starmer won’t evaporate, and that our new PM won’t adopt really stupid policies, rashly hoping for some populist revival of support.”
Well, our new PM got no ‘bounce’ at all, but maybe at least isn’t an inveterate liar. In fact, she tried to enact roughly what she promised to those few Conservative members, whereas most of us assumed she’d be more moderate in practice once she’d got the job! She did indeed ‘adopt really stupid policies’, but perhaps not primarily to get populist approval but because she’d fallen hook, line and sinker for ‘Minfordnomics’.
Patrick Minford argued that Brexit would benefit the UK, but was quite open about his view that it would lead to decline in UK farming and industry. I think his logic was, if it can be produced more cheaply elsewhere, let that happen, whilst we do what we’re best at. This of course ignores the fact that much of our trade was with Europe, now more difficult and costly. It also ignores the security of home production (very obvious now with increased conflict) and the dignity and pride of things done at home. Moreover, this ‘purely logical’ approach to economics is of the kind that argues full employment can be achieved if the wage levels are appropriate, ignoring the fact that those levels might be below starvation level.
Hunt has his limitations, but is more mature and able than the PMs and chancellors we’ve had for some years. I hope he can save the UK from misery, but I also hope the Conservatives lose lots of seats at a General Election soon and learn from that!
July 18th: Boris Johnson got rid of most of the most talented moderates in his parliamentary party, demanding all candidates in 2019 and all MPs since should show total loyalty to him and the Brexit project. That meant many, less courageous, MPs swallowing their pride and principles to defend the indefensible, such as lies about ‘forty new hospitals’ and ‘Northern Ireland’s economy lagging behind the rest of Britain’, trashing our reputation for integrity and reliability, and adopting populist but ineffective policies such as increased prison sentences and the appalling Rwanda policy.
Finally forced out by his dishonesty and irresponsibility over ‘Partygate’ and the Pincher affair, Johnson leaves behind a sorry state of both UK policy and economy, and of possible successors. The debates on TV, in the press and on Twitter have brought us little honesty, few ideas, and much mud-slinging about the candidates’ own involvement and about each other. The third TV debate has been cancelled as two leading candidates could see these pubic viewings were just making them all look bad. Recall that Johnson refused to participate in all but one TV debate in 2019 and also swerved the hardest interview experienced by the other leaders in the 2019 General Election.
Whoever is chosen might get a small ‘bounce’, and might genuinely be a bit more honest than Johnson, but it is to be hoped that currently greater trust in Keir Starmer won’t evaporate, and that our new PM won’t adopt really stupid policies, rashly hoping for some populist revival of support.
June 21st: Rail strikes today, and the Government tries to blame this on Labour, who haven’t been in power for twelve years! It’s very probable that the unions have been obstructive to new practices in some ways, and certain that the railways must find economies as fewer people commute. Nonetheless, rail companies make large profits at public expense, and it probably suits the Government to milk the situation to get a few more votes in the by-elections this week.
The ‘Boris tried to get his lover a job’ story is very curious. Trying to suppress an almost certainly true story seems pointless, but is probably a panic reaction, calculating that some core Tory voters in Tiverton and Honiton are more likely to be influenced by paper copies of their favourite newspapers than by the commentary. Why would the Times and Mail withdraw the story? What have they been promised? Is Johnson seriously considering a General Election once the by-election results are known, and in that case, has he offered the Times and Mail an exclusive?
I’m an optimist, but the country does seem to be out of control at present. I don’t envy any new government trying to address so many difficulties – inflation, staff shortages, trade, Northern Ireland, the pandemic, Ukraine, but building trust and cooperation must be at the centre of any programme of government right now, and at any time. Labour isn’t to blame for most of the current crop of problems, but they do need some courage in projecting a vision that’s positive for people. That does seem to be lacking, and if the Tories do dump Johnson and find a more decent and competent leader, it might be hard for Starmer to be seen as the better choice.

A good day – that the HoC could be honest about the shenanigans of Johnson’s regime and his personal unsuitability to be Prime Minister.
And, this week, a ‘stolen’ video displaying the carelessness and contempt for the public and for shared mores as Shaun Bailey’s Mayoral team at CCHQ partied on the same day we were instructed to return to social restrictions.
Honesty in politicians means avoiding deliberate untruths or grossly misleading statements, as a minimum, but also means not promising things that there is no realistic chance of delivering. One shortlisted candidate for the expanded North-East Mayor says they’ll ‘eliminate child poverty’ – a laudable but impossible aim. They should really say ‘reducing child poverty is my principal aim’ and perhaps ‘we should be able to eliminate child poverty, and I’ll do my best to reduce it substantially in my five year term’.
It’s generally understood that Cameron promised a referendum that he thought he’d be forced to drop in a hung parliament, that Clegg promised no student fee increase as he didn’t expect to be in power, and that Johnson urged a Brexit that he didn’t believe in. Only the last was a complete falsehood, but the others were rash at least, and came back to haunt us all.
May 2nd: I get on fine with reasonable members of major parties, Labour, Conservative, Green (I don’t meet many SNP members, but probably them too). I do not get on with those who hold dogmatic positions, defying logic, ignoring facts, being insulting to others.
People should vote quite separately for local and parliamentary elections, as the issues are often different and the individuals too. A local council might be doing well despite being the same party as a bad government, or vice versa. Of course there’s going to be some overlap – local parties and national parties are likely to have related priorities and assumptions about the mix of private and public, individual and state, both with respect to responsibilities and to economic mechanisms. But I respect those who vote for an excellent candidate even where that party isn’t their ‘usual’ one.
However, at present this Government is so bad, so dishonest, so incompetent, that I’d rather they got a clear signal this week that it’s time for them to acknowledge defeat and give way to others with energy, ideas and integrity.
February 14th: I’m often accused of being too charitable to those who seem corrupt or crazy. Perhaps I am. But my experience is that people are often less corrupt and/or less crazy than they first appear. Moreover, in the case of politics, those who vote for what seem stupid or malign policies are unlikely to be convinced by our viewing those representatives in the worst possible light. So this is an attempt to ‘defend’ a significant minority of Conservative MPs who continue to vote with the Government even though they seem decent enough as people. This is not any defence of the policies, nor a full justification for their continuing support.
Traditional, one-nation Conservatism, and moderate, democratic Socialism, can have constructive discussions with each other, with a fair amount of consensus on what’s acceptable both to the public and in parliamentary processes. They also agree that change must happen gradually.
They agree on a mixed economy, but disagree about the mix, the balance between public and private finance, and between individual and collective responsibility.
The Cabinet (most of them) must know that Brexit has been hugely damaging, that leaving the ECHR would be insane, that scrapping EU laws without discussion or replacement would be disastrous. The only (sane) reason for these proposals at all is that they know they’re going to lose the next General Election, badly, but think their only hope of avoiding huge losses (resulting in < 100 seats?) is to keep sufficient core voters who might support Reform. Any attempt to appeal to swing Con/Lab or Con/LD voters could cost far more than it would gain.
Meanwhile, the ‘sensible’ Conservative MPs want their party to regain its pragmatism and caution. They know they’ll lose many seats at the next General Election, but hope that they can retain enough to form a substantial Opposition, and then re-form a parliamentary group capable of governing. But if they rebel now, they might fail to prevent whatever policy it is, create even more of an impression of incompetence, and feed the populist appetite leaking votes to Reform. They might also be de-selected (as in 2019). Thus they continue to conform, hoping to keep their own seats and a future, sensible Party.
Some Ministers might feel similarly, though they’re deeper in the collective insanity of making enemies, damaging trade, reducing Britain’s influence, weakening our universities, etc. But maybe a few (like one or two of Trump’s lieutenants?) think that the UK would be even worse off without their moderating voice in Cabinet.
Of course, I might be wrong. Many MPs are just in the habit of voting with their own Government, and fearful of losing their seats, even if they’re not personally corrupt.
November 16th: Common UK views have moved from ‘In God we trust’ through ‘With Truss, “Oh my God!”‘ to a weary fatalism now Rishi Sunak holds the reins – ‘God knows what’s coming next!’.
Back in the Spring, Sunak’s wife’s non-dom status became known, and by chance I was interviewed in his constituency of Richmond as if I were a resident (but I did tell ITV!). The comments after this clip are hilarious! It got extra coverage when re-tweeted by a member of the Shadow Cabinet!
I haven’t changed my views since the early days of ‘Dishy Rishi’, when I said we knew nothing about his vision or skills – now both clearly lacking – although he does seem more decent and a bit more honest than some of his colleagues. HIs judgement though – Braverman and Williamson and Raab. How long can he last?
October 18th: What a summer! My last entry, on 18th July, ended with this: “Whoever is chosen might get a small ‘bounce’, and might genuinely be a bit more honest than Johnson, but it is to be hoped that currently greater trust in Keir Starmer won’t evaporate, and that our new PM won’t adopt really stupid policies, rashly hoping for some populist revival of support.”
Well, our new PM got no ‘bounce’ at all, but maybe at least isn’t an inveterate liar. In fact, she tried to enact roughly what she promised to those few Conservative members, whereas most of us assumed she’d be more moderate in practice once she’d got the job! She did indeed ‘adopt really stupid policies’, but perhaps not primarily to get populist approval but because she’d fallen hook, line and sinker for ‘Minfordnomics’.
Patrick Minford argued that Brexit would benefit the UK, but was quite open about his view that it would lead to decline in UK farming and industry. I think his logic was, if it can be produced more cheaply elsewhere, let that happen, whilst we do what we’re best at. This of course ignores the fact that much of our trade was with Europe, now more difficult and costly. It also ignores the security of home production (very obvious now with increased conflict) and the dignity and pride of things done at home. Moreover, this ‘purely logical’ approach to economics is of the kind that argues full employment can be achieved if the wage levels are appropriate, ignoring the fact that those levels might be below starvation level.
Hunt has his limitations, but is more mature and able than the PMs and chancellors we’ve had for some years. I hope he can save the UK from misery, but I also hope the Conservatives lose lots of seats at a General Election soon and learn from that!
July 18th: Boris Johnson got rid of most of the most talented moderates in his parliamentary party, demanding all candidates in 2019 and all MPs since should show total loyalty to him and the Brexit project. That meant many, less courageous, MPs swallowing their pride and principles to defend the indefensible, such as lies about ‘forty new hospitals’ and ‘Northern Ireland’s economy lagging behind the rest of Britain’, trashing our reputation for integrity and reliability, and adopting populist but ineffective policies such as increased prison sentences and the appalling Rwanda policy.
Finally forced out by his dishonesty and irresponsibility over ‘Partygate’ and the Pincher affair, Johnson leaves behind a sorry state of both UK policy and economy, and of possible successors. The debates on TV, in the press and on Twitter have brought us little honesty, few ideas, and much mud-slinging about the candidates’ own involvement and about each other. The third TV debate has been cancelled as two leading candidates could see these pubic viewings were just making them all look bad. Recall that Johnson refused to participate in all but one TV debate in 2019 and also swerved the hardest interview experienced by the other leaders in the 2019 General Election.
Whoever is chosen might get a small ‘bounce’, and might genuinely be a bit more honest than Johnson, but it is to be hoped that currently greater trust in Keir Starmer won’t evaporate, and that our new PM won’t adopt really stupid policies, rashly hoping for some populist revival of support.
June 21st: Rail strikes today, and the Government tries to blame this on Labour, who haven’t been in power for twelve years! It’s very probable that the unions have been obstructive to new practices in some ways, and certain that the railways must find economies as fewer people commute. Nonetheless, rail companies make large profits at public expense, and it probably suits the Government to milk the situation to get a few more votes in the by-elections this week.
The ‘Boris tried to get his lover a job’ story is very curious. Trying to suppress an almost certainly true story seems pointless, but is probably a panic reaction, calculating that some core Tory voters in Tiverton and Honiton are more likely to be influenced by paper copies of their favourite newspapers than by the commentary. Why would the Times and Mail withdraw the story? What have they been promised? Is Johnson seriously considering a General Election once the by-election results are known, and in that case, has he offered the Times and Mail an exclusive?
I’m an optimist, but the country does seem to be out of control at present. I don’t envy any new government trying to address so many difficulties – inflation, staff shortages, trade, Northern Ireland, the pandemic, Ukraine, but building trust and cooperation must be at the centre of any programme of government right now, and at any time. Labour isn’t to blame for most of the current crop of problems, but they do need some courage in projecting a vision that’s positive for people. That does seem to be lacking, and if the Tories do dump Johnson and find a more decent and competent leader, it might be hard for Starmer to be seen as the better choice.

April 18th: A busy day yesterday, starting with filming by ITV on Blyth dockside for the evening programmes on Thursday 25th. It felt like one of those adverts, sitting at a table in the open air with cranes, goods and the sea behind. Seven questions about me, my aims and policy, and my local knowledge (and I got the local celebrity right!).
Later that morning, an important session with ‘Becoming Visible’ – working with deaf people on materials, education and advice for employment. They filmed me answering questions and will add sign language later so that the deaf community can get information accessibly. We discussed difficulties of funding, of delayed education, and the need for employers to see disabled people as an underused resource rather than a problem to be solved.
My Sustrans interview (see previous blog item) was then followed by a personal profile by an Evening Chronicle reporter. I declined to say who my second vote would be cast for, and explained that I was offering myself and my experience for a job that needs to be done well – this is not a personal ambition – and that linked to my personal faith.

February 13th: The UK has finally found something it can be ‘world-beating’ at – vaccination! Well, not quite, as Israel are ahead of us, but well ahead of most countries and the EU as a whole. It makes a nice change from all the other ‘world-beating’ claims of our Prime Minister, most of which either were false, or rapidly became false. To what extent is this real achievement a result of Brexit?
We were a major player in developing one of the earliest vaccines (Oxford/Astra-Zeneca), which is also simpler to make and will be cheaper than some others, so poorer countries can benefit. And unlike our wasteful and ineffective (privatised) Test and Trace scheme, this was well-organised within the NHS structure. We also approved vaccines faster, and ordered plenty well in advance. However, my understanding is that within the EU our approval processes could have been done and might even have helped the EU, and other EU countries placed independent orders. I am unclear, though, whether we’ve overdone it somewhat with such huge volumes of orders, presumably in case they didn’t all work well.
I don’t think anyone doubts that the EU is a very process-driven, bureaucratic juggernaut, and I don’t think the pro-Europeans amongst us, and those arguing for Remain, were sufficiently honest about this – better to be saying “It has many faults, but we’re still much better off within it!” In this case, slow approval, and orders waiting for that, has meant a substantial delay in the vaccination programme for France, Germany and others. A slight sense of panic at the Commission evidently led to a proposal to invoke Article 16 and restrict vaccine trade, without sufficient analysis of the actual problem and without political reflection. A bad decision, but quickly admitted and reversed, unlike many of the UK’s decisions about our relationships. I’m disgusted that our Government, having threatened to use A16 to address completely foreseeable issues about trade between NI and GB, now criticises others for the same notion.
I think our Cabinet have painted themselves into a corner over Europe, claiming, perhaps sincerely but very naively, that it would be fairly easy to agree on trade issues as standards and sources wouldn’t suddenly change on Jan 31st, but now wanting not only to preserve their own political fortunes, but also perhaps thinking that admission of failure (and of economy with the truth, at least) would exacerbate public loss of confidence during a crisis. The problem is, the longer anyone persists in disguising or bending the truth, the more difficult it becomes to admit it!

This General Election is happening because of Boris Johnson, and for no other reason. He put a modified Withdrawal Agreement to Parliament, and it agreed to continue with it for more debate (‘it passed Second Reading’). But then Parliament said it wanted more than the three days’ debate that Johnson allowed, and he refused, wasted time, and called this Election, claiming that ‘Parliament has blocked Brexit!’.
This is not true! Theresa May’s deal (better for the UK than Johnson’s, though both are bad) would have passed if the Tory right-wing and the DUP hadn’t blocked it, including Johnson himself. Now Parliament was willing to consider the modified deal, but insisted it should be properly scrutinised. Johnson wouldn’t accept that, either because he knew it wouldn’t stand up to scrutiny, or because he was afraid of amendments (perhaps including a second referendum to see if the public still wanted Brexit at all!).

April 1st: (no joke!) In the past few days, we’ve seen a report on policing of the Sarah Everard vigil that concluded ’everything was done correctly’ and one on racism that stated ‘Britain is not a systemically racist country’. Both were very quick, and both were strongly contested. Whatever was right or wrong in these analyses, I think the authors were, at least, insensitive and rather complacent. A vigil that should probably have been allowed, creating bad feeling that led to physical action, and a failure to recognise what racism feels like, add to an impression of an establishment that resents criticism.
At the least, the first report should have acknowledged that an expression of sensible concern was not equivalent to the defiant and infectious anti-mask protest the same week, and the second should have recognised that the poverty that is the main factor holding back black communities is itself a product of sustained racism, even if there is rather less explicit and overt racism than in many other countries (where far-right parties have a stronger hold).

July 21st: Today, the Russia report of the ISC was published. Whilst it didn’t reveal Russian interference in the Referendum, it did reveal that our Government made no effort to investigate the possibility of significant disruption to our democracy, despite warnings in 2014 and at other times, and despite the US doing just this after their 2016 elections. My view: that Theresa May (then PM) believed strongly that doubt cast on the Referendum result would damage the UK more than the result itself. This appears to include ignoring a proposal from our Intelligence Services to investigate Arron Banks before the referendum (maybe rather like Obama’s reluctance to make known FBI investigations into Trump in 2016, in case it looked like bias against him). I believe that she had an overdeveloped sense of duty, stronger than principle, that led to this neglect, and also to her attempt to deliver on the Tory manifesto promise to reduce immigration – and we’ve all seen how that worked out!
Has corruption been a factor? As I’ve explained, I think probably not initially, but possibly now, as the pattern of the last decade allowing rich foreigners to acquire citizenship for a fee, then to donate to the Conservative party and to make friends with ministers, certainly seems to apply to the current PM and Cabinet. The ISC report does refer to this influence, which should embarrass all decent Conservative MPs (and there are many so, except for their support for Johnson & co.).
What about Government contracts being awarded to friends of ministers without tender, and appointments made of known associates? My view is that this is corrupt, but not in the simplest form of ‘lining ones pockets’. Rather, it’s only too easy to think that people you know are the ones to trust, and that companies they recommend are likely to be reliable, and so on. But when you make friends with people like you, especially rich ones, this process becomes unaccountable and self-beneficial, and so corrupt, whilst the perpetrators can display injured innocence. Much the same applies to the need for democracy rather than choosing your supporters, something that Corbyn and his inner circle also were guilty of, claiming to represent members views over MPs until the members disagreed.
This is why we have proper processes – to avoid the temptation to work this way, and to be seen to work properly. Our current Government is not only corrupt and incompetent, but has also done much to destroy trust in government and sow division. It will take a long time to rebuild, but the esteem in which Keir Starmer is increasingly held shows that the public want a leader they can trust.

November 22nd: Many Lib Dem members are furious that Ed Davey, and the party, are saying little about Europe, and clearly not committing to rejoining at the earliest possible date. They say things like: ‘There’s no-one arguing for EU membership, even though a clear majority now believe that leaving was a mistake, and have a favourable view of the EU!’ Starmer seems to be taking a similar line to Davey, though it’s well-known that he wanted to Remain. So why are they silent on this?
Last year, although most Labour supporters, and nearly all Lib Dem supporters, wanted to Remain, once Johnson got his majority, there was no stopping him (and it’s worth remembering that the General Election was called because the PM controlled HoC business and had withdrawn the Withdrawal Agreement, making ‘no-deal’ the default), so in 2020 the debate changed. I think both Davey and Starmer calculated that Johnson could be relied on to mess things up, and their job was to help that along, with the expectation that he’d look more and more ridiculous and dishonest. Avoiding giving him ammunition was Starmer’s idea, I think – let him stew in his own juice!
As well as avoiding the ‘it’s all the fault of Remoaners!’ tag, another key aim was to get the press turning against the Government – something that’s now happening. That works provided the Opposition doesn’t offer too many easy attack lines.
Finally, we all hope that Johnson (who isn’t actually insane, completely stupid, and is probably well-advised usually) will agree some kind of deal with the EU at the last moment. As this will be a massive U-turn, and he’ll try to present that to his own party as a victory, the worst thing to do right now is to make that harder for him, almost to force him to stick to his own bad script. And what strengthens my conviction is that he is doing things to appease his right-wing (defence increases, public-sector pay freeze) that will make his U-turn less offensive to them. Much as we might despise the man, for dishonesty, selfishness, laziness, etc, surely we want him to concede what’s needed to the EU to avoid food shortages, closure of industry, the death of farming, and a general huge hit to the economy.
He’s painted himself into a corner. We might be gleeful about that, but it’s much more important just now to allow him to jump out of it. There’ll still be the pandemic, and a major shock to the economy, and I think both Davey and Starmer will pivot quite rapidly to being more ‘I told you so’ and pro-EU once the public can see the horrible mess Johnson and his shower have got us into.

December 18th: The EU negotiators have said that Sunday 20th is the latest date on which a deal could be agreed and still get approval by the EU Parliament. Our PM says that an EU concession on fisheries is essential to close a deal. Does he really mean this? Everyone knows, if they’ve thought about it much, that fishing is a tiny issue on the UK economy, but also that we do not catch ‘our’ fish nor eat ‘our’ fish, but swap lots of it with other countries, allow, or even encourage, their vessels to catch in our waters whilst we catch in theirs, and we are the only EU country to have allowed much of our permitted quota to be sold abroad. If Johnson had simply bought back some of our quota, he could have claimed a ‘victory’ by increasing our own industry turnover!
The real problem is that Johnson has painted himself into a corner, making fishing a massive, symbolic issue for the whole Brexit debate, and thus making it much harder for himself to climb down on this. Moreover, whereas Johnson is known for agreeing with the last person he has talked to, and thus would be a poor and over-compliant negotiator on his own, Cummings (and of course the ERG) have stiffened his resolve, not only wanting absolute control (including less devolution and localism) but also convinced that the weak Europeans would blink first.
The EU hasn’t blinked, though it has agreed to a softening on the issue of divergence, but after Johnson conceded the principle of costs (tariffs) if divergence did take place and was agreed. Johnson has blinked, and must blink again. Let’s hope, though, that Barnier can find some imaginative wording to help Johnson ‘sell’ his final U-turn as a victory for toughness and sovereignty.

June 18th: A fantastic result last night for the Liberal Democrats – winning the Chesham & Amersham by-election on a 25% swing from the Conservatives! Ed Davey swung a symbolic (small) orange hammer into a ‘blue wall’, and claimed that many Conservative votes in the South were now vulnerable to Lib Dem gains. Labour got about 1.5% of the vote – dismal! But is this really a great victory and/or a seismic shift?
The total Lib Dem + Labour + Green vote count was actually lower than in 2019, with an overall turnout of 52% instead of 77% – the big story is probably that many Conservative voters stayed at home, whilst most of the former Labour voters chose Liberal Democrat. Tactical voting sometimes produces such results, particularly at by-elections, and occasionally in General Elections, notably in 1997. It’s unlikely that the Lib Dems will get such a large share at a GE, though they might well hold the seat. Sensible Labour strategists will realise this was a tactical vote – such Labour campaigning as there was showed ‘no concession to the Lib Dems’ for the benefit of their Left wing, and they’ll hope for a similarly low level of activity by LD in Batley & Spen. Even some Conservatives are likely to welcome the result, as Johnson is disliked and despised by many Conservative MPs and voters but they have been nervous of making that public.
Calls for electoral pacts miss the point that voters won’t automatically shift parties as ‘intended’. In Labour targets, a LD candidate can take votes that might otherwise go to the Conservative. In Lib Dem targets, a Labour candidate can show that the Lib Dems haven’t become ‘too left wing’. But a non-aggression pact (low levels of campaigning) could be very helpful.

May 21st: The UK is confronted by Covid-19, Brexit and an Environmental catastrophe, whilst a dogmatic and incompetent Government rules. Easy to rant, or despair, or retreat into more manageable issues. I believe those are all wrong paths. Best to ‘think globally, act locally’ as it’s often said, but also to do little things that could be that ‘butterfly’ effect. One extra letter to an MP, one person spoken to, even one smile to a stranger, might just tip that person into a different choice or reaction. It’s necessary to have faith that many others might be doing similarly, and that people of influence can themselves be influenced.
Meanwhile, do the things under one’s direct control, and enjoy beauty, simple pleasures, friendship. This photo was a fortuitous snap on the edge of North Tyneside this week. Really beautiful.

November 4th: Tomorrow the rest of the US votes (after early voters). By Thursday we should have a clear impression of the US results, but if they’re close, then maybe nothing definite until the weekend, and then possibly lots of challenges. I’m reading some good news about turnout amongst the young, women and also older men, disgusted and alarmed about Trump the person and Trump and associates’ policies.
I hate Trump, but I really despise those who know him well yet continue to endorse him – McConnell possibly the worst, but Rubio and Cruz, and now Haley too. And in the UK, Johnson and others. Do they continue to think they can manipulate him – it’s hard to believe they actually think he’s better than Harris as a US President.
I sometimes have to calm myself down, considering, for example, what it must have felt like for a decent German citizen in the 1930s. The inadequate response, to date, to the climate crisis has a similar effect on me. Sometimes my only recourse is to think: no matter how bad things get – politically, socially, environmentally – our moral duty is to make them less bad as best we can. Like the story of the boy with the starfish, that might mean just doing some small, local things, but it’s always worth it, even if we can’t see how our small contribution can make a difference.

July 7th: Has Boris Johnson gone too far this time? He seems to have followed a deliberate strategy (like Trump, and influenced by Lynton Crosby) of saying plausible things openly, and anticipating that his personality, a largely uncritical press (until recently!), and his status as Prime Minister will get his messages across, whilst rebuttals won’t get the same coverage. In any case, it’s been shown that, once someone ‘knows’ something, attempts to refute it often strengthen the conviction that it was right. Difficult, therefore, to change people’s minds, and argument doesn’t generally do it.
However, this week he’s stated, publically, that care homes didn’t follow procedures, and implied, at least, that the 20,000+ care-home deaths were a consequence. Since they mostly followed Gov’t advice, took in probably infected people, made use of underpaid staff who were not advised against multiple sites, and lacked necessary PPE, they are not to blame. Already he’s had to ‘clarify’ what he meant, but I anticipate that this one will run and run, and most of the press will be very unsympathetic.
His timing seems poor too. I think the rumour of 20,000 fewer troops is a ‘dead cat’ distraction, designed to take our attention off the Covid-19 crisis, the economy, and Brexit, but criticising care homes brings back dismay at the Government. On Brexit, there is talk of a collaboration with the EU over vaccine development, whilst our Galileo (GPS) substitute looks like a debacle. Maybe more Brexit U-turns are likely. Even a Leave-EU posting is worried about no-deal (though they’re trying to blame this on the delay they say was caused by Remainers, not the ERG). With more frequent criticism of the Gov’t, and Johnson in particular, in the Mail, the Telegraph and elsewhere, how long can he last?

22nd March: This morning I talked to Year 12 students at Duke’s Secondary School in Ashington. I explained some of the background and aims of the new North of Tyne Authority, and why I was standing for Mayor. Also why the South of Tyne authorities had been doubtful, linked to why powers here will be limited for now.
The students asked some good questions – about Environment, Transport, Brexit, Education, Representation, and why they should trust what I said! On trust, I said I’d always be honest if I didn’t know an answer, if the problem would take a long time to solve or was outside my powers, and I’m always willing to credit other individuals and parties for good policies and actions. I also said that representation, whether a school council, a Citizens’ Assembly (which I favour for setting local and regional priorities) or any other level, had to give real influence, not just cosmetic.

Wednesday 11th: A survey out this week found that 88% of major adverts by the Conservatives were factually misleading, but 0% (that’s zero!) of Labour’s. The Lib Dems were criticised for misleading bar-charts (though most had accurate captions). We’re used to exaggeration and claims of success, but facts are usually reliable, and what people are describing as ‘BBC bias’ is really their being too trusting of statements by Government ministers. The picture shows the inconsistency and hypocrisy of the leaders of Leave.
What weird times, when falsity abounds, mostly from the Government, and leading members of both major parties advocate voting for others.
Doing the usual campaigning slog, we’ve delivered thousands of leaflets (more today too), suffering severe bruising when falling on ice last week but determined to tell the public that honest, passionate moderation is always best!

June 23rd: Four years since the Brexit vote, when a narrow majority chose to defy conventional wisdom, but probably swayed by promises of easy trade deals, no action without a plan, and illegal activity by campaigners, possibly with foreign money. Now looms either massive compromises or massive costs, with huge social division, and loss of trust and influence abroad. Aaarrghh!
Today our lazy, narcissistic and incompetent Prime Minister announces a relaxing of the 2m-rule to ‘1m-plus’, meaning with added precautions such as cleaning and masks, whilst lying, as he does, about other countries’ schemes etc. Yet still he, and most others, spend most of their time talking about distance, and very little talking about time spent that close. So far as I can see, when outdoors, a brief encounter has minimal risk, and some say that all the wiping of surfaces is also probably not the key. The huge risks come from sustained sharing of airspace when indoors. Hence pubs, clubs, cinemas, theatres, restaurants, etc. are a problem.
So is public transport, yet even here maybe vigorous ventilation could reduce the risk substantially, yet I hear very little about this. On buses and metros, it’s still possible to open the windows, and the air changes very quickly, which might be very helpful. Who is researching this?
We were also told that the ‘test and trace’ app was vital, that it would be world-beating, and ready by June 1st. In fact, it’s failed, late and, apparently, not that important, and the PM says ‘no other country has a working system’ – palpably untrue! What is true is that we can’t depend solely on technology!

In fact, I’m against direct election of any senior position, as voting by party or by quality of public speaking neglects the qualities often needed to do the actual job. And as well as that interesting result to come, what’s going to happen in the Conservative Party? Will it fracture? Will it unite but further Right?

August 11th: A Government which I now find I trust on almost nothing (for the first time in my life) appears to wish to distract from its serial failures on the pandemic and a public lack of confidence in our narcissistic Prime Minister by trumpeting that we have a ‘refugee crisis’, unfortunately echoed by TV and press. Yes, we have a worry, but a crisis? Surely not? With the UK receiving far fewer asylum applications than many European countries, and when we have obligations to rescue those at sea and to consider refugees carefully, this is no crisis. Worse still, the Government talks of changing the law so that we don’t have to deal with it. Government ignorance, of international law and even of our sea boundaries, compounds this unpleasant tactic.
For many years, it’s suited the Conservative party to demonise Europe, to appease those overly concerned by migration, and to denigrate the role of government. When that is compounded by a Prime Minister and his hand-picked and inadequate Cabinet who seem to think constant misrepresentation and outright lying are acceptable if they keep the polling figures up, it’s no surprise that the public are not always trusting of the official line on safety in schools, for example.
Today that’s perhaps also a factor in a complete caving in by the Scottish Government on the school results. Their first policy was probably unjust, but simply accepting teacher estimates that projected average rises in results of 10-20% can’t be right. It could mean universities having to teach more students who struggle, and finding it impossible to fail too many as they will be perceived as being disadvantaged. And it will make it very hard to return to lower grades next year if ordinary exams are mounted. What a mess!

June 17th: We used to talk of the ‘Three Rs’ in school – Reading, Writing and Arithmetic, still important, but only some aspects of learning, intelligence and life experience. But in respect of the Environment, the ‘three Rs’ are sometimes used to mean something different. I prefer to make that ‘four Rs’ as above. Specifically, recycling is not nearly sufficient to address our waste of resources, the pollution of plastics and other materials in the sea and, too often, in poorer countries, and in reducing the impact on climate.
In the current febrile political climate, ‘Reform’ is getting a lot of attention – far more than it deserves. Like the Kardashians, Nigel Farage and his ‘party’ got too much attention, and are now in a position where they can claim they deserve it, despite some real drawbacks and dangers. Firstly, Reform isn’t a ‘party’ in the normal sense. People are members only in that they’ve paid up; they don’t get any say in policy or leadership. Secondly, it has a very limited list of policies, most of which don’t make much sense, with no detail, no costings, and implying some really unpleasant attitudes. They get some public support mostly as a protest against the much-exaggerated issue of migration (most of which is beneficial, and very little of which is a result of refugees in small boats) and the run-down state of many areas and many public services. But their proposals to cut tax and services would make all that much worse! Let’s hope they get few seats or none at all.
A while back I was asked my intentions for elections in 2025. My answer was: “Let’s get through the General Election first, then let’s see what happens to the Conservative Party!”

April 20th: Our Prime Minister stirs like the Kraken. Is it to fly into Belfast and try to reduce tension and find a way forward (out of the mess he created, of course)? No! Is it to deal with the inconsistency the police have reported between Government laws and Government guidelines on Covid? No! Is it to quarantine every arrival from India, rather than wait until the (as always, announced) deadline on Friday? No! Or about the growing miasma of sleaze, corruption and cronyism around government contracts with unqualified companies they happen to play golf with? Certainly not!
It’s about football, something he admits (in a rare bout of honesty) that he doesn’t support or even watch. This sport, which Bill Shankly famously described as ‘not a matter of life and death, it’s more important than that’, dominates the news. Leading politicians denounce ‘greed’ (unlike that of Cabinet ministers and their mates, of course). Of course it’s important to discuss something that is so popular, but is it really the Government’s business, if at all, and particularly when there’s so much else that they should be sorting out?
I’m pleased to hear of the imminent commitment by the UK Government (and the US Government too) to stringent targets for greenhouse gas reductions, and heartened to read of specific initiatives in the UK and elsewhere, but targets aren’t good enough, and announcing an announcement, plus the football kerfuffle, does look like an attempt to distract from the ‘cronyism’ and NI border rows.

Leading politicians denounce ‘greed’ (unlike that of Cabinet ministers and their mates, of course). Of course it’s important to discuss something that is so popular, but is it really the Government’s business, if at all, and particularly when there’s so much else that they should be sorting out?
I’m pleased to hear of the imminent commitment by the UK Government (and the US Government too) to stringent targets for greenhouse gas reductions, and heartened to read of specific initiatives in the UK and elsewhere, but targets aren’t good enough, and announcing an announcement, plus the football kerfuffle, does look like an attempt to distract from the ‘cronyism’ and NI border rows.

February 14th: I’m often accused of being too charitable to those who seem corrupt or crazy. Perhaps I am. But my experience is that people are often less corrupt and/or less crazy than they first appear. Moreover, in the case of politics, those who vote for what seem stupid or malign policies are unlikely to be convinced by our viewing those representatives in the worst possible light. So this is an attempt to ‘defend’ a significant minority of Conservative MPs who continue to vote with the Government even though they seem decent enough as people. This is not any defence of the policies, nor a full justification for their continuing support.
Traditional, one-nation Conservatism, and moderate, democratic Socialism, can have constructive discussions with each other, with a fair amount of consensus on what’s acceptable both to the public and in parliamentary processes. They also agree that change must happen gradually.
They agree on a mixed economy, but disagree about the mix, the balance between public and private finance, and between individual and collective responsibility.
The Cabinet (most of them) must know that Brexit has been hugely damaging, that leaving the ECHR would be insane, that scrapping EU laws without discussion or replacement would be disastrous. The only (sane) reason for these proposals at all is that they know they’re going to lose the next General Election, badly, but think their only hope of avoiding huge losses (resulting in < 100 seats?) is to keep sufficient core voters who might support Reform. Any attempt to appeal to swing Con/Lab or Con/LD voters could cost far more than it would gain.
Meanwhile, the ‘sensible’ Conservative MPs want their party to regain its pragmatism and caution. They know they’ll lose many seats at the next General Election, but hope that they can retain enough to form a substantial Opposition, and then re-form a parliamentary group capable of governing. But if they rebel now, they might fail to prevent whatever policy it is, create even more of an impression of incompetence, and feed the populist appetite leaking votes to Reform. They might also be de-selected (as in 2019). Thus they continue to conform, hoping to keep their own seats and a future, sensible Party.
Some Ministers might feel similarly, though they’re deeper in the collective insanity of making enemies, damaging trade, reducing Britain’s influence, weakening our universities, etc. But maybe a few (like one or two of Trump’s lieutenants?) think that the UK would be even worse off without their moderating voice in Cabinet.
Of course, I might be wrong. Many MPs are just in the habit of voting with their own Government, and fearful of losing their seats, even if they’re not personally corrupt.
Who knows?

Thursday 12th: Polling day, though many will have already posted their votes. Turnout in marginal seats is reportedly high. By about 10.15pm we’ll have some idea of the overall picture, but the count of seats will depend on those marginals.
In the past week, my personal team of three has delivered about 2,250 leaflets in one of our constituencies. We might not win, but it’s important to let people know what we stand for, to signal to other candidates and parties that not everyone agrees with either, to add to the national vote share, and, I believe, to demonstrate a positive attitude to the best in other parties and people.
On Tuesday evening, I was filmed answering a local-knowledge quiz (three of the five Tynemouth candidates participated). I didn’t do as well as the sitting MP, but he has lived here much longer than I have! Watch it at: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=99DLsJDMRu0

February 12th 2024: The general mood right now for most people seems to be ‘Anything but this!’ For many, that means voting for the candidate most likely to unseat a Conservative, even if that individual has behaved (mostly) honourably. For many others, it means ‘I’m not voting for them, nor for any of the others!’. This is not a healthy situation.
Keir Starmer is evidently a cautious person. He’s very conscious of what happened in 1992, when Labour had a fair lead in the polls, yet John Major and the Conservatives won. The margin in the polls is far larger now, but he clearly doesn’t want to take things for granted, and also doesn’t want to promise what he can’t deliver, in case he leads a one-term government.
However, it would be good to have more of a sense of vision and hope, instead of dull competence, even though that’s what’s more important in getting our society back on track as a functioning and civil country. He no doubts wants to be radical on the climate too, but has managed to give a very confused message on that. If the markets can accept Labour’s initial plans and track record, I really hope he’ll revive that necessary huge investment before long.
But I can’t pretend that a majority Labour government is my preferred option. I’d like the Lib Dems to get 30-50 seats, return to being the third largest party (2nd largest is too much to hope, I think), and have a real share in decision-making. Let’s see.

National and International issues:
Europe and Brexit
Someone challenged me on my views on Brexit, saying that I was ignoring the democratic vote to leave the EU. Firstly, I was strongly opposed to leaving, and any candidate can give their views. Secondly, I think major constitutional decisions should have a stronger mandate than 52% of those voting. Thirdly, it’s clear that most of the promises made by the Leave campaign, including our current Prime Minister, have been broken (massive bureaucratic barriers to trade, a border in the Irish sea, zero exports of shellfish, loss of rights of citizens, reduced security, loss of influence, no easy new trade deals, etc. etc.). A second Referendum on the actual deal should have been part of the offer, and was actually supported by Jacob Ress-Mogg! And last but not least, in the Tynemouth constituency, half of the North Tyneside borough, and the seat I contested in 2019, voted by 52:48 to stay in the EU! The borough overall voted 53% for Leave, but there’s a mix of opinions in every area, and it’s quite close here.
Starting from here, we can’t simply rejoin and I’m not arguing for that, but we need to (a) rebuild trust and reduce tension, (b) try to reduce paperwork and obstacles to trade, (c) seriously consider joining the ‘outer ring’ of Europe – the EEA/EFTA – which would make trade easier but retain some of the freedoms sought.

June 21st: Rail strikes today, and the Government tries to blame this on Labour, who haven’t been in power for twelve years! It’s very probable that the unions have been obstructive to new practices in some ways, and certain that the railways must find economies as fewer people commute. Nonetheless, rail companies make large profits at public expense, and it probably suits the Government to milk the situation to get a few more votes in the by-elections this week.
The ‘Boris tried to get his lover a job’ story is very curious. Trying to suppress an almost certainly true story seems pointless, but is probably a panic reaction, calculating that some core Tory voters in Tiverton and Honiton are more likely to be influenced by paper copies of their favourite newspapers than by the commentary. Why would the Times and Mail withdraw the story? What have they been promised? Is Johnson seriously considering a General Election once the by-election results are known, and in that case, has he offered the Times and Mail an exclusive?
I’m an optimist, but the country does seem to be out of control at present. I don’t envy any new government trying to address so many difficulties – inflation, staff shortages, trade, Northern Ireland, the pandemic, Ukraine, but building trust and cooperation must be at the centre of any programme of government right now, and at any time. Labour isn’t to blame for most of the current crop of problems, but they do need some courage in projecting a vision that’s positive for people. That does seem to be lacking, and if the Tories do dump Johnson and find a more decent and competent leader, it might be hard for Starmer to be seen as the better choice.
