June 8th: Rishi Sunak seems to be planning the worst General Election campaign ever – perhaps the only way in which Britain will be Great during his premiership. Panned by everyone in every party including his own and by Buckingham Palace (reportedly) for his snub of the D-Day event, he looks ever less suitable to be Prime MInister.
I have reservations about Keir Starmer and the Labour Party (I’m a Lib Dem!), but I expect to see a calm, competent and reassuring presence in Number 10 in a few weeks’ time. Business, and others, say that stability and confidence are the first requirement for a new Government, and surely there are some simple things that will improve morale quickly without much cost. For example, reducing or eliminating the restrictions on public protest, making Voter ID much simpler, finally settling some long-running disputes such as the Windrush scandal. Beyond that, an SPS agreement with the EU to smooth imports and reduce costs and bureaucracy, etc.
But I’d also really like some of the Lib Dem priorities – sorting out social care and looking after carers, stopping the sewage scandal, and stronger action on the Environment for a start!

Results:
May 5th: We have a Labour Mayor of the new North-East region (seven local authorities) and a Labour Police & Crime Commissioner (six local authorities). See my Post on the PCC position and general views.
In the North Tyneside local elections, we put up five candidates but with minimal campaigning. Voters had three votes each, as all positions were up for election in the revised wards. Some put all three votes for one party, some ‘split’ their vote, and some used only one or two of their three choices. Our candidates did surprisingly well in view of our low profile, gaining from 322 votes in one ward to 507 in another. Perhaps there’s a more positive feeling around about the Lib Dems. The legacy of the Coalition years is ebbing, we expect more MPs by the end of 2024, and, once in power, Labour will attract much more criticism and might not get the easy ride it’s had in areas like this for the past decade.
Before the Election:
All the attention this year is on the incompetence and dishonesty of the current Conservative government, which is likely to be reflected once again in local election results (though those should really reflect local issues!). And we’re all waiting for that General Election!
In North Tyneside, all 60 councillors are up for election in 20 wards with modified boundaries and names. With our limited resources, we’re putting up candidates in just five wards. Without much campaigning, we don’t expect stellar results, but as electors have three votes, I anticipate that some will choose to ‘split’ their vote, perhaps giving one to the Lib Dem. Although the public are somewhat suspicious of changes to the voting system, they are also known to favour a ‘fairer’ system, and might not really want a massive Labour majority this year!
As well as the Local Elections, there’s an election for the Mayor of the expanded NE region (seven authorities). Our candidate is Dr Aidan King, a GP from Newcastle, who emphasises renewable energy and more. The Labour candidate is Kim McGuinness, currently PCC of Northumbria, and not seen as a strong candidate. Against her is the independent Jamie Driscoll, currently (ex-Labour) Mayor of the smaller ‘North of Tyne’ region. Despite the split in Labour support, we expect McGuinness to win for Labour, but with the Tories being so unpopular, we might even get a third place!
Finally, there’s an election for the post of Police & Crime Commissioner for Northumbria, for which Dr John Appleby is the Lib Dem candidate. There’s usually little public or press interest in the PCC post. The Lib Dem policy is to replace these positions by regional boards, but whilst they exist, we’ll put up good candidates! John’s manifesto isn’t finalised, but will focus on prevention, especially work with young people, victim support, and maximising the time police spend on crime rather than other issues. Another vital area is the experience of women – domestic violence, rape prosecutions and other issues – the subject of a hustings being organised in late April.
Here’s a quick view of John and his priorities, plus my brief manifesto. Also note you can find a list of all candidates and their personal statements at: https://choosemypcc.org.uk/area/northumbria/
John:
- Forty years living in the North-East
- An experienced manager of people and budgets
- A good communicator, never promises what he can’t deliver
- Ex-councillor, trade union officer, school governor
- Chairs a local charity, has lived in deprived areas
- Environmental campaigner
John wants to see:
- Work with Young People both now and for the future
- Listening to victims and the community and with more attention to domestic violence and the poor conviction rate for rape
- Police spending less time on non-crime issues
- Better detection and a timely justice system – the best deterrent
- More and better probation to reduce re-offending
- A local Police Board – better than a PCC
I expect interest in the Lib Dems to grow substantially after a General Election, when we’ll have more MPs and when ousting this dreadful Government is no longer top priority!
Watch this space!
Local Elections 2022 and 2023:
In 2023, the Lib Dems did well again nationally in seats and councils, though we had a limited showing in North Tyneside.
In 2022, across England, Wales and Scotland, the Liberal Democrats won 222 seats and 3 councils – great results, and showing a real prospect of gaining parliamentary seats in forthcoming by-elections and a future General Election.
In North Tyneside, our top target was Weetslade ward, where Daniel Elsom went from zero to hero last year with 829 votes (26%) and a good third place. This year, with lots of hard work from a small team, he gained 1064 votes (35%) and a strong second place, almost halving the gap from Labour, who were taking this area for granted. Maybe next year ….
Notes made before the elections:
In 2022, North Tyneside has ‘usual’ local elections for one councillor in each of its twenty wards. Currently Labour hold 52 out of 60 positions – practically a ‘one-party state’, which is not healthy for scrutiny and challenge. The Labour candidate in my own ward seems to claim credit for everything that the Council has done, and that ‘only a Labour councillor can deliver ……’. If that’s true, it implies that other councillors and non-Labour wards will be disadvantaged – highly improper if not actually corrupt!
In 2020, local elections were cancelled. In 2021, pandemic restrictions led to a reduced requirement for nominations – only two signatures for each nomination instead of the usual ten – but this year we once again need ten names. In North Tyneside our Liberal Democrat group is contesting six wards as we need to concentrate our efforts with a small band of activists.
For our local priorities in Weetslade, where Daniel Elsom is again mounting a real challenge to Labour, see our Facebook pages at https://www.facebook.com/weetsladelibdems and https://www.facebook.com/NorthTyneLDs. For more general views about the borough and the region, see our posts on this site under ‘Previous Elections’.
The Liberal Democrats and the Green Party have some real, differences but share the aims of addressing the Climate Crisis, and of ensuring that this Labour-dominated authority gets the scrutiny it needs. The North Tyneside Green Party issued this statement: “The Green Party is committed to do everything possible to hold our council to account and to strengthen their response to the ongoing climate emergency. Our vision is one of a better, healthier and greener community, and we believe that a council with strong alternative voices will better represent our community and be more able to make that vision a reality. We are not campaigning in Weetslade this year, but will be happy to work with Liberal Democrat councillors, providing effective scrutiny of the Council’s priorities and decision-making, and ensuring vital issues aren’t forgotten.”
For the national Lib Dem priorities, see https://www.libdems.org.uk/plan
Lib Dem candidates for North Tyneside in 2023
For six of the twenty council wards in North Tyneside, the candidates are as follows:
- Benton, Jed Beyer
- Killingworth, Nathan Shone
- Monkseaton North, David Nisbet
- St Mary’s, Janet Appleby
- Wallsend, Harriet Stanway
- Weetslade, Daniel Elsom
Young people care now about the future – environment, education, lasting jobs. Three of our candidates are enthusiastic young candidates: Daniel, Nathan and Jed. They’d bring a breath of fresh air and not be satisfied with ‘staying calm and carrying on’ – we need to do better than that!
In Weetslade ward, campaigner and candidate Daniel Elsom is advocating Community Skips to allow residents to deposit major items for disposal and recycling, as the North Tyneside dump is far away, and current rules do not allow residents to use the much closer Newcastle Brunswick facility (obvious scope for co-operation here!). This would help residents, improve recycling, and reduce unsightly and dangerous fly-tipping. In 2021 he gained 25% of the vote in a ward we’d not contested in many years. One to watch!
Future elections
Local elections are scheduled for May 6th 2023, but as the Coronation has now been fixed for that day, it’s possible that this date will move. We’ll see!
With the Government in complete disarray, it’s quite possible there’ll be a General Election before long. We’ll certainly be fielding candidates in both the Tynemouth constituency and the North Tyneside constituency, but we haven’t yet finalised candidates for these. We have prepared Ward Profiles and Diversity Statements for any applicants wishing to stand in either seat.

April 12th: Easter, a Christian celebration of joy, hope, new life, release from despair, self-centredness, greed and listlessness, but named from a pagan festival of Spring. For us, ‘joining in’ with many thousands on-line to celebrate and look forward, but so different from normal. As new cases and numbers of deaths begin to level out, we hope for a vaccine, that new recognition of who and what is really important will not be lost amidst economic hardship, mental health, suffering in refugee camps. A few weeks more before we have any idea at all …..
Author: johnapplebyld
Our Community
April 3rd: Mounting cases, mounting numbers of deaths, confusion in Government (though with a little welcome honesty yesterday!), but some positives too. Our quiet street is developing a sense of community spirit. A Green/Red flag scheme so people can signal a need is in place, maybe not revealing needs if they are already under control, but showing a keen desire to look after each other. A WhatsApp group to share experiences and wants, whether a birthday, information about mail-order, or a wish for cheese or tofu! A nurse was isolated with her family for a few days, only to find her positive was a false positive and she’s back in the front-line. A seven-year-old’s birthday was marked communally with singing and music, including my own accordion in the street outside and my wife’s violin. We’ve already been booked for the proposed street-party at the end of lock-down.
Will this community spirit continue when it’s all over? Obviously we don’t know, but at least we know more names and faces. Maybe this time will awaken people to what’s really important in life (beauty and friendship, rather than possessions), to the people they depend on who are often badly-paid and insecure, to the risks of unlimited foreign travel. I hope so.
Government logic and its limitations
March 28th: Our UK Gov’t has been much criticised. My interpretation is this. They believed (probably rightly) that nearly everyone would catch the virus before immunity and/or vaccine took effect. Therefore, it was pointless to try to delay the inevitable, including amongst medical staff, as economic harm would be bad and would also cause deaths. Moreover, the vast majority of deaths would be amongst the elderly, and would be those quite likely to die within the year (noting that the normal death rate in the UK is about 50,000 per month – rarely mentioned).
What this also assumes, I think, is that people simply divide into those that die and those that don’t. What it leaves out is four things. Firstly, a significant minority of those who die might be saved with sufficient care, hence staffing and ventilators etc are needed. Secondly, a delay in the peak gives more time to develop treatments. Thirdly, it’s been said that a higher ‘load’ of the virus not only increases the chance of catching it, but also the severity of the illness – this is pertinent to medical staff and why PPE is important. Lastly, good treatment might make death less painful even where it’s inevitable. It’s also possible that, if many can avoid it altogether this year, a vaccine might save them in a second wave.
There’s also been accusations of ideology, callousness, etc. I’m doubtful about those. I imagine both many cock-ups as a complex situation develops, and a genuine philosophical difficulty for those (like Johnson) who believe people do best with less regulation and then must adjust to imposing rules. There’s also a balance to be struck between doing the right thing logically, and being seen to do something. Johnson’s latest approval ratings suggest that he’s succeeded with that, at least!
Locked down
March 28th. Already semi-retired, and with neither young nor old to care for, I’m fairly used to time in the house, but not to an empty diary: no days at work, Metro rides, evening meetings, and fewer walks, though the beach is wide and sparse. Our street now has a chatty What’sApp group and a red/green flag for windows. More bicycles than cars sometimes too! With relatives and acquaintances seriously ill, we know it’s deadly despite our own comfort.
Totally unreal!
March 21st: I’ve read some novels about things like ‘after the nuclear holocaust’, plagues, etc, and Wyndham’s stories such as Day of the Triffids and The Chrysalids, and seen films too, such as ‘Children of Men’ (in which children are no longer born for some unknown reason). They were interesting, intriguing, slightly scary. I grew up and became an adult at a time when nuclear war seemed a possibility (though it’s not gone away entirely). One question that was addressed by all of them was how people might behave when scared, stressed, hungry. They usually told of a mixture of noble, communal, self-sacrificing behaviour, and selfish, wild, panicky behaviour. I think we see aspects of this already in this extraordinary crisis.
I’m an optimist, not always predicting good outcomes, but always believing that good things can happen. Right now, I know there will be many tragedies, many deaths, much unemployment, but still hope that society will prevail, health and well-being restored, the very worst avoided. Might the UK run short of food, even if we’re well-organised in time, if other countries restricted exports because of their own problems? I doubt we’ll get any severe shortage, but we are likely to see local problems, and less choice. I wonder how much we can cut down on food waste, which we’re told is 30% overall. Maybe the law should relax to allow shops to sell goods a little past their dates, but we must also accept more vegetables in imperfect condition, boxes and tins with dents, and throw away very little in our own houses.
I hope selfishness and panic will very soon be replaced by care, organisation, patience, and that we might see the best in people predominating. My optimism says we will, but my realism also says that there will be problems, profiteering, and lots of worry. I also hope that we might recognise better what’s really important, and that unlimited travel has its drawbacks. Maybe also the greater collective efforts and interventionist government could help us tackle the climate emergency?
UK policy – seriously wrong, or possibly honest?
March 16th: The quick answer – I don’t know! There are lots of people arguing, and ‘scientists’ are quoted, though many are not epidemiologists. It seems to me that assumptions are being made by all sides. I think the UK policy is roughly this:
- It’s likely that almost everyone will get this virus sooner or later, within the next year before any reliable vaccine is available. In any case, a vaccine might be only partially effective (like all flu jabs), as the virus could mutate.
- More testing won’t necessarily achieve anything as such, if 1. is correct.
- If so, then how can the peak be lowered and timed to allow best management by the NHS? Answer: by accepting a growing number of cases, whilst minimising effects on the most vulnerable.
- Banning gatherings at an early stage might just postpone the peak, or be unsustainable and make it harder later. Closing schools in particular could lead to a greater shortage of medical and emergency personnel.
- Things that affect economic activity will have other effects, including poverty and hence other health problems.
What’s wrong with all this? Well, the point about general infection and vaccines might well be true, but time to build up equipment (ventilators) and expertise will reduce deaths. We don’t know to what extent that’s been considered (but a relative of mine in France is getting a novel treatment, so knowledge will increase).
If a good vaccine can be developed in a year or so, then maybe stricter restrictions that reduce overall infection rates would be worth the social costs, but we won’t know for months yet. Vaccine development might in any case be slower than this.
Assumption 1. is key. WHO policy, that many think should be followed here, is based, I think, on the different assumption that overall infection rates can be held at a lower level and the disease eradicated or prevented by vaccination. That was clearly appropriate for Ebola.
Where our Government is clearly in the wrong is, firstly, that intensive care beds are at a low level, and there are significant shortages of nurses – they are responsible for that over the past ten years. Brexit policy is likely to make staff shortages much worse. And secondly, they could have ordered more ventilators weeks earlier – that alone might save lives.
Coronavirus – everyone’s an expert!
March 14th: For once, I think Boris Johnson might be showing some courage. He looks terrible – haggard and short of confidence. For perhaps the first time in his life he’s fully aware of major responsibility, and of decisions on which lives depend and on which he’ll be judged. The Government policy of ramping up more steadily than others has logic, though it’s not up to me (or most of us) to judge if it’s correct. What they have definitely got wrong is to start with a shortage of nurses and beds, and having damaged relationships with other countries. A complete lock-down at an early stage would probably delay the peak more, provided people didn’t tire of restrictions, and that economic hardship didn’t cause death and disease through poverty (as well as absence of medical staff). However, unless an effective vaccine were available within 6-9 months, a second wave of infections next winter, on a much larger scale, could be a disaster.
Brexit – what a mess!
March 2020: A while since I posted here – so much to think about. Johnson got his majority in December, so he could claim to ‘get Brexit done’, but really only just getting started. I rather hoped his monomaniac approach, including choosing such a loyal if untalented Cabinet, would give way to some realism, but it was not to be. He still has a crazy Cabinet, and an apparent belief that incredibly complex negotiations can be done in a few months. Three possibilities: 1. He’s genuinely OK with the idea of a hard Brexit. 2. He’ll extend the transition after all. 3. He’s going to cave in on most EU requirements. My own view is that ‘no-deal’ is improbable. Why? Because he likes being popular, and medicine shortages and the loss of industries like Nissan would make him very unpopular. I predict a mix of 2 and 3.
Preserving our beautiful world
30th December: Listening to Greta Thunberg on the radio – showing how much difference an individual can make. Before that, David Attenborough and Mark Carney, all emphasising the need for urgent action. Individual actions saving energy all make a small contribution but also help to show governments what voters want.
Disappointment but not despair
Sunday 15th: The bad news – a substantial majority for the Conservatives, gained by constant lying, unrealistic promises, little information about what a Brexit deal might look like, and vague threats against the judiciary, the press, etc. The good news – doubling our vote in both constituencies of North Tyneside and Tynemouth (around 7%). The questions: will Johnson use his majority to ignore the hard right and make a sensible deal? will the Labour Party find a sensible leader and become an effective opposition? will the Lib Dems find a distinctive purpose under a new leader? will the state of Labour and Conservative parties lead to yet more gains for Lib Dems in local elections?

Sunday 15th: The bad news – a substantial majority for the Conservatives, gained by constant lying, unrealistic promises, little information about what a Brexit deal might look like, and vague threats against the judiciary, the press, etc. The good news – doubling our vote in both constituencies of North Tyneside and Tynemouth (around 7%). The questions: will Johnson use his majority to ignore the hard right and make a sensible deal? will the Labour Party find a sensible leader and become an effective opposition? will the Lib Dems find a distinctive purpose under a new leader? will the state of Labour and Conservative parties lead to yet more gains for Lib Dems in local elections?

May 3rd: Everyone will now know that May 1st was a disaster for the Conservative Party, not forgiven for their incompetence and dishonesty over 14 years, during which they failed by every measure, whether it be financial management, migration, international reputation, etc. They weren’t even ‘conservative’, trashing our institutions and all the things that (used to) give Britain a strong reputation and so much ‘soft power’.
Of course, a local election shouldn’t just reflect the national mood, but it usually does. Local Lib Dem councillors suffered badly in the period c.2013-2017 or so. And this time, not only were Conservatives not credible, but Labour managed to skip their ‘honeymoon period’ in government too, creating an impression of an uncaring regime in their determination to be seen as financially prudent.
It was a good day for the Lib Dems, with over 300 councillors gained, and control of three councils – Cambridge, Oxford and Shropshire.
What about Reform? They are cock-a-hoop with over 600 councillors and 10 councils. But any talk of future government is highly questionable. They appear to have no real policies, a leader who hates sharing power (members get no say on policy), and minimal experience in local government. One successful candidate talked of ‘waste’ but could only think of biscuits in council meetings. It’s highly probable that within a year they’ll find they can’t do very much, especially when funding is so tight, and that waste is not only less than they think but is very hard to reduce.
The local Elected Mayor contest in North Tyneside led to a Labour Mayor again, but by a small margin of 444 votes. I did a little better than last time, but hoped for more. Here’s the results:

November 7th: Thank goodness – Biden has surpassed the 270 votes he needs and the era of Trump is coming to an end! Biden is a good man, but what a mountain to climb: the pandemic, the economy, the climate, racism. I hope that his decency and moderation will mean that even the obstructive McConnell won’t be able to block everything.
And maybe Trump will find that justice catches up with him regarding his dodgy deals, debts, etc, etc. Whether he learns from that we don’t know, but it’s hard to believe he’ll run again as has been suggested. And some of his supporters might have cause to think if he’s convicted and jailed, though others will never accept that, I’m sure.
What is certain is that Twitter won’t give him privileged status, which has meant his account hasn’t been blocked as it would have been!
The climate is in crisis. Today’s result doesn’t solve that, but at least we might not be heading for the precipice as we were. I’m so thankful for that.

July 7th: Has Boris Johnson gone too far this time? He seems to have followed a deliberate strategy (like Trump, and influenced by Lynton Crosby) of saying plausible things openly, and anticipating that his personality, a largely uncritical press (until recently!), and his status as Prime Minister will get his messages across, whilst rebuttals won’t get the same coverage. In any case, it’s been shown that, once someone ‘knows’ something, attempts to refute it often strengthen the conviction that it was right. Difficult, therefore, to change people’s minds, and argument doesn’t generally do it.
However, this week he’s stated, publically, that care homes didn’t follow procedures, and implied, at least, that the 20,000+ care-home deaths were a consequence. Since they mostly followed Gov’t advice, took in probably infected people, made use of underpaid staff who were not advised against multiple sites, and lacked necessary PPE, they are not to blame. Already he’s had to ‘clarify’ what he meant, but I anticipate that this one will run and run, and most of the press will be very unsympathetic.
His timing seems poor too. I think the rumour of 20,000 fewer troops is a ‘dead cat’ distraction, designed to take our attention off the Covid-19 crisis, the economy, and Brexit, but criticising care homes brings back dismay at the Government. On Brexit, there is talk of a collaboration with the EU over vaccine development, whilst our Galileo (GPS) substitute looks like a debacle. Maybe more Brexit U-turns are likely. Even a Leave-EU posting is worried about no-deal (though they’re trying to blame this on the delay they say was caused by Remainers, not the ERG). With more frequent criticism of the Gov’t, and Johnson in particular, in the Mail, the Telegraph and elsewhere, how long can he last?

June 25th: On Sunday evening I attended a public hustings for voters in Tynemouth, with six of the nine candidates attending, and about 60-70 members of the public. We got five minutes to introduce ourselves, then there were five questions answered by all six candidates.
I said that whereas Conservatives emphasised the individual, and Labour emphasised the collective, Lib Dems were not merely a balanced mixture, but also believed strongly that decision-making should be local, national or international as appropriate – the UK (and the two big parties) is too centralised. I also stressed my own priority of the Environment, as well as the party’s headlines on care, social care and the NHS, and on Europe and internationalism.
Our questions were on: Active Travel, Palestine, Housing, Europe, and on voting systems. My responses were generally well-received, and my overall ‘performance’ was judged as ‘brilliant!’ by one person (though I have to admit I do know them!). I do try to respond to the question, to acknowledge good points made by other candidates (and areas of disagreement), and to take every opportunity to bring the Environment into the discussion. If we had more hustings, and more time, we could explain more and avoid ‘sound-bite’ answers.
Three more hustings this week, two on young people, and one for the deaf community. Only ten days to go ……

July 7th: Has Boris Johnson gone too far this time? He seems to have followed a deliberate strategy (like Trump, and influenced by Lynton Crosby) of saying plausible things openly, and anticipating that his personality, a largely uncritical press (until recently!), and his status as Prime Minister will get his messages across, whilst rebuttals won’t get the same coverage. In any case, it’s been shown that, once someone ‘knows’ something, attempts to refute it often strengthen the conviction that it was right. Difficult, therefore, to change people’s minds, and argument doesn’t generally do it.
However, this week he’s stated, publically, that care homes didn’t follow procedures, and implied, at least, that the 20,000+ care-home deaths were a consequence. Since they mostly followed Gov’t advice, took in probably infected people, made use of underpaid staff who were not advised against multiple sites, and lacked necessary PPE, they are not to blame. Already he’s had to ‘clarify’ what he meant, but I anticipate that this one will run and run, and most of the press will be very unsympathetic.
His timing seems poor too. I think the rumour of 20,000 fewer troops is a ‘dead cat’ distraction, designed to take our attention off the Covid-19 crisis, the economy, and Brexit, but criticising care homes brings back dismay at the Government. On Brexit, there is talk of a collaboration with the EU over vaccine development, whilst our Galileo (GPS) substitute looks like a debacle. Maybe more Brexit U-turns are likely. Even a Leave-EU posting is worried about no-deal (though they’re trying to blame this on the delay they say was caused by Remainers, not the ERG). With more frequent criticism of the Gov’t, and Johnson in particular, in the Mail, the Telegraph and elsewhere, how long can he last?

September 6th: Afghanistan is a mess. How much is that the fault of the US and the UK? That’s not simple. Afghanistan is sometimes called ‘The Graveyard of Empires’, with failed attempts to rule it by the UK, the US, the USSR since around 1830. You’d think governments might learn from that!
When the US bombed and invaded in 2001, aided by the UK and others, there was at least some reason – to root out Al-Qaida – but even that was a more complex mission than it appeared, partly because of the support of elements in Pakistan (who shielded Osama bin Laden in exile for years afterwards). However, the installation of Hamid Karzai as President was problematic from the start. And the last election that installed Ashraf Ghani had an extremely low turnout. In a country with no tradition of a central government, but strong regional and tribal allegiances, any central power was likely to have trouble commanding respect. Unsurprisingly, these governments, installed in a simulacrum of western-style centralised democracies, have been partial and corrupt.
At the same time, US-led influences tried to instil patterns and levels of representation that were unfamiliar, such as setting a quota for female leaders that was actually higher than that in the US itself! In a society where women had had almost no power, this was seen as a step too far in the conservative rural areas, and reduced credibility. Meanwhile, the partiality and corruption at the centre also undermined efforts to set up an organised defence force.
Perhaps more limited objectives in culture change, and a more distinctively regional/federal governing structure might have taken root. Perhaps concentrating on female education and participation in sport and culture would have created less of a conservative backlash than what was seen as an imposition of leadership. Of course a fully-inclusive society was a fine ideal, but evidently the culture change expected in less than one generation, and the tribalism and corruption of a centralised and non-credible government, was too much. The Taliban, it seems, brought order and a familiar culture to the outlying regions when the government was seen as remote and hostile.
It’s tragic too that at a time of increasing nationalism elsewhere, the UK government has become less friendly and trusting, but also weakened severely those cultural influences that have given us ‘soft power’ and perhaps helped to encourage a more inclusive, honest and forward-looking style of government across many countries. That is, many world leaders (one in seven?) are British educated. Our Civil Service has been respected for professionalism and independence. The BBC is the most trusted international news source. Our governance has been seen as mature, rational, patient and honest. All this seems under threat. Very worrying.

May 3rd: Everyone will now know that May 1st was a disaster for the Conservative Party, not forgiven for their incompetence and dishonesty over 14 years, during which they failed by every measure, whether it be financial management, migration, international reputation, etc. They weren’t even ‘conservative’, trashing our institutions and all the things that (used to) give Britain a strong reputation and so much ‘soft power’.
Of course, a local election shouldn’t just reflect the national mood, but it usually does. Local Lib Dem councillors suffered badly in the period c.2013-2017 or so. And this time, not only were Conservatives not credible, but Labour managed to skip their ‘honeymoon period’ in government too, creating an impression of an uncaring regime in their determination to be seen as financially prudent.
It was a good day for the Lib Dems, with over 300 councillors gained, and control of three councils – Cambridge, Oxford and Shropshire.
What about Reform? They are cock-a-hoop with over 600 councillors and 10 councils. But any talk of future government is highly questionable. They appear to have no real policies, a leader who hates sharing power (members get no say on policy), and minimal experience in local government. One successful candidate talked of ‘waste’ but could only think of biscuits in council meetings. It’s highly probable that within a year they’ll find they can’t do very much, especially when funding is so tight, and that waste is not only less than they think but is very hard to reduce.

April 24th: Feeling tired today after four fixtures yesterday – BBC Radio, BBC TV, Chronicle/Journal hustings, then a hustings in Alnwick. The evening fixture was organised by Friends of the Earth and was focussed on the Environment – a subject I’ve featured and emphasised whenever I can in this campaign.
Some good questions included our support for declaring a Climate Emergency in line with the street protests and the amazing Greta Thunberg. I supported this call, as it’s such a massive issue and we should be grateful to young people in particular for insisting action is taken now. But I said, to audience agreement, that declarations aren’t much use unless we all take action, including examining our own lifestyles and sacrifices we might need to make. I already do what I can (I don’t own a car, buy second-hand and rarely fly) but maybe there’s more? Perhaps I could aim to eat only seasonal food to avoid heating, cooling and transport costs?
Another important issue raised was Biodiversity – important for the richness of our environment, for insect pollination, and for sources for new drugs.

November 22nd: Many Lib Dem members are furious that Ed Davey, and the party, are saying little about Europe, and clearly not committing to rejoining at the earliest possible date. They say things like: ‘There’s no-one arguing for EU membership, even though a clear majority now believe that leaving was a mistake, and have a favourable view of the EU!’ Starmer seems to be taking a similar line to Davey, though it’s well-known that he wanted to Remain. So why are they silent on this?
Last year, although most Labour supporters, and nearly all Lib Dem supporters, wanted to Remain, once Johnson got his majority, there was no stopping him (and it’s worth remembering that the General Election was called because the PM controlled HoC business and had withdrawn the Withdrawal Agreement, making ‘no-deal’ the default), so in 2020 the debate changed. I think both Davey and Starmer calculated that Johnson could be relied on to mess things up, and their job was to help that along, with the expectation that he’d look more and more ridiculous and dishonest. Avoiding giving him ammunition was Starmer’s idea, I think – let him stew in his own juice!
As well as avoiding the ‘it’s all the fault of Remoaners!’ tag, another key aim was to get the press turning against the Government – something that’s now happening. That works provided the Opposition doesn’t offer too many easy attack lines.
Finally, we all hope that Johnson (who isn’t actually insane, completely stupid, and is probably well-advised usually) will agree some kind of deal with the EU at the last moment. As this will be a massive U-turn, and he’ll try to present that to his own party as a victory, the worst thing to do right now is to make that harder for him, almost to force him to stick to his own bad script. And what strengthens my conviction is that he is doing things to appease his right-wing (defence increases, public-sector pay freeze) that will make his U-turn less offensive to them. Much as we might despise the man, for dishonesty, selfishness, laziness, etc, surely we want him to concede what’s needed to the EU to avoid food shortages, closure of industry, the death of farming, and a general huge hit to the economy.
He’s painted himself into a corner. We might be gleeful about that, but it’s much more important just now to allow him to jump out of it. There’ll still be the pandemic, and a major shock to the economy, and I think both Davey and Starmer will pivot quite rapidly to being more ‘I told you so’ and pro-EU once the public can see the horrible mess Johnson and his shower have got us into.

April 6th: Today the National Insurance increase is implemented. On top of huge rises in energy costs, and a continuing squeeze on benefits and local authority budgets, times will be hard for many families. Yes, it’s possible to manage on less, and people used to know more about how to do that, but life wasn’t very good for many in those ‘nostalgic times’, and in any case, why should ordinary families be told to put up with things by people who don’t have to? When coupled with a casual and hypocritical attitude to the pandemic rules by Downing street, it’s clear that this Government is seriously out of touch. Many people remain to be convinced that Labour is ready for government, but increasingly they (and the Liberal Democrats) are seen as a serious party who cares.
The Government is also out of touch on other issues. Most people oppose the selling off of Channel 4 – pointless except as a piece of dogma. Most people are supportive of more on-shore wind turbines and against fracking, yet the Government is against one and favours the other. People support more Ukrainian refugees, but the Home Office makes that very difficult. They appear to be completely wrapped up in their own rhetoric. It’s to be hoped that they lose power sooner rather than later!
The immediate prospect of a challenge to the Government will come on May 5th in the local elections. Although primarily about local issues, and distorted to some extent by dissatisfaction that results from national funding but which impinges on other parties, it seems likely that many usual Conservative voters will stay at home, whilst opposition voters will turn out with greater enthusiasm. In North Tyneside, there are prospects of more opposition councillors from the Lib Dems and the Greens, who both had impressive gains in target wards. Although the overall political ‘colour’ of the two is very different, we share the aims of addressing the climate change, holding the local council to account, and scrutinising plans and decisions to set better priorities and ensure value for money.

September 19th: The Lib Dem conference is underway this weekend, mostly by Zoom but with some people participating in London. Lots of good debates about well thought-out policy (mostly) and today the Leader’s speech. But will anyone take any notice?
The Liberal Democrats see themselves as a national party – rightly so in that they have many councillors in all areas, and usually get a credible share of the vote in seats where they already have a base and work hard. For a while, they had a substantial number of MPs – over 40 in 1997, rising to over 50 in 2010, though currently languishing just into double figures. They also have around 100 peers, and much of the impact of the party is in contributions to committee work and amendments in the House of Lords.
The problem is, though, that the public don’t really know what the Lib Dems stand for, in simple terms. Most people would say that the Conservatives (long-term, not true just now, though!) favour individual responsibility, free enterprise, sound finance, strong defence, traditional family values. Similarly, they’d say Labour favoured the NHS, the poor, fairness and equality.
What might they say about the Lib Dems? Europe. Student fees. Middle-ground. Not quite Tories nor Socialists. ……… One positive, one negative, the rest rather vague! As a party, they have a wide range of sound and interesting policy, but have trouble getting coverage for that, more so with fewer MPs. It could be argued that not being a party of sound-bites is not all bad, and that the specifics can cut through in individual elections, notably Chesham & Amersham recently.
However, in General Elections, that’s not ideal, especially with our First-Past-The-Post system. There’s much could be said about voting systems, but it’s a mistake to think that PR will solve all our problems, and I think we must be cautious in thinking that public support for statements like ‘every vote counts’, ‘get parties to collaborate more’ would necessarily translate into electoral success (‘I don’t really understand this’, ‘They want it just to suit themselves’, ‘But it might let in extremists’, ….). My experience of the Supplementary Vote system (used for Mayoral elections) is that people still put the Lib Dems second to avoid ‘letting Lab/Con in’, not realising that votes transfer, and unfortunately even obscuring the number of second choices we get (except in London, where they count and publish those too).
Although it’s sensible (aren’t they always?) to avoid alienating voters when trying to win votes from both sides, there is a danger of being just ‘not them, but not the others either’. I do think we need one or two distinctive, desirable, memorable messages that, vitally, the public associates with the Liberal Democrats.
Well, today Ed Davey set out his two main messages: Firstly, looking after our carers, at home and professional – the huge army of people who support our children, our elderly, our disabled and our sick. Secondly, a voucher for £200 for families to help their children catch up with missed education or missed opportunities during the pandemic. Families would be able to spend that on formal teaching, other classes or tutors, or activities. These two principal proposals would make a massive difference to many thousands of families struggling with current burdens and unable to profit from future opportunities.
The public care about carers, they care about their children – will these key ideas be memorable and striking? Time will tell!

April 12th: Easter, a Christian celebration of joy, hope, new life, release from despair, self-centredness, greed and listlessness, but named from a pagan festival of Spring. For us, ‘joining in’ with many thousands on-line to celebrate and look forward, but so different from normal. As new cases and numbers of deaths begin to level out, we hope for a vaccine, that new recognition of who and what is really important will not be lost amidst economic hardship, mental health, suffering in refugee camps. A few weeks more before we have any idea at all …..
John’s blog on current issues
Our Community
April 3rd: Mounting cases, mounting numbers of deaths, confusion in Government (though with a little welcome honesty yesterday!), but some positives too. Our quiet street is developing a sense of community spirit. A Green/Red flag scheme so people can signal a need is in place, maybe not revealing needs if they are already under control, but showing a keen desire to look after each other. A WhatsApp group to share experiences and wants, whether a birthday, information about mail-order, or a wish for cheese or tofu! A nurse was isolated with her family for a few days, only to find her positive was a false positive and she’s back in the front-line. A seven-year-old’s birthday was marked communally with singing and music, including my own accordion in the street outside and my wife’s violin. We’ve already been booked for the proposed street-party at the end of lock-down.
Will this community spirit continue when it’s all over? Obviously we don’t know, but at least we know more names and faces. Maybe this time will awaken people to what’s really important in life (beauty and friendship, rather than possessions), to the people they depend on who are often badly-paid and insecure, to the risks of unlimited foreign travel. I hope so.
Government logic and its limitations
March 28th: Our UK Gov’t has been much criticised. My interpretation is this. They believed (probably rightly) that nearly everyone would catch the virus before immunity and/or vaccine took effect. Therefore, it was pointless to try to delay the inevitable, including amongst medical staff, as economic harm would be bad and would also cause deaths. Moreover, the vast majority of deaths would be amongst the elderly, and would be those quite likely to die within the year (noting that the normal death rate in the UK is about 50,000 per month – rarely mentioned).
What this also assumes, I think, is that people simply divide into those that die and those that don’t. What it leaves out is four things. Firstly, a significant minority of those who die might be saved with sufficient care, hence staffing and ventilators etc are needed. Secondly, a delay in the peak gives more time to develop treatments. Thirdly, it’s been said that a higher ‘load’ of the virus not only increases the chance of catching it, but also the severity of the illness – this is pertinent to medical staff and why PPE is important. Lastly, good treatment might make death less painful even where it’s inevitable. It’s also possible that, if many can avoid it altogether this year, a vaccine might save them in a second wave.
There’s also been accusations of ideology, callousness, etc. I’m doubtful about those. I imagine both many cock-ups as a complex situation develops, and a genuine philosophical difficulty for those (like Johnson) who believe people do best with less regulation and then must adjust to imposing rules. There’s also a balance to be struck between doing the right thing logically, and being seen to do something. Johnson’s latest approval ratings suggest that he’s succeeded with that, at least!
Locked down
March 28th. Already semi-retired, and with neither young nor old to care for, I’m fairly used to time in the house, but not to an empty diary: no days at work, Metro rides, evening meetings, and fewer walks, though the beach is wide and sparse. Our street now has a chatty What’sApp group and a red/green flag for windows. More bicycles than cars sometimes too! With relatives and acquaintances seriously ill, we know it’s deadly despite our own comfort.
Totally unreal!
March 21st: I’ve read some novels about things like ‘after the nuclear holocaust’, plagues, etc, and Wyndham’s stories such as Day of the Triffids and The Chrysalids, and seen films too, such as ‘Children of Men’ (in which children are no longer born for some unknown reason). They were interesting, intriguing, slightly scary. I grew up and became an adult at a time when nuclear war seemed a possibility (though it’s not gone away entirely). One question that was addressed by all of them was how people might behave when scared, stressed, hungry. They usually told of a mixture of noble, communal, self-sacrificing behaviour, and selfish, wild, panicky behaviour. I think we see aspects of this already in this extraordinary crisis.
I’m an optimist, not always predicting good outcomes, but always believing that good things can happen. Right now, I know there will be many tragedies, many deaths, much unemployment, but still hope that society will prevail, health and well-being restored, the very worst avoided. Might the UK run short of food, even if we’re well-organised in time, if other countries restricted exports because of their own problems? I doubt we’ll get any severe shortage, but we are likely to see local problems, and less choice. I wonder how much we can cut down on food waste, which we’re told is 30% overall. Maybe the law should relax to allow shops to sell goods a little past their dates, but we must also accept more vegetables in imperfect condition, boxes and tins with dents, and throw away very little in our own houses.
I hope selfishness and panic will very soon be replaced by care, organisation, patience, and that we might see the best in people predominating. My optimism says we will, but my realism also says that there will be problems, profiteering, and lots of worry. I also hope that we might recognise better what’s really important, and that unlimited travel has its drawbacks. Maybe also the greater collective efforts and interventionist government could help us tackle the climate emergency?
UK policy – seriously wrong, or possibly honest?
March 16th: The quick answer – I don’t know! There are lots of people arguing, and ‘scientists’ are quoted, though many are not epidemiologists. It seems to me that assumptions are being made by all sides. I think the UK policy is roughly this:
- It’s likely that almost everyone will get this virus sooner or later, within the next year before any reliable vaccine is available. In any case, a vaccine might be only partially effective (like all flu jabs), as the virus could mutate.
- More testing won’t necessarily achieve anything as such, if 1. is correct.
- If so, then how can the peak be lowered and timed to allow best management by the NHS? Answer: by accepting a growing number of cases, whilst minimising effects on the most vulnerable.
- Banning gatherings at an early stage might just postpone the peak, or be unsustainable and make it harder later. Closing schools in particular could lead to a greater shortage of medical and emergency personnel.
- Things that affect economic activity will have other effects, including poverty and hence other health problems.
What’s wrong with all this? Well, the point about general infection and vaccines might well be true, but time to build up equipment (ventilators) and expertise will reduce deaths. We don’t know to what extent that’s been considered (but a relative of mine in France is getting a novel treatment, so knowledge will increase).
If a good vaccine can be developed in a year or so, then maybe stricter restrictions that reduce overall infection rates would be worth the social costs, but we won’t know for months yet. Vaccine development might in any case be slower than this.
Assumption 1. is key. WHO policy, that many think should be followed here, is based, I think, on the different assumption that overall infection rates can be held at a lower level and the disease eradicated or prevented by vaccination. That was clearly appropriate for Ebola.
Where our Government is clearly in the wrong is, firstly, that intensive care beds are at a low level, and there are significant shortages of nurses – they are responsible for that over the past ten years. Brexit policy is likely to make staff shortages much worse. And secondly, they could have ordered more ventilators weeks earlier – that alone might save lives.
Coronavirus – everyone’s an expert!
March 14th: For once, I think Boris Johnson might be showing some courage. He looks terrible – haggard and short of confidence. For perhaps the first time in his life he’s fully aware of major responsibility, and of decisions on which lives depend and on which he’ll be judged. The Government policy of ramping up more steadily than others has logic, though it’s not up to me (or most of us) to judge if it’s correct. What they have definitely got wrong is to start with a shortage of nurses and beds, and having damaged relationships with other countries. A complete lock-down at an early stage would probably delay the peak more, provided people didn’t tire of restrictions, and that economic hardship didn’t cause death and disease through poverty (as well as absence of medical staff). However, unless an effective vaccine were available within 6-9 months, a second wave of infections next winter, on a much larger scale, could be a disaster.
Brexit – what a mess!
March 2020: A while since I posted here – so much to think about. Johnson got his majority in December, so he could claim to ‘get Brexit done’, but really only just getting started. I rather hoped his monomaniac approach, including choosing such a loyal if untalented Cabinet, would give way to some realism, but it was not to be. He still has a crazy Cabinet, and an apparent belief that incredibly complex negotiations can be done in a few months. Three possibilities: 1. He’s genuinely OK with the idea of a hard Brexit. 2. He’ll extend the transition after all. 3. He’s going to cave in on most EU requirements. My own view is that ‘no-deal’ is improbable. Why? Because he likes being popular, and medicine shortages and the loss of industries like Nissan would make him very unpopular. I predict a mix of 2 and 3.
Preserving our beautiful world
30th December: Listening to Greta Thunberg on the radio – showing how much difference an individual can make. Before that, David Attenborough and Mark Carney, all emphasising the need for urgent action. Individual actions saving energy all make a small contribution but also help to show governments what voters want.
Disappointment but not despair
Sunday 15th: The bad news – a substantial majority for the Conservatives, gained by constant lying, unrealistic promises, little information about what a Brexit deal might look like, and vague threats against the judiciary, the press, etc. The good news – doubling our vote in both constituencies of North Tyneside and Tynemouth (around 7%). The questions: will Johnson use his majority to ignore the hard right and make a sensible deal? will the Labour Party find a sensible leader and become an effective opposition? will the Lib Dems find a distinctive purpose under a new leader? will the state of Labour and Conservative parties lead to yet more gains for Lib Dems in local elections?

April 23rd: Walking across Castle Leazes to the BBC Newcastle studios for an interview on ‘Alfie and Anna at Breakfast’ (8.20am, on BBC Sounds), I saw that the cows were back for the summer. I used to see them every day from April to October when I lived in Fenham and walked to Newcastle University each day.
Category: Uncategorized
New life at Easter
April 21st – Easter Sunday: Greeting the dawn at 5.45am on the sea-front at Whitley Bay with forty people from local churches. A wonderful, beautiful clear morning with hope for new life. Good words on the radio too about how new energy and hope can rise from disaster, such as the fire at Notre Dame, and how similar that story is to the fire at Brancepeth Church in County Durham in 1997. Both seemed to resonate with people of faith and none – a sense of shared history and mystery about these ancient buildings.
Centre for Cities hustings
April 18th: At a hustings organised by the Centre for Cities and the NE Chamber of Commerce, where all five candidates answered questions on the economy, transport, etc. Some good questions: ‘Why would an entrepreneur choose Newcastle?’, ‘How do we make the local economy more inclusive?’ (this meant including those from different socio-economic backgrounds), ‘What would you do for business in Newcastle City Centre?’.
The whole 90 minute session was filmed by Hexham TV (a web-based community station – also see March 6th) and can be seen at: https://m.facebook.com/watch/?v=2439405909629159&_rdr
(Also note that my interview with Sustrans is available as three items on my Twitter posts.)
Look at the interviewer, not the camera
April 18th: A busy day yesterday, starting with filming by ITV on Blyth dockside for the evening programmes on Thursday 25th. It felt like one of those adverts, sitting at a table in the open air with cranes, goods and the sea behind. Seven questions about me, my aims and policy, and my local knowledge (and I got the local celebrity right!).
Later that morning, an important session with ‘Becoming Visible’ – working with deaf people on materials, education and advice for employment. They filmed me answering questions and will add sign language later so that the deaf community can get information accessibly. We discussed difficulties of funding, of delayed education, and the need for employers to see disabled people as an underused resource rather than a problem to be solved.
My Sustrans interview (see previous blog item) was then followed by a personal profile by an Evening Chronicle reporter. I declined to say who my second vote would be cast for, and explained that I was offering myself and my experience for a job that needs to be done well – this is not a personal ambition – and that linked to my personal faith.
Getting around
April 17th: Meetings concerning transport and logistics in the area, with Directors of the North East Joint Transport Committee, the CEO of the Port of Tyne Authority, and senior staff of Sustrans, the cycling organisation.
Transport is a crucial aspect of the functioning and prosperity of the North of Tyne area and the whole region, but unlike the other ‘Metro Mayors’, our new Mayor won’t have direct control owing to the overlapping responsibilities of the various authorities.
I heard lots about strategic plans, the need for Government as well as regional investment, and challenged them on how new environmental targets would affect their plans. Sustrans will advise on more than cycling; they’ll help find solutions for Active Living in cities, including public transport, walking and cycling.
Newcastle Airport is run separately, and well, but a low carbon strategy for the area can’t simply assume growth in all aspects of transport. David Attenborough, and the recent ‘Extinction Rebellion’ protests are highlighting this, and this letter was in yesterday’s Metro – the public are taking this seriously now!
A short break
April 10th: I love the British countryside, and the North of Tyne area has a lot of it (some of that actually South of the Tyne!). Although this break was in the Lake District, both areas share beauty, many small communities, and many, many sheep! Returning over the Pennines via Alston, I noticed the border from Cumbria back into Northumberland with new eyes!
Flights of fancy
4th March: A useful discussion with the Chief Executive and Planning & Corporate Affairs Director of Newcastle Airport about their plans for visitors, tourism, business, and the challenges of balancing prosperity for the region with the growing environmental threat. Today they’re releasing a new website for tourism across the North-East on behalf of their seven local authority partners and other agencies: http://visitnortheastengland.com/
After that, an interview and photo-shoot, plus short video, with NETimes – a digital magazine for business in the North-East. https://netimesmagazine.co.uk/times-live/the-future-of-the-north-of-tyne/ /
Open for Business
3rd March: A demanding two hours on the platform at a Business Hustings organised by the CBI, NE Chamber of Commerce, Federation of Small Businesses, Entrepreneurs Forum for all four declared candidates (nb. a fifth declared that afternoon). We had a chance to set out our vision and approach, our values, and specific policies for business, including human issues of equality, poverty, education, etc. Lots of questions from the floor and submitted electronically. Weds 27th: I think things are really bad in UK politics right now! To have our two biggest parties, both with leaders not really trusted even by many of their traditional supporters, with long-standing senior members advising voting for other parties, is just weird! A choice between a bad Brexit under a shifty and untruthful leader, or an unclear outcome under a weak leader with dodgy associates, is what the public often sees and doesn’t like. Why don’t they just vote Liberal Democrat? We’ve been consistent on Brexit. Our manifesto is costed and realistic, and honest about the need for tax rises, our leader has apologised for past mistakes, we have endorsements from the CBI on Business and the Resolution Foundation on Poverty. Just vote!

January 13th: I was gripped by Prime Minister’s Questions yesterday! As many said, Keir Starmer was aiming at an open goal, and scored repeatedly. Few Conservatives supported the PM at all; just a few asked boilerplate, irrelevant questions to try to take the heat off their ‘winning’ leader.
In 2019, many Conservative MPs, most Conservative members, and then sufficient voters, thought that Johnson, for all his known faults, would do a good enough job as PM, getting the country out of the endless, boring, Brexit debate (some Remainers thought this too), and there would be enough checks and balances to keep him from doing too much harm. As with Trump in the US, that was hopelessly optimistic. Brexit is an ongoing open sore, and Johnson gets worse, not better.
Before all the stuff about parties, and wallpaper, and dodgy dealings of all kinds, I often said that my chief regrets about the past six years were the lying, the disregard of courtesy and convention, the undermining or actual attacks on our highly-prized institutions (Rule of Law, human rights, the BBC, universities, animal welfare, the Civil Service, honesty in treaties and diplomacy, democracy, …….), and the shredding of our international reputation. These bothered me more than loss of freedom of movement or economic harm, important though those were.
Is Johnson finished? I don’t know – in the next week or so many Conservative MPs will find out if their constituents get more and more angry, or simmer down. What that party (or the Conservative Work-Event, as I call it now!) won’t want is a leadership election during March and April, with local elections coming up. They’ll either act very soon, or wait until the Summer.
If the former, then it’s likely Sunak will be the next PM. Apart from confidence and presentation, we know nothing about his abilities, and his experience is of privilege. He’d at least be able to stay in the same flat at number 10 if he wanted! But there are other Conservatives with more experience who’d stand more chance of tackling the crises of the pandemic, the economy, cost-of-living, etc.

That’s true at every level – individual, community, borough, regional, national and international too! And because I believe that the North-East is often overlooked despite its many strengths (even often missed in weather forecasts!). November 22nd: Many Lib Dem members are furious that Ed Davey, and the party, are saying little about Europe, and clearly not committing to rejoining at the earliest possible date. They say things like: ‘There’s no-one arguing for EU membership, even though a clear majority now believe that leaving was a mistake, and have a favourable view of the EU!’ Starmer seems to be taking a similar line to Davey, though it’s well-known that he wanted to Remain. So why are they silent on this?
Last year, although most Labour supporters, and nearly all Lib Dem supporters, wanted to Remain, once Johnson got his majority, there was no stopping him (and it’s worth remembering that the General Election was called because the PM controlled HoC business and had withdrawn the Withdrawal Agreement, making ‘no-deal’ the default), so in 2020 the debate changed. I think both Davey and Starmer calculated that Johnson could be relied on to mess things up, and their job was to help that along, with the expectation that he’d look more and more ridiculous and dishonest. Avoiding giving him ammunition was Starmer’s idea, I think – let him stew in his own juice!
As well as avoiding the ‘it’s all the fault of Remoaners!’ tag, another key aim was to get the press turning against the Government – something that’s now happening. That works provided the Opposition doesn’t offer too many easy attack lines.
Finally, we all hope that Johnson (who isn’t actually insane, completely stupid, and is probably well-advised usually) will agree some kind of deal with the EU at the last moment. As this will be a massive U-turn, and he’ll try to present that to his own party as a victory, the worst thing to do right now is to make that harder for him, almost to force him to stick to his own bad script. And what strengthens my conviction is that he is doing things to appease his right-wing (defence increases, public-sector pay freeze) that will make his U-turn less offensive to them. Much as we might despise the man, for dishonesty, selfishness, laziness, etc, surely we want him to concede what’s needed to the EU to avoid food shortages, closure of industry, the death of farming, and a general huge hit to the economy.
He’s painted himself into a corner. We might be gleeful about that, but it’s much more important just now to allow him to jump out of it. There’ll still be the pandemic, and a major shock to the economy, and I think both Davey and Starmer will pivot quite rapidly to being more ‘I told you so’ and pro-EU once the public can see the horrible mess Johnson and his shower have got us into.

March 23rd: I’m a mild royalist, mostly on the grounds that the alternatives look worse, but I’m very sympathetic to the immense pressures on anyone subjected to constant scrutiny. The Princess of Wales does well in this tricky role, but the past few weeks must have been pretty terrible, coping with her illness, public interest, and malicious speculation. Why might she have edited her own photo, if indeed she did? Perhaps it was actually edited by George, and she took the rap!
Whatever the full story, which is not very interesting in itself, what’s clear is that much of the press would rather focus on this than the dismal record of the current Government and its almost complete lack of plans, energy and competence. Apart from ideology, we do need a competent government that has energy to get things done, and honesty in telling us what they’re doing and what they can’t do.

Thursday 12th: Polling day, though many will have already posted their votes. Turnout in marginal seats is reportedly high. By about 10.15pm we’ll have some idea of the overall picture, but the count of seats will depend on those marginals.
In the past week, my personal team of three has delivered about 2,250 leaflets in one of our constituencies. We might not win, but it’s important to let people know what we stand for, to signal to other candidates and parties that not everyone agrees with either, to add to the national vote share, and, I believe, to demonstrate a positive attitude to the best in other parties and people.
On Tuesday evening, I was filmed answering a local-knowledge quiz (three of the five Tynemouth candidates participated). I didn’t do as well as the sitting MP, but he has lived here much longer than I have! Watch it at: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=99DLsJDMRu0
I’ll be up tonight until about 4 a.m. to hear my own result, but luckily I don’t have to work tomorrow. I don’t yet know whether I’ll be fairly cheerful or rather depressed – the latter if Brexit is confirmed (i.e. the very first stage of a lengthy process!), but I expect we’ll all have some time off before renewing our commitment to making the UK a better, more welcoming, and more sustainable country. We believe a majority would now support Remain, and a definite majority say that the Referendum shouldn’t have been held. What a waste of time, effort, anguish, to achieve a poorer result, and certainly a weakening of Britain’s reputation for pragmatism, civility and moderation.

September 6th: Afghanistan is a mess. How much is that the fault of the US and the UK? That’s not simple. Afghanistan is sometimes called ‘The Graveyard of Empires’, with failed attempts to rule it by the UK, the US, the USSR since around 1830. You’d think governments might learn from that!
When the US bombed and invaded in 2001, aided by the UK and others, there was at least some reason – to root out Al-Qaida – but even that was a more complex mission than it appeared, partly because of the support of elements in Pakistan (who shielded Osama bin Laden in exile for years afterwards). However, the installation of Hamid Karzai as President was problematic from the start. And the last election that installed Ashraf Ghani had an extremely low turnout. In a country with no tradition of a central government, but strong regional and tribal allegiances, any central power was likely to have trouble commanding respect. Unsurprisingly, these governments, installed in a simulacrum of western-style centralised democracies, have been partial and corrupt.
At the same time, US-led influences tried to instil patterns and levels of representation that were unfamiliar, such as setting a quota for female leaders that was actually higher than that in the US itself! In a society where women had had almost no power, this was seen as a step too far in the conservative rural areas, and reduced credibility. Meanwhile, the partiality and corruption at the centre also undermined efforts to set up an organised defence force.
Perhaps more limited objectives in culture change, and a more distinctively regional/federal governing structure might have taken root. Perhaps concentrating on female education and participation in sport and culture would have created less of a conservative backlash than what was seen as an imposition of leadership. Of course a fully-inclusive society was a fine ideal, but evidently the culture change expected in less than one generation, and the tribalism and corruption of a centralised and non-credible government, was too much. The Taliban, it seems, brought order and a familiar culture to the outlying regions when the government was seen as remote and hostile.
It’s tragic too that at a time of increasing nationalism elsewhere, the UK government has become less friendly and trusting, but also weakened severely those cultural influences that have given us ‘soft power’ and perhaps helped to encourage a more inclusive, honest and forward-looking style of government across many countries. That is, many world leaders (one in seven?) are British educated. Our Civil Service has been respected for professionalism and independence. The BBC is the most trusted international news source. Our governance has been seen as mature, rational, patient and honest. All this seems under threat. Very worrying.

April 15th: Today, the Newcastle Chronicle & Journal organised a hustings for seven candidates for North Tyneside Mayor. That was the obvious five parties, plus two independents. Questions came from Chronicle readers, plus a small crowd of invited visitors from Citizens T&W in the recording ‘studio’. We had up to one minute for an opening ‘pitch’, then up to one minute for each answer. Two good questions came from sixth-formers, on crumbling school buildings and on mental health.
I emphasised my pragmatism, my focus on creating a good environment for pleasure, health and the planet, and the need to consult people fully and properly.
There were some good ideas from other candidates, but also a lack of realism in opposing the closure of a loss-making school. I pointed out that the Conservatives academy scheme had taken away from local authorities the power to plan for school capacity. Some candidates advocated ‘savings’ (= cuts) without saying where – it’s easy to talk of inefficiencies without being able to deliver them.
With the Greens and one Independent, I favoured cross-party working. On the housing shortage, most of us agreed on the need for more social housing, and on my observation that ‘affordable housing’ meant nothing of the sort. I recommended appointing more inspectors of housing conditions, and said that the Grenfell disaster was partly a consequence of a shortage of fire inspectors and experts.
The hustings has been written up – see: https://www.chroniclelive.co.uk/news/north-east-news/northtyneside-mayoral-elections-hustings-31431618
An audio form should be available shortly. I’ll add the link here once I’ve got it.

July 30th: Today Lib Dem members get to vote for the new leader – Ed Davey or Layla Moran. What should we be looking for in our leader? How much does our decision depend on current circumstances (short-term) or be independent of them (longer-term)? What’s the priority – vision (and PR attractive) or experience (credibility)?
Vision: this is very important, as it’s about inspiration, attractiveness, getting noticed (difficult for LD always!), setting party priorities, engaging support internally as well as from outside. But even Vision has different aspects – priorities, clear statements, chiming with public perceptions and desires, and it links with credibility too. In a senior management role, I found that I could advocate only those things that I believed in myself, that I believed were feasible, and which I also thought could be both exciting and credible with my colleagues.
Experience: this covers both ‘having done it’, knowledge, and also evidence of competence in managing a broad and complex range of issues and decisions, and of selecting and managing staff. I worked both alongside and below managers who sometimes had lots of Vision but less of these aspects. It’s not much use dealing with complexity by ignoring things, making over-hasty decisions, or delegating to the extent of abdicating responsibility.
Both Conservative and Labour parties have in recent years chosen ‘leaders’ who were seen by members as strong on a kind of vision, but in Johnson’s case that was mostly a few simple slogans, and in Corbyn’s case a set of values that didn’t chime with the public. For both, there was little credibility, lots of naivety, but the disconnect was evidently worse in Corbyn’s case.
Now things are changing. Keir Starmer is not inspiring, but on almost every criterion public opinion is supportive of him as a serious, competent and trustworthy leader. Labour policy, and therefore voting intention, are lagging behind, but it’s clear that here and in the USA, where Biden is seen as decent and honest, the public are returning to the need for grown-up government.
For the Lib Dems right now, it’s tempting to think Layla Moran will get more attention and be more inspiring. That might be true in the short-term, but would it last. Once the hard questions start coming in, would she stand up to that level of scrutiny? Would the press and public see her as a solid, competent, leader of a national party? Well, maybe, maybe not. I think she’d be pretty good, and probably come over better than Jo Swinson, and I also think she’s more instinctively inclusive in her style. However, I think Ed Davey is the right choice, as his warmth, experience (both personal and professional), and priorities are the right ones. Environment and Carers are excellent priorities for us, and his character and experience will be reliable both under scrutiny and in the work of getting the Lib Dems back to a substantial number of seats. But I’m willing to give Layla the benefit of the doubt if she is elected and wish her well.
I’ve just voted for Ed!

March 14th: For once, I think Boris Johnson might be showing some courage. He looks terrible – haggard and short of confidence. For perhaps the first time in his life he’s fully aware of major responsibility, and of decisions on which lives depend and on which he’ll be judged. The Government policy of ramping up more steadily than others has logic, though it’s not up to me (or most of us) to judge if it’s correct. What they have definitely got wrong is to start with a shortage of nurses and beds, and having damaged relationships with other countries. A complete lock-down at an early stage would probably delay the peak more, provided people didn’t tire of restrictions, and that economic hardship didn’t cause death and disease through poverty (as well as absence of medical staff). However, unless an effective vaccine were available within 6-9 months, a second wave of infections next winter, on a much larger scale, could be a disaster.

March 14th: I’ve just watched short videos of arrests in Russian cities – one of a protestor with a card saying, literally, ‘two words’, and the other with a card that was completely blank. The Russian government is afraid of criticism. Much of its attitude is even more rooted in the past than Britain’s current nostalgia of ‘Dad’s Army’ and ‘Britannia rules the waves’.
But it’s also true that our governments have failed to tell the truth, in the sense of both words and actions. The belief that economic engagement would convert Russia, China and other autocracies to our liberal democracy was naive. Of course engagement, and particularly educating foreign students, is part of what’s needed, but sterner stuff must also be shown when such trust is clearly abused, as in Salisbury, Crimea, Syria, and substantial dependence on Russian energy supplies was a real risk, especially coupled with inadequate storage.
At the same time, our governments have failed to be honest with us about the need to pay our way – in taxes sufficient to provide the services we value, and in balancing our trade so that foreign investment can be selective rather than uncritical. The ‘golden visa’ scheme was always a terrible idea (actually introduced under Gordon Brown!), but should at least have had safeguards, notably a restriction on political donations for an initial period.
It’s commonplace to say ‘they’re all liars’ about our politicians, whilst expecting unrealistic things to be done, and voting for the best promises rather than the honest but more mundane ‘we’ll do what we can’. Vision is great, exaggerated promises are not.
