April 22nd: The UK did not join the EU procurement scheme for ventilators and other equipment until recently (after the initial schemes). That’s an agreed fact. Why did we not? That’s now the subject of intense and hostile dispute. The Government ‘line’ and rebuttal/clarification:
- ‘We aren’t part of the EU.’ – But we were able to participate if we chose.
- ‘We didn’t get the emails.’ – Improbable, but just conceivable when an incompetent government, working with a bureaucratic decision-making system, faces crisis and chaos.
- ‘The EU schemes haven’t yet delivered anything.’ – True, but both unwise to eschew any collaboration right now, and these schemes could well be crucial in future.
- ‘A political decision was taken.’ (Permanent Secretary). ‘No, it wasn’t.’ (Gov’t) – A chorus of ‘liars!’ followed.
What I suspect is this. When the idea of a joint scheme was raised, the Gov’t discussed it, and concluded that a UK-only approach would be just as effective, certainly nearly as effective, hopefully more effective. This was certainly the firm belief of the keen Brexiteers such as Gove and Raab, and Johnson has always believed in low regulation (though he was less anti-EU over other issues). Thus they thought they’d not only get as good a result, but also demonstrate the ‘go-it-alone’ Brexit value.
I’ve met many politicians, at all levels, and been involved myself, as well as experience of senior management, decision-making, and, indeed, ‘news management’. My clear impression is that outright lying is not common in the UK, but wishful thinking is very common, both in campaigning (where the public want quick and simple solutions!) and in defending one’s record.
This also comes into play when people complain that politicians put ‘party before country’. If you genuinely believe that the opposing party would be a disaster for the country, then defending your own party is, in that mentality, working for the country. In normal times, the opposing party would not be a disaster and MPs and ministers should maintain truth and principled actions as far as possible, and resign if they can’t. In the last General Election, I suspect that many mostly decent Conservative MPs genuinely thought that a Corbyn led government would be disastrous (and maybe that going back on Brexit might be too), hence their unstinting support for a most unsuitable, but confident and charismatic leader. With Keir Starmer as Leader of the Opposition, that no longer applies. Principled Conservatives should not fear loss of power, and they could actually be more free to criticise their own side!
I don’t understand why the government has got into such a mess about this. They should have put together a team of expert procurement people and asked them to get on with it. They are scoring own goals by taking responsibility fro things they have no expertise in.

February 8th: I decided some years ago that I hate dogma. That’s not a particular dogma, just all of it! There might be a very few exceptions, but these would be a few ‘truths’ for me, such as statements about the importance of truth itself, honesty, the value of human beings, the need to look after the world for the sake of our children and grandchildren, etc.
Dogma means (to me) an explicit statement of a belief that the holder is unwilling to question. I have no objection to strong beliefs, strongly argued, it’s the closed-mindedness that’s the problem, the ‘black-and-white’ view of the subject or the world. Just now, it’s party politics that’s at the forefront of my mind, but I will mention one other area.
Boris Johnson shouldn’t be Prime Minister. Increasingly, that’s a view held by many Conservative voters and MPs, as well as almost all others. It’s commonly said that by continuing to support him in post, those people are ‘putting party before country’, or ‘putting their own careers before principles’. I don’t think it’s so simple, though I’m not excusing it. It’s clear to me that for many of these MPs (and voters), there is a strong conviction that a Conservative government is best for the country, certainly in the longer-term and probably in the medium-term too. That is, even with doubts and problems at present, they continue to think that a Labour government will be worse for the country overall than almost any conceivable government by ‘their’ party. In this sense, they might believe they are putting country before anything else. Of course, an element of personal career is relevant, but the argument extends easily to: ‘I’ll be a better MP for my constituency than my opponent, because of my core values.’
Whilst I understand this mentality up to a point, it’s dangerous, as it can lead incrementally to acceptance, even advocacy, of bad policy, bad behaviour, bad management, etc. Surely most Conservative MPs would not have supported Johnson so willingly in 2019 if they’d known in advance how he might behave, how little he valued them, their opinions, their values.
A dogmatic position that says, in effect: any Conservative government, however bad, is always better than any Labour government, however good, is not a rational position, it’s a black-and-white dogma and should be called out and given no power. Of course, the same would be true for the converse.
Here’s my other example: When I was young, homosexuality was unknown, then weird, then a joke, then strange, then gradually more a fact of life. However, until I was about 25-30, I wasn’t wholly comfortable with this, whilst trying hard to be accepting. What finally brought me ‘off the fence’ was this: To hold the traditional view (of heterosexual lifelong marriage) was, in effect, to judge that any traditional marriage relationship, however bad, was automatically better than any other form of relationship, however good. That is, a dogmatic traditional position was clearly wrong and untenable for me. Thereafter, I accepted the validity and value of all good, committed, respectful relationships, hetero- or homo-sexual, whilst still rejecting any relationship that didn’t meet those values, or didn’t try hard to. I could add other rejected dogmas to these two, but that’s enough for today!

Tuesday 12th: I visited one of our active local Lib Dem branches, meeting in Morpeth, to hear what matters to them and areas beyond Tyneside. Northumberland is the most sparsely-populated county in England, and most of the people in the North of Tyne area are concentrated in the South-East corner, namely Newcastle, North Tyneside, plus Ashington and Blyth. Balancing the needs of this much wider area with the cities and large towns is a challenge I’d have to meet as Mayor. My discussions with the NE Chamber of Commerce revealed low membership of rural businesses.
Moreover, Brexit, in any form, would hit agriculture, not just manufacturing. In fact, Jacob Rees-Mogg’s favourite economist, Patrick Minford, said Brexit would be good for the UK but would decimate industry and agriculture – was that what people voted for?

April 17th: Meetings concerning transport and logistics in the area, with Directors of the North East Joint Transport Committee, the CEO of the Port of Tyne Authority, and senior staff of Sustrans, the cycling organisation.
Transport is a crucial aspect of the functioning and prosperity of the North of Tyne area and the whole region, but unlike the other ‘Metro Mayors’, our new Mayor won’t have direct control owing to the overlapping responsibilities of the various authorities.
I heard lots about strategic plans, the need for Government as well as regional investment, and challenged them on how new environmental targets would affect their plans. Sustrans will advise on more than cycling; they’ll help find solutions for Active Living in cities, including public transport, walking and cycling.
Newcastle Airport is run separately, and well, but a low carbon strategy for the area can’t simply assume growth in all aspects of transport. David Attenborough, and the recent ‘Extinction Rebellion’ protests are highlighting this, and this letter was in yesterday’s Metro – the public are taking this seriously now!

These pages relate to the Election of the Mayor of the ‘North of Tyne Combined Authority’ in May 2019 – a new post with a new joint organisation formed from the three local authorities: Newcastle upon Tyne, North Tyneside and Northumberland. My manifesto (several forms) and summary of policies are listed. There are also frequent blog entries relating to the campaign period under my ‘News’ page.
Jamie Driscoll (Labour) was elected to this position, with ambitious promises to transform the NE economy, create jobs, build housing, etc. etc. Time will tell how much of this is actually achievable with the limited powers and funding attached to the CA and the Mayor’s position. The NoT Mayor and CA are the weakest of all the ‘Metro Mayors’ in the UK as the area is smaller than most, but also doesn’t include powers that overlap with the existing NE CA which involves the four ‘south of Tyne’ authorities but which wouldn’t join this new CA at this time. We’ll be watching this space!

Thursday 12th: Polling day, though many will have already posted their votes. Turnout in marginal seats is reportedly high. By about 10.15pm we’ll have some idea of the overall picture, but the count of seats will depend on those marginals.
In the past week, my personal team of three has delivered about 2,250 leaflets in one of our constituencies. We might not win, but it’s important to let people know what we stand for, to signal to other candidates and parties that not everyone agrees with either, to add to the national vote share, and, I believe, to demonstrate a positive attitude to the best in other parties and people.
On Tuesday evening, I was filmed answering a local-knowledge quiz (three of the five Tynemouth candidates participated). I didn’t do as well as the sitting MP, but he has lived here much longer than I have! Watch it at: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=99DLsJDMRu0
I’ll be up tonight until about 4 a.m. to hear my own result, but luckily I don’t have to work tomorrow. I don’t yet know whether I’ll be fairly cheerful or rather depressed – the latter if Brexit is confirmed (i.e. the very first stage of a lengthy process!), but I expect we’ll all have some time off before renewing our commitment to making the UK a better, more welcoming, and more sustainable country. We believe a majority would now support Remain, and a definite majority say that the Referendum shouldn’t have been held. What a waste of time, effort, anguish, to achieve a poorer result, and certainly a weakening of Britain’s reputation for pragmatism, civility and moderation.

April 12th: Easter, a Christian celebration of joy, hope, new life, release from despair, self-centredness, greed and listlessness, but named from a pagan festival of Spring. For us, ‘joining in’ with many thousands on-line to celebrate and look forward, but so different from normal. As new cases and numbers of deaths begin to level out, we hope for a vaccine, that new recognition of who and what is really important will not be lost amidst economic hardship, mental health, suffering in refugee camps. A few weeks more before we have any idea at all …..

Our Community
April 3rd: Mounting cases, mounting numbers of deaths, confusion in Government (though with a little welcome honesty yesterday!), but some positives too. Our quiet street is developing a sense of community spirit. A Green/Red flag scheme so people can signal a need is in place, maybe not revealing needs if they are already under control, but showing a keen desire to look after each other. A WhatsApp group to share experiences and wants, whether a birthday, information about mail-order, or a wish for cheese or tofu! A nurse was isolated with her family for a few days, only to find her positive was a false positive and she’s back in the front-line. A seven-year-old’s birthday was marked communally with singing and music, including my own accordion in the street outside and my wife’s violin. We’ve already been booked for the proposed street-party at the end of lock-down.
Will this community spirit continue when it’s all over? Obviously we don’t know, but at least we know more names and faces. Maybe this time will awaken people to what’s really important in life (beauty and friendship, rather than possessions), to the people they depend on who are often badly-paid and insecure, to the risks of unlimited foreign travel. I hope so.
Government logic and its limitations
March 28th: Our UK Gov’t has been much criticised. My interpretation is this. They believed (probably rightly) that nearly everyone would catch the virus before immunity and/or vaccine took effect. Therefore, it was pointless to try to delay the inevitable, including amongst medical staff, as economic harm would be bad and would also cause deaths. Moreover, the vast majority of deaths would be amongst the elderly, and would be those quite likely to die within the year (noting that the normal death rate in the UK is about 50,000 per month – rarely mentioned).
What this also assumes, I think, is that people simply divide into those that die and those that don’t. What it leaves out is four things. Firstly, a significant minority of those who die might be saved with sufficient care, hence staffing and ventilators etc are needed. Secondly, a delay in the peak gives more time to develop treatments. Thirdly, it’s been said that a higher ‘load’ of the virus not only increases the chance of catching it, but also the severity of the illness – this is pertinent to medical staff and why PPE is important. Lastly, good treatment might make death less painful even where it’s inevitable. It’s also possible that, if many can avoid it altogether this year, a vaccine might save them in a second wave.
There’s also been accusations of ideology, callousness, etc. I’m doubtful about those. I imagine both many cock-ups as a complex situation develops, and a genuine philosophical difficulty for those (like Johnson) who believe people do best with less regulation and then must adjust to imposing rules. There’s also a balance to be struck between doing the right thing logically, and being seen to do something. Johnson’s latest approval ratings suggest that he’s succeeded with that, at least!
Locked down
March 28th. Already semi-retired, and with neither young nor old to care for, I’m fairly used to time in the house, but not to an empty diary: no days at work, Metro rides, evening meetings, and fewer walks, though the beach is wide and sparse. Our street now has a chatty What’sApp group and a red/green flag for windows. More bicycles than cars sometimes too! With relatives and acquaintances seriously ill, we know it’s deadly despite our own comfort.
Totally unreal!
March 21st: I’ve read some novels about things like ‘after the nuclear holocaust’, plagues, etc, and Wyndham’s stories such as Day of the Triffids and The Chrysalids, and seen films too, such as ‘Children of Men’ (in which children are no longer born for some unknown reason). They were interesting, intriguing, slightly scary. I grew up and became an adult at a time when nuclear war seemed a possibility (though it’s not gone away entirely). One question that was addressed by all of them was how people might behave when scared, stressed, hungry. They usually told of a mixture of noble, communal, self-sacrificing behaviour, and selfish, wild, panicky behaviour. I think we see aspects of this already in this extraordinary crisis.
I’m an optimist, not always predicting good outcomes, but always believing that good things can happen. Right now, I know there will be many tragedies, many deaths, much unemployment, but still hope that society will prevail, health and well-being restored, the very worst avoided. Might the UK run short of food, even if we’re well-organised in time, if other countries restricted exports because of their own problems? I doubt we’ll get any severe shortage, but we are likely to see local problems, and less choice. I wonder how much we can cut down on food waste, which we’re told is 30% overall. Maybe the law should relax to allow shops to sell goods a little past their dates, but we must also accept more vegetables in imperfect condition, boxes and tins with dents, and throw away very little in our own houses.
I hope selfishness and panic will very soon be replaced by care, organisation, patience, and that we might see the best in people predominating. My optimism says we will, but my realism also says that there will be problems, profiteering, and lots of worry. I also hope that we might recognise better what’s really important, and that unlimited travel has its drawbacks. Maybe also the greater collective efforts and interventionist government could help us tackle the climate emergency?
UK policy – seriously wrong, or possibly honest?
March 16th: The quick answer – I don’t know! There are lots of people arguing, and ‘scientists’ are quoted, though many are not epidemiologists. It seems to me that assumptions are being made by all sides. I think the UK policy is roughly this:
- It’s likely that almost everyone will get this virus sooner or later, within the next year before any reliable vaccine is available. In any case, a vaccine might be only partially effective (like all flu jabs), as the virus could mutate.
- More testing won’t necessarily achieve anything as such, if 1. is correct.
- If so, then how can the peak be lowered and timed to allow best management by the NHS? Answer: by accepting a growing number of cases, whilst minimising effects on the most vulnerable.
- Banning gatherings at an early stage might just postpone the peak, or be unsustainable and make it harder later. Closing schools in particular could lead to a greater shortage of medical and emergency personnel.
- Things that affect economic activity will have other effects, including poverty and hence other health problems.
What’s wrong with all this? Well, the point about general infection and vaccines might well be true, but time to build up equipment (ventilators) and expertise will reduce deaths. We don’t know to what extent that’s been considered (but a relative of mine in France is getting a novel treatment, so knowledge will increase).
If a good vaccine can be developed in a year or so, then maybe stricter restrictions that reduce overall infection rates would be worth the social costs, but we won’t know for months yet. Vaccine development might in any case be slower than this.
Assumption 1. is key. WHO policy, that many think should be followed here, is based, I think, on the different assumption that overall infection rates can be held at a lower level and the disease eradicated or prevented by vaccination. That was clearly appropriate for Ebola.
Where our Government is clearly in the wrong is, firstly, that intensive care beds are at a low level, and there are significant shortages of nurses – they are responsible for that over the past ten years. Brexit policy is likely to make staff shortages much worse. And secondly, they could have ordered more ventilators weeks earlier – that alone might save lives.
Coronavirus – everyone’s an expert!
March 14th: For once, I think Boris Johnson might be showing some courage. He looks terrible – haggard and short of confidence. For perhaps the first time in his life he’s fully aware of major responsibility, and of decisions on which lives depend and on which he’ll be judged. The Government policy of ramping up more steadily than others has logic, though it’s not up to me (or most of us) to judge if it’s correct. What they have definitely got wrong is to start with a shortage of nurses and beds, and having damaged relationships with other countries. A complete lock-down at an early stage would probably delay the peak more, provided people didn’t tire of restrictions, and that economic hardship didn’t cause death and disease through poverty (as well as absence of medical staff). However, unless an effective vaccine were available within 6-9 months, a second wave of infections next winter, on a much larger scale, could be a disaster.
Brexit – what a mess!
March 2020: A while since I posted here – so much to think about. Johnson got his majority in December, so he could claim to ‘get Brexit done’, but really only just getting started. I rather hoped his monomaniac approach, including choosing such a loyal if untalented Cabinet, would give way to some realism, but it was not to be. He still has a crazy Cabinet, and an apparent belief that incredibly complex negotiations can be done in a few months. Three possibilities: 1. He’s genuinely OK with the idea of a hard Brexit. 2. He’ll extend the transition after all. 3. He’s going to cave in on most EU requirements. My own view is that ‘no-deal’ is improbable. Why? Because he likes being popular, and medicine shortages and the loss of industries like Nissan would make him very unpopular. I predict a mix of 2 and 3.
Preserving our beautiful world
30th December: Listening to Greta Thunberg on the radio – showing how much difference an individual can make. Before that, David Attenborough and Mark Carney, all emphasising the need for urgent action. Individual actions saving energy all make a small contribution but also help to show governments what voters want.
Disappointment but not despair
Sunday 15th: The bad news – a substantial majority for the Conservatives, gained by constant lying, unrealistic promises, little information about what a Brexit deal might look like, and vague threats against the judiciary, the press, etc. The good news – doubling our vote in both constituencies of North Tyneside and Tynemouth (around 7%). The questions: will Johnson use his majority to ignore the hard right and make a sensible deal? will the Labour Party find a sensible leader and become an effective opposition? will the Lib Dems find a distinctive purpose under a new leader? will the state of Labour and Conservative parties lead to yet more gains for Lib Dems in local elections?

August 10th: Riots and crime for over a week, with hundreds of arrests, including some for on-line posts. There’s always been rumours, and wild statements made to mates in the pub, but social media spreads those like wild-fire, and it’s impossible to retract a rumour. Some Conservative politicians and commentators, and some from Labour too, have tried to argue that the riots were protests about ‘legitimate concerns’, and even tried to draw parallels with the pro-Gaza and climate protests, but those were predominantly peaceful and even the more extreme elements kept to verbal attacks in almost all cases. These were riots, led by thugs, and incited by some who want chaos and hate democracy.
However, it’s also clear that poverty, poor or non-existent housing, long waiting lists, etc. have given many people a feeling of being ignored and neglected, and that probably contributed to the larger numbers giving tacit encouragement to those with a violent agenda. Again, those grievances have been amplified by some who have contributed to the problems now being articulated, ironically under a new Labour government that’s far more likely to address these.
I’m not a paid-up Starmer supporter, but it’s absurd to label him a failure after a month of the new regime. Yes, he’s already made some mistakes, but he’s clearly more honest, more competent, more serious than his several predecessors, and it’s only fair to suspend judgement until he’d had a few months to demonstrate what his priorities really are. What is clear though is that people will want to see at least signs of progress on housing, waiting lists and some other costs before too long, and such signs will also help tackle the scapegoating of migrants.

November 29th: After the news on November 6th, I was so upset that I decided to sign out of Twitter for a few days, and also look at much less news. Definitely a good idea. Now back in the thick of it.
There’s always things to be done, and each might help a little, in the faith that many others will also do their bit. - Have a good bike, and maybe a maintenance deal for it?
- Safe bike storage

April 8th: Troubles in Belfast – very disturbing. Our PM took about four days to comment, and another minister says it’s a local issue. No, it’s a consequence of both bad (though not hasty) and hasty decisions taken in, or jointly with, London. The Brexit vote created a problem of how to keep Northern Ireland integrated in the UK, and seamlessly interacting with the Republic. Once Theresa may had announced, suddenly and unexpectedly, that Brexit was to be interpreted as leaving both Single Market and Customs Union, there had to be border checks somewhere. Johnson, damning the concept whilst creating a border in the Irish Sea, was doing much worse than kicking this down the road, he was simultaneously avoiding a crucial issue whilst raising expectations. Shortages, economic difficulties, and then inconsistent application of Covid regulations has raised the temperature.
Though it must be said, the DUP position is worse still than Johnson’s, opposing the Good Friday Agreement, favouring Brexit, whilst claiming that they don’t want any border issues with the Republic. And May’s £1Billion bribe for them to cooperate wasn’t enough to satisfy them. What a mess!

April 22nd: When politics comes up in conversation, it usually focusses on one or two principal events or policies, that someone either likes or dislikes, or on politicians – commonly ‘they’re all the same’ or ‘they’re only in it for themselves’. It’s much less common to hear people’s comments on what a politician, or a council or a government is able to do. Comments are also expressed in black/white terms (‘the railways are bad’ or ‘our money is wasted’) when what’s probably meant is more about how bad, or how much (‘my train has been late three times this week’ or ‘that was a waste of money’).
It’s worth considering what Politics is actually concerned with. Here’s some questions we can ask:
– What is best done collectively, and what individually?
– What is best done by the state, and what by private companies?
– What’s the right balance between regulation for the general good and individual and corporate freedom?
– What’s best done locally, regionally, nationally or internationally?
– What is the right balance of short-term and long-term needs?
– What’s the balance: high gain and high risk, vs. lower gain and risk?
These aren’t the only questions, but they do cover much of the political ground.
I think most people would recognise these as valid questions, and almost no-one would adopt either extreme for each example, except possibly the second question for some ideologues of the Left or the Right. A typical Conservative voter would probably say ‘more to the right’ for the first three questions, and a typical Labour voter would probably say ‘more to the left’ for all three. A typical Liberal Democrat position would probably be fairly central on the first two questions, slightly to the right on the regulation/freedom axis, but with a strong emphasis on the fourth question – making decisions at the right level.
Another aspect of government is that, in my view, there is no perfect and stable state to be achieved. At any time, one can only say ‘the balance is wrong’, and try to shift it. That’s because we are a complex society with many individual views and needs, and external factors too. Even in small organisations, there will be periods when collective action and benefit seems the right priority, and other periods when individual benefits and freedoms need to be addressed.

September 22nd: The Labour Party seem to specialise in internal conflict, which right now must be delighting the Conservatives and distracting from their mismanagement of practically everything! This week the highlight is on Starmer’s proposals to re-introduce an Electoral College for the election of the party leader, viz. a weighted combination of MPs, unions and members. This has immediately raised hackles and cries of ‘undemocratic!’. However, there are other approaches.
All the main parties require a candidate for leader to have the endorsement of a proportion of the party’s MPs, but no MP may endorse more than one candidate. All who are eligible and gain this level of support can be voted on by the membership. The MPs’ endorsement is clearly to show that they are judged both suitable for the role (which is much more than values and speech-making, but includes team-building, administration and effective decision-making), but this has not been properly exercised recently in both Conservative and Labour parties, who put Johnson and Corbyn on their ballots and gave the country an invidious choice in 2019!
However, a simple change could improve this, though still requiring MPs to judge sensibly, of course. A candidate for Leader could need the endorsement of many more MPs, perhaps one third of the Parliamentary Party, demonstrating that they were judged competent and able to work with their colleagues. But an MP could endorse more than one candidate, as they would be saying only that they could work with that person, not necessarily that this was their first choice. Thus, provided MPs considered this carefully, the shortlist would all be people who could do the job. The membership would then vote on who they believed would give the strongest leadership to the country in vision and values.
I know that I’m not well-placed to judge how well an MP would fulfil a leader’s role, and that’s surely true for almost everyone outside Parliament. After all, everyone who’s ever worked with Boris Johnson has said how unsuitable he was for the role he ended up in!

May 19th: A friend (expert on Hungary) wrote in ‘Unherd’ that statements comparing the UK to Hungary are facile – see https://unherd.com/thepost/tory-britain-is-not-the-new-hungary/ and went on to say that amongst MPs on the All Party Parliamentary Group on Hungary, only a few (Conservative) members have taken a real interest in Hungary in recent years.
I responded by saying it’s tedious how many people (esp. on Twitter) keep saying that the UK is ‘a police state’, ‘a third-world country’, ‘the worst country’, ‘totally corrupt’, or ‘these are exactly the steps that the Nazis took’, etc.
However, looking at worse countries helps to understand why some trends should not be trivialised. The Good Law Project https://goodlawproject.org/ is gradually succeeding in uncovering procurement deals, despite the Gov’t trying to bully their way out of this (by inflating costs), but yesterday the High Court judged that the Gov’t is not obliged to provide data on value for money, or how much PPE (probably illegally procured) was unfit for purpose.
I try to understand why apparently intelligent and previously sensible cabinet members behave the way they do. In 2020 I think they were in a state of blind panic, and tended to trust their personal contacts more than civil service listed ones. In addition, they must by now know that Brexit has massive disadvantages, but probably believe that admitting that would tank the economy more than denying it. Thus it’s not just about political advantage, but a perceived need to ‘fly the flag’ in a similar way to wartime propaganda. However, there is an underlying tendency in most people to trust people like themselves, and (in the case of Tories) to believe that the private sector will normally be better value than the public sector, rather than taking a case-by-case approach as they should.
Maybe I’m too ‘understanding’, but I apply this to lots of cases, currently to why Biden isn’t condemning the Israeli government’s actions, which are intolerable!

March 21st: I’ve read some novels about things like ‘after the nuclear holocaust’, plagues, etc, and Wyndham’s stories such as Day of the Triffids and The Chrysalids, and seen films too, such as ‘Children of Men’ (in which children are no longer born for some unknown reason). They were interesting, intriguing, slightly scary. I grew up and became an adult at a time when nuclear war seemed a possibility (though it’s not gone away entirely). One question that was addressed by all of them was how people might behave when scared, stressed, hungry. They usually told of a mixture of noble, communal, self-sacrificing behaviour, and selfish, wild, panicky behaviour. I think we see aspects of this already in this extraordinary crisis.
I’m an optimist, not always predicting good outcomes, but always believing that good things can happen. Right now, I know there will be many tragedies, many deaths, much unemployment, but still hope that society will prevail, health and well-being restored, the very worst avoided. Might the UK run short of food, even if we’re well-organised in time, if other countries restricted exports because of their own problems? I doubt we’ll get any severe shortage, but we are likely to see local problems, and less choice. I wonder how much we can cut down on food waste, which we’re told is 30% overall. Maybe the law should relax to allow shops to sell goods a little past their dates, but we must also accept more vegetables in imperfect condition, boxes and tins with dents, and throw away very little in our own houses.
I hope selfishness and panic will very soon be replaced by care, organisation, patience, and that we might see the best in people predominating. My optimism says we will, but my realism also says that there will be problems, profiteering, and lots of worry. I also hope that we might recognise better what’s really important, and that unlimited travel has its drawbacks. Maybe also the greater collective efforts and interventionist government could help us tackle the climate emergency?

May 4th: We may be ‘past the peak’ of the pandemic, but owing to a slow start, late lockdown, and too much travel, the UK is still suffering. The PM appears to be more cautious than before but is still much the same character, and an inept Cabinet still sees honest admission of problems as weakness.
The lockdown will be eased soon to some extent, and it seems certain that public transport will be especially difficult. More working at home and staggered start times will help, but it can’t be economic without many people close together. Would masks help? Here’s my summary of the issue:
- The public will be using simple masks, not medical grade.
- These screen out only some droplets, not all.
- Removing them can transfer the virus.
- They’ll need frequent washing.
- They might make people complacent.
- Hand washing and distancing needed too!

April 20th: Our Prime Minister stirs like the Kraken. Is it to fly into Belfast and try to reduce tension and find a way forward (out of the mess he created, of course)? No! Is it to deal with the inconsistency the police have reported between Government laws and Government guidelines on Covid? No! Is it to quarantine every arrival from India, rather than wait until the (as always, announced) deadline on Friday? No! Or about the growing miasma of sleaze, corruption and cronyism around government contracts with unqualified companies they happen to play golf with? Certainly not!
It’s about football, something he admits (in a rare bout of honesty) that he doesn’t support or even watch. This sport, which Bill Shankly famously described as ‘not a matter of life and death, it’s more important than that’, dominates the news. Leading politicians denounce ‘greed’ (unlike that of Cabinet ministers and their mates, of course). Of course it’s important to discuss something that is so popular, but is it really the Government’s business, if at all, and particularly when there’s so much else that they should be sorting out?
I’m pleased to hear of the imminent commitment by the UK Government (and the US Government too) to stringent targets for greenhouse gas reductions, and heartened to read of specific initiatives in the UK and elsewhere, but targets aren’t good enough, and announcing an announcement, plus the football kerfuffle, does look like an attempt to distract from the ‘cronyism’ and NI border rows.

Tuesday 3rd December: The Northern Echo has asked candidates in the NE to answer five questions about our priorities for our constituencies. I’ve been busy attempting to answer around 200 individual emails from electors (I’m about 2/3 through so far), so only today managed to respond, as follows:
Answers to questions from Northern Echo:
- What are three key local issues facing your constituency, and how would you address them? The first is the probable consequences of Brexit in any form, which is predicted to hit the North-East hardest (11% drop in economy relative to where we should be). This will require Government investment – see my answer to qu 5 below. There is potential in this region for major work on environmental improvements in the offshore industry – wind power in particular. This would be part of an overall push towards a greener economy. The Liberal Democrat manifesto urges a £100bn investment in environmental measures; a good chunk of that needs to come to areas like the North East.
- This question doesn’t rule out national issues, in my view, where they’ll have a local effect. Therefore, my second priority is Health and Social Care, which is in crisis. It needed sorting anyway, but substantial cuts in central government grants to local authorities have made it harder and harder to deal with. Both major parties have failed on this, partly because they keep trying to gain political advantage and so won’t agree on a plan. Thirdly, although schools are quite good in North Tyneside, overall participation in Higher Education is low in the North-East, and Further Education is also badly-funded. Therefore more support for FE, making apprenticeships easier to set up, and encouragement to aim higher still, are all needed. Better FE and apprenticeships could also help the rural parts of this area. Environmental education is already being encouraged somewhat by the North of Tyne authority, but there is so much more to do.
- Leave, remain or second referendum – what is your stance on Brexit, and why? Remain. The EU has brought peace to Europe, increased trade, increased opportunities for travel and employment, given us greater influence internationally with giants like the US and China, and also gives the best hope of concerted action on the Environment. But the EU does need reform.
- Should people be prepared to pay additional tax to fund improvements in public services, like the NHS? Yes, extra tax is needed to pay for better services. Of the major parties, only the Liberal Democrats are honest in saying this, and our manifesto has been commended by the Institute for Financial Studies for its realism and honesty about this. Conservatives pretend that improvements can be funded with no tax rises (and despite tax cuts), whilst Labour claim it can all be funded by the rich – seriously doubted by IFS.
- High streets are struggling – what would you do to rescue them? This combines with other Environmental and Health issues. We need to encourage more walking and cycling for both reasons, and better provision of, and use of, public transport. June 23rd: Leadership outsider Wera Hobhouse says we need a pact with Labour to defeat the Conservatives at the next General Election. Layla Moran champions a range of policies generally seen as ‘centre-left’. But, as in 1997, we need to gain votes in current Conservative seats more than in current Labour ones, and we need to win over some people who vote Conservative when they are sufficiently scared of a Labour government, like last time!
But politics isn’t just a straight line from Left to Right, with us in the middle. A simple, more realistic and useful, model is a triangle, where we are the third corner. We can be a little closer to one or the other of the two big parties, but we aren’t some kind of average or compromise between them. We are, and should be, distinctive in several policy areas.
Maybe the most obvious area of difference is that we are fundamentally in favour of localism – devolving decision-making to the lowest possible level – component country, region, district, neighbourhood, family, individual. We also favour better governance, and some kind of proportional voting system is needed (though Italy and Israel show that it doesn’t necessarily produce stable and/or good government). However, PR is not a vote-winner in itself, so here’s some suggestions for improved governance that are likely to attract support from Labour MPs and some of the public possibly too. That is, of course, in addition to radical policies on the Environment, where Ed Davey’s experience is very valuable!
Governance policy suggestions: Automatic voter registration, publication of all gov’t reports within 30 days, Select Committees established within 2 months, Parliament not to be suspended beyond 30 days without 2/3 vote in favour, civil servants must attend Select Committees, no public appointments for anyone in contempt of Parliament, proxy or remote voting to replace ‘pairing’, more legal powers for the Electoral Commission, no political donations from anyone within first 2 years of citizenship, and when actually voting, including an ‘abstention’ or ‘none of the above’ box on the ballot paper.
I think left/right is very unhelpful and most people don’t really know what it means. Many people I know hold seemingly left and right wing views simultaneously.
LikeLike
I agree, but many voters do say “there’s no difference between ……” and we want clear differences from both. The Coalition agreement had lots of good stuff in it, but the only things memorably associated with the LD were negative!

April 12th: Last Thursday was the closing date for nominations for local council elections, police & crime commissioner elections, and regional mayors. Today I received formal notice of acceptance of my own nominations for Elected Mayor of North Tyneside and for a local ward. What do we all expect to happen? Two years ago, with the Brexit arguments still raging, the Conservatives lost over a thousand local seats, and Labour lost too. The Liberal Democrats gained over 700 local councillors – in recognition of our pro-Europe stance, perhaps, but probably mostly a return to our local presence after a beating!
This May, the elections, in greater numbers because of last year’s cancellations, will be seen partly as a measure of our Government’s popularity. Most people who comment on the Gov’t think they are incompetent, dishonest and corrupt, but right now the success of the vaccination programme gives them a ‘bounce’, an impression that things are under control. Of course we now look better relative to other countries than we did, but we still have a higher overall death rate and a bigger economic hit than most countries, and the full impact of our self-imposed trade barriers is yet to be felt. And then there’s Northern Ireland. It’s now becoming very clear that Cameron’s shallow thinking led to an ill-judged and unprepared referendum, with immense consequences. May’s determination to assert her authority as a reformed Remainer reinforced the mistakes, and Johnson’s ambition and lack of realism bolted us into a scheme that is clearly unworkable.
I think the Government is so trapped by its own mistakes that they really have only two options left: they can continue to lie and bluff, or they can resign. The imminent elections won’t prove much at all, but sooner or later people are likely to blame the Gov’t for not solving the problems, even if they continue to blame the EU (wrongly) for causing them.

June 19th: A day to remember – the House of Commons debating the Privileges Committee report into Boris Johnson’s deliberate misleading of the House, and his subsequent rubbishing of the process and the individuals bravely producing the report. A bad day – that it was necessary, and that many Conservative MPs stayed away (very few opposed the report). A good day – that the HoC could be honest about the shenanigans of Johnson’s regime and his personal unsuitability to be Prime Minister.
And, this week, a ‘stolen’ video displaying the carelessness and contempt for the public and for shared mores as Shaun Bailey’s Mayoral team at CCHQ partied on the same day we were instructed to return to social restrictions.
Honesty in politicians means avoiding deliberate untruths or grossly misleading statements, as a minimum, but also means not promising things that there is no realistic chance of delivering. One shortlisted candidate for the expanded North-East Mayor says they’ll ‘eliminate child poverty’ – a laudable but impossible aim. They should really say ‘reducing child poverty is my principal aim’ and perhaps ‘we should be able to eliminate child poverty, and I’ll do my best to reduce it substantially in my five year term’.
It’s generally understood that Cameron promised a referendum that he thought he’d be forced to drop in a hung parliament, that Clegg promised no student fee increase as he didn’t expect to be in power, and that Johnson urged a Brexit that he didn’t believe in. Only the last was a complete falsehood, but the others were rash at least, and came back to haunt us all.

March 19th: A very good meeting with representatives of the Federation of Small Businesses (FSB). Issues that particularly concern these often quite small companies include cash-flow, owing to late payment by larger organisations, and the difficulties of competing in procurement for public works. I was amazed to discover that there are 100,000 sole-trader/self-employed businesses in the North-East, generating around £4 billion in economic activity. They are also interested in how to contribute to a carbon-neutral economy, and in improving skills training for staff.

March 28th: Our UK Gov’t has been much criticised. My interpretation is this. They believed (probably rightly) that nearly everyone would catch the virus before immunity and/or vaccine took effect. Therefore, it was pointless to try to delay the inevitable, including amongst medical staff, as economic harm would be bad and would also cause deaths. Moreover, the vast majority of deaths would be amongst the elderly, and would be those quite likely to die within the year (noting that the normal death rate in the UK is about 50,000 per month – rarely mentioned).
What this also assumes, I think, is that people simply divide into those that die and those that don’t. What it leaves out is four things. Firstly, a significant minority of those who die might be saved with sufficient care, hence staffing and ventilators etc are needed. Secondly, a delay in the peak gives more time to develop treatments. Thirdly, it’s been said that a higher ‘load’ of the virus not only increases the chance of catching it, but also the severity of the illness – this is pertinent to medical staff and why PPE is important. Lastly, good treatment might make death less painful even where it’s inevitable. It’s also possible that, if many can avoid it altogether this year, a vaccine might save them in a second wave.
There’s also been accusations of ideology, callousness, etc. I’m doubtful about those. I imagine both many cock-ups as a complex situation develops, and a genuine philosophical difficulty for those (like Johnson) who believe people do best with less regulation and then must adjust to imposing rules. There’s also a balance to be struck between doing the right thing logically, and being seen to do something. Johnson’s latest approval ratings suggest that he’s succeeded with that, at least!

May 22nd: Presumably our Prime Minister concluded that nothing was going to get better, and some things might get much worse, but why did he announce the General Election whilst standing in the rain?
Six weeks to Election Day, then we’ll have a new Government and at the very least the end of stupid and performative policies that make no sense at all. I wish Keir Starmer and a Labour administration well, but would prefer a Lib Dem part of decision-making. More MPs will help raise our profile both nationally and locally, and in Parliamentary committees etc.
Labour won’t have PR on its priority list, but it’s to be hoped that Starmer won’t block it developing over time. An easy start would be to reinstate the Supplementary Vote system for Mayors and PCCs, as well as making Voter ID easy for everyone (if it’s retained) – include young people’s bus passes, veterans’ ID, police warrant cards, or why not ‘polling card + one other form of ID’ as for parcels?
I’ll be the LIb Dem candidate for Tynemouth – with boundaries little changed from last time. However, the rest of North Tyneside borough will split to join three other constituencies: Newcastle East, Newcastle North, and Cramlington & Killingworth.

Weds 20th: The Liberal Democrat Manifesto has been published today – see: http://www.libdems.org.uk/plan . This is an ambitious set of policies that are all possible – fully costed and not a spending spree like the Conservatives. They used to be the party of financial prudence, but seem to have fallen for the ‘magic money tree’ concept they previously ridiculed. In any case, it’s hard to believe anything said by this Prime Minister, who was twice sacked for lying in his newspaper articles. His most important lie just now is that it was Parliament who blocked Brexit and forced the General Election. In fact, it was firstly the ERG and DUP (and Johnson himself) not accepting Theresa May’s proposals (bad, but better than his own), and then Johnson not allowing Parliament time to scrutinise the amended proposals.
On reflection, the policies I proposed on this site when standing for Mayor of the ‘North of Tyne’ still largely apply to what’s needed in this region, but I’m very happy to embrace those in the national manifesto. Those include (apart from stopping Brexit!): ambitious plans to address the Climate Emergency, help schools and childcare, address the social care crisis, and invest in infrastructure including in the North. See also the BBC commentary, around 1pm today, from:
“The Liberal Democrat manifesto is out. I’ve read it! This thread gives a northern take on it, so I’ve picked the bits that I think have the most regional relevance. Overall there is an emphasis on increased regional investment, and more powers and resources for councils…” and follow the whole thread.
Teamwork in Berwick
Sun 17th: North Tyneside members set off for Lynemouth and Linton in Northumberland, not far from Ashington, to deliver leaflets on behalf of Tom Hancock and our Berwick constituency team. Berwick was held by Alan Beith (now Lord Beith) for forty years and he is fondly remembered there, but we lost the seat in 2015 as the Party was punished for (mostly) the austerity imposed by the Conservative government. With an arch-Brexiteer Tory MP there, we’re attracting lots of support from those who understand just how bad Brexit would be for this rural constituency, as well as the rest of the North-East.
A local candidate
Friday 15th: I live in Whitley Bay, and I’ve lived in North Tyneside for eleven of the last thirteen years. The Labour MP and the Conservative candidate for Tynemouth also live in this constituency, and the Green candidate lives not far away and is locally active. But the Brexit candidate gives a home address in Australia! Does he have any interest at all in this area (he claims to have visited Tynemouth once)? It seems all of a pattern with another Brexit member, one of our MEPs, who lives in the South of France. They claim to care about Britain, but really! NB This featured on Tyne Tees news the same night!
The Race is on!
November 15th: Phew! My nomination papers were formally accepted yesterday, so I’m officially the Liberal Democrat candidate for Tynemouth constituency (for the third time, also standing here in 2010 and 2017). It’s always a bit tense, getting ten local people to sign (to say I’m honest and suitable) and many more bits of paper that must conform to the legal requirements. Not to mention the £500 deposit that we get back if we get over 5% of the vote. On recent polls, I’m very hopeful of much better than that! Climate Emergency?
April 24th: Feeling tired today after four fixtures yesterday – BBC Radio, BBC TV, Chronicle/Journal hustings, then a hustings in Alnwick. The evening fixture was organised by Friends of the Earth and was focussed on the Environment – a subject I’ve featured and emphasised whenever I can in this campaign.
Some good questions included our support for declaring a Climate Emergency in line with the street protests and the amazing Greta Thunberg. I supported this call, as it’s such a massive issue and we should be grateful to young people in particular for insisting action is taken now. But I said, to audience agreement, that declarations aren’t much use unless we all take action, including examining our own lifestyles and sacrifices we might need to make. I already do what I can (I don’t own a car, buy second-hand and rarely fly) but maybe there’s more? Perhaps I could aim to eat only seasonal food to avoid heating, cooling and transport costs?
Another important issue raised was Biodiversity – important for the richness of our environment, for insect pollination, and for sources for new drugs.

Manifestly sensible!

January 5th, 2022: (There, I’ve got the year right!) Omicron cases rising steeply, whilst hospitalisations and deaths rise more slowly. The Government decides to do little and ‘ride it out’. Brave or foolhardy? Considerate to business and society, or careless about prolonging the crisis? Figures for France and Germany show that the UK approach isn’t necessarily bad – their death rates are higher than ours, though they did better in the second wave in 2020/21. However, they do have more bed capacity than we do, and more health staff, so they might have less risk of overwhelmed hospitals and ambulances.
Staff shortages are perhaps the biggest problem, in health, social care and elsewhere, owing to both actual Covid-19 infection and isolation because of contact. The Government appears to pay little heed to this, maybe because it would also highlight the major shortages caused by Brexit.
That Omicron seems to lead to less serious illness and death is a relief, but a smaller proportion of a larger case-load is still a major burden. We have to hope that high vaccination rates and milder variants will allow some greater relaxation by the summer. Meanwhile, apart from the actual policies, we have a Government that appears careless, dismissive, arrogant and incompetent. Let’s hope that we get a new Prime Minister soon who can actually do the job, not merely be popular with Conservative members!

January 13th: I was gripped by Prime Minister’s Questions yesterday! As many said, Keir Starmer was aiming at an open goal, and scored repeatedly. Few Conservatives supported the PM at all; just a few asked boilerplate, irrelevant questions to try to take the heat off their ‘winning’ leader.
In 2019, many Conservative MPs, most Conservative members, and then sufficient voters, thought that Johnson, for all his known faults, would do a good enough job as PM, getting the country out of the endless, boring, Brexit debate (some Remainers thought this too), and there would be enough checks and balances to keep him from doing too much harm. As with Trump in the US, that was hopelessly optimistic. Brexit is an ongoing open sore, and Johnson gets worse, not better.
Before all the stuff about parties, and wallpaper, and dodgy dealings of all kinds, I often said that my chief regrets about the past six years were the lying, the disregard of courtesy and convention, the undermining or actual attacks on our highly-prized institutions (Rule of Law, human rights, the BBC, universities, animal welfare, the Civil Service, honesty in treaties and diplomacy, democracy, …….), and the shredding of our international reputation. These bothered me more than loss of freedom of movement or economic harm, important though those were.
Is Johnson finished? I don’t know – in the next week or so many Conservative MPs will find out if their constituents get more and more angry, or simmer down. What that party (or the Conservative Work-Event, as I call it now!) won’t want is a leadership election during March and April, with local elections coming up. They’ll either act very soon, or wait until the Summer.
If the former, then it’s likely Sunak will be the next PM. Apart from confidence and presentation, we know nothing about his abilities, and his experience is of privilege. He’d at least be able to stay in the same flat at number 10 if he wanted! But there are other Conservatives with more experience who’d stand more chance of tackling the crises of the pandemic, the economy, cost-of-living, etc.

Sunday 8th: This morning I went to St Andrew’s URC Church in Benton, at their invitation, to talk about the Cedarwood Trust in North Shields, of which I am now the Chair. Cedarwood has existed since 1980, set up by the Church of England Urban Fund, North Tyneside Council, and others, to support the people of this most deprived area – in respect of children in ‘income-deprived homes‘, the area is in the lowest 0.5% of the UK.
The church members had contributed an impressive pile of toys and gifts to be given to children. I said that the children that Cedarwood relates to were ‘just the same as your own children, but with less money and fewer opportunities.’

April 11th: Rishi Sunak impressed the public with his charm, confidence and ‘generosity’ with public spending. Many (including him!) thought he might be the next Prime Minister, but I always wondered – we knew nothing of any vision for the UK, ability in managing the executive decision-making or skill in building and managing a team. We did know that he’d been a hedge-fund manager, good at making money from insubstantial investments and manipulation of markets. In the past few weeks, his fall from grace has been spectacular – a budget that failed to address the cost-of-living crisis, apparent opposition to sensible energy/climate plans, and then his wife’s non-dom status for her fantastic wealth. Then, on top of all that. questions about his US and UK status.
On Thursday I was visiting Richmond in North Yorkshire, his constituency, and was by chance interviewed by an ITV team seeking the views of local residents. They featured my views at some length: https://twitter.com/ITVNewsPolitics/status/1512098733554610187 Some of the comments following the clip are hilarious! I was quite honest with them about who I was but they evidently thought the clip worth keeping. The whole tweet was re-tweeted by Wes Streeting (Shadow Cabinet), so it had lots of views!

April 23rd: Walking across Castle Leazes to the BBC Newcastle studios for an interview on ‘Alfie and Anna at Breakfast’ (8.20am, on BBC Sounds), I saw that the cows were back for the summer. I used to see them every day from April to October when I lived in Fenham and walked to Newcastle University each day.
John’s blog on current issues
New life at Easter
April 21st – Easter Sunday: Greeting the dawn at 5.45am on the sea-front at Whitley Bay with forty people from local churches. A wonderful, beautiful clear morning with hope for new life. Good words on the radio too about how new energy and hope can rise from disaster, such as the fire at Notre Dame, and how similar that story is to the fire at Brancepeth Church in County Durham in 1997. Both seemed to resonate with people of faith and none – a sense of shared history and mystery about these ancient buildings.
Centre for Cities hustings
April 18th: At a hustings organised by the Centre for Cities and the NE Chamber of Commerce, where all five candidates answered questions on the economy, transport, etc. Some good questions: ‘Why would an entrepreneur choose Newcastle?’, ‘How do we make the local economy more inclusive?’ (this meant including those from different socio-economic backgrounds), ‘What would you do for business in Newcastle City Centre?’.
The whole 90 minute session was filmed by Hexham TV (a web-based community station – also see March 6th) and can be seen at: https://m.facebook.com/watch/?v=2439405909629159&_rdr
(Also note that my interview with Sustrans is available as three items on my Twitter posts.)
Look at the interviewer, not the camera
April 18th: A busy day yesterday, starting with filming by ITV on Blyth dockside for the evening programmes on Thursday 25th. It felt like one of those adverts, sitting at a table in the open air with cranes, goods and the sea behind. Seven questions about me, my aims and policy, and my local knowledge (and I got the local celebrity right!).
Later that morning, an important session with ‘Becoming Visible’ – working with deaf people on materials, education and advice for employment. They filmed me answering questions and will add sign language later so that the deaf community can get information accessibly. We discussed difficulties of funding, of delayed education, and the need for employers to see disabled people as an underused resource rather than a problem to be solved.
My Sustrans interview (see previous blog item) was then followed by a personal profile by an Evening Chronicle reporter. I declined to say who my second vote would be cast for, and explained that I was offering myself and my experience for a job that needs to be done well – this is not a personal ambition – and that linked to my personal faith.
Getting around
April 17th: Meetings concerning transport and logistics in the area, with Directors of the North East Joint Transport Committee, the CEO of the Port of Tyne Authority, and senior staff of Sustrans, the cycling organisation.
Transport is a crucial aspect of the functioning and prosperity of the North of Tyne area and the whole region, but unlike the other ‘Metro Mayors’, our new Mayor won’t have direct control owing to the overlapping responsibilities of the various authorities.
I heard lots about strategic plans, the need for Government as well as regional investment, and challenged them on how new environmental targets would affect their plans. Sustrans will advise on more than cycling; they’ll help find solutions for Active Living in cities, including public transport, walking and cycling.
Newcastle Airport is run separately, and well, but a low carbon strategy for the area can’t simply assume growth in all aspects of transport. David Attenborough, and the recent ‘Extinction Rebellion’ protests are highlighting this, and this letter was in yesterday’s Metro – the public are taking this seriously now!
A short break
April 10th: I love the British countryside, and the North of Tyne area has a lot of it (some of that actually South of the Tyne!). Although this break was in the Lake District, both areas share beauty, many small communities, and many, many sheep! Returning over the Pennines via Alston, I noticed the border from Cumbria back into Northumberland with new eyes!
Flights of fancy
4th March: A useful discussion with the Chief Executive and Planning & Corporate Affairs Director of Newcastle Airport about their plans for visitors, tourism, business, and the challenges of balancing prosperity for the region with the growing environmental threat. Today they’re releasing a new website for tourism across the North-East on behalf of their seven local authority partners and other agencies: http://visitnortheastengland.com/
After that, an interview and photo-shoot, plus short video, with NETimes – a digital magazine for business in the North-East. https://netimesmagazine.co.uk/times-live/the-future-of-the-north-of-tyne/ /
Open for Business
3rd March: A demanding two hours on the platform at a Business Hustings organised by the CBI, NE Chamber of Commerce, Federation of Small Businesses, Entrepreneurs Forum for all four declared candidates (nb. a fifth declared that afternoon). We had a chance to set out our vision and approach, our values, and specific policies for business, including human issues of equality, poverty, education, etc. Lots of questions from the floor and submitted electronically. Around 150 people there, including media, with good write-ups in the Journal at https://www.chroniclelive.co.uk/business/business-news/north-tyne-mayor-should-buy-16072217?utm_source=sharebar&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=sharebar and by the Knowledge Development Manager of NE Chamberon on Twitter: @NEEChamberArlen . Also see @CBINorth for this video clip summarising my approach to Business.
Environment and Rural Affairs
April 1st: Lots of good humour, but mostly serious stuff! At an excellent seminar led by Lord Donald Curry, Northumberland farmer and House of Lords cross-bencher, a key voice in the drafting of the Agriculture bill – possibly the most significant changes to support structures and funding since 1947. As Brexit has delayed progress, there is an unforeseen benefit that we were not too late to contribute ideas and priorities to the process, and he welcomed this. We talked also about the sustainability of rural communities, where often the local church is the only remaining public building and focus for communal life.
Giving people a voice
March 27th: I spent an hour with representatives of Tyne & Wear Citizens – involving people in social and political change who have felt ignored in the past. Good to hear their stories about why they’re involved, and telling mine too (early days of the People’s Kitchen, living on an estate). Would I, as Mayor, support their campaigns on the Living Wage, Mental Health, Islamophobia, Free School Meals funds? Yes, I would, but we discussed some practical implications, how much influence the Mayor might have, and questions of how quickly things could move.
On April 30th all the candidates will face similar questions in front of an Assembly of 1,200 – wow!

Good words on the radio too about how new energy and hope can rise from disaster, such as the fire at Notre Dame, and how similar that story is to the fire at Brancepeth Church in County Durham in 1997. Both seemed to resonate with people of faith and none – a sense of shared history and mystery about these ancient buildings.
Centre for Cities hustings
April 18th: At a hustings organised by the Centre for Cities and the NE Chamber of Commerce, where all five candidates answered questions on the economy, transport, etc. Some good questions: ‘Why would an entrepreneur choose Newcastle?’, ‘How do we make the local economy more inclusive?’ (this meant including those from different socio-economic backgrounds), ‘What would you do for business in Newcastle City Centre?’.
The whole 90 minute session was filmed by Hexham TV (a web-based community station – also see March 6th) and can be seen at: https://m.facebook.com/watch/?v=2439405909629159&_rdr
(Also note that my interview with Sustrans is available as three items on my Twitter posts.)
Look at the interviewer, not the camera
April 18th: A busy day yesterday, starting with filming by ITV on Blyth dockside for the evening programmes on Thursday 25th. It felt like one of those adverts, sitting at a table in the open air with cranes, goods and the sea behind. Seven questions about me, my aims and policy, and my local knowledge (and I got the local celebrity right!).
Later that morning, an important session with ‘Becoming Visible’ – working with deaf people on materials, education and advice for employment. They filmed me answering questions and will add sign language later so that the deaf community can get information accessibly. We discussed difficulties of funding, of delayed education, and the need for employers to see disabled people as an underused resource rather than a problem to be solved.
My Sustrans interview (see previous blog item) was then followed by a personal profile by an Evening Chronicle reporter. I declined to say who my second vote would be cast for, and explained that I was offering myself and my experience for a job that needs to be done well – this is not a personal ambition – and that linked to my personal faith.
Getting around
April 17th: Meetings concerning transport and logistics in the area, with Directors of the North East Joint Transport Committee, the CEO of the Port of Tyne Authority, and senior staff of Sustrans, the cycling organisation.
Transport is a crucial aspect of the functioning and prosperity of the North of Tyne area and the whole region, but unlike the other ‘Metro Mayors’, our new Mayor won’t have direct control owing to the overlapping responsibilities of the various authorities.
I heard lots about strategic plans, the need for Government as well as regional investment, and challenged them on how new environmental targets would affect their plans. Sustrans will advise on more than cycling; they’ll help find solutions for Active Living in cities, including public transport, walking and cycling.
Newcastle Airport is run separately, and well, but a low carbon strategy for the area can’t simply assume growth in all aspects of transport. David Attenborough, and the recent ‘Extinction Rebellion’ protests are highlighting this, and this letter was in yesterday’s Metro – the public are taking this seriously now!
A short break
April 10th: I love the British countryside, and the North of Tyne area has a lot of it (some of that actually South of the Tyne!). Although this break was in the Lake District, both areas share beauty, many small communities, and many, many sheep! Returning over the Pennines via Alston, I noticed the border from Cumbria back into Northumberland with new eyes!
Flights of fancy
4th March: A useful discussion with the Chief Executive and Planning & Corporate Affairs Director of Newcastle Airport about their plans for visitors, tourism, business, and the challenges of balancing prosperity for the region with the growing environmental threat. Today they’re releasing a new website for tourism across the North-East on behalf of their seven local authority partners and other agencies: http://visitnortheastengland.com/
After that, an interview and photo-shoot, plus short video, with NETimes – a digital magazine for business in the North-East. https://netimesmagazine.co.uk/times-live/the-future-of-the-north-of-tyne/ /
Open for Business
3rd March: A demanding two hours on the platform at a Business Hustings organised by the CBI, NE Chamber of Commerce, Federation of Small Businesses, Entrepreneurs Forum for all four declared candidates (nb. a fifth declared that afternoon). We had a chance to set out our vision and approach, our values, and specific policies for business, including human issues of equality, poverty, education, etc. Lots of questions from the floor and submitted electronically. Around 150 people there, including media, with good write-ups in the Journal at https://www.chroniclelive.co.uk/business/business-news/north-tyne-mayor-should-buy-16072217?utm_source=sharebar&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=sharebar and by the Knowledge Development Manager of NE Chamberon on Twitter: @NEEChamberArlen . Also see @CBINorth for this video clip summarising my approach to Business.
Environment and Rural Affairs
April 1st: Lots of good humour, but mostly serious stuff! At an excellent seminar led by Lord Donald Curry, Northumberland farmer and House of Lords cross-bencher, a key voice in the drafting of the Agriculture bill – possibly the most significant changes to support structures and funding since 1947. As Brexit has delayed progress, there is an unforeseen benefit that we were not too late to contribute ideas and priorities to the process, and he welcomed this. We talked also about the sustainability of rural communities, where often the local church is the only remaining public building and focus for communal life.
Giving people a voice
March 27th: I spent an hour with representatives of Tyne & Wear Citizens – involving people in social and political change who have felt ignored in the past. Good to hear their stories about why they’re involved, and telling mine too (early days of the People’s Kitchen, living on an estate). Would I, as Mayor, support their campaigns on the Living Wage, Mental Health, Islamophobia, Free School Meals funds? Yes, I would, but we discussed some practical implications, how much influence the Mayor might have, and questions of how quickly things could move.
On April 30th all the candidates will face similar questions in front of an Assembly of 1,200 – wow!

March 18th: The £37 billion to be spent on Test and Trace has been described as ‘winning the prize for the most wasteful and inept public spending programme of all time’ by a former Treasury Permanent Secretary. A review says that 27,000 deaths could have been avoided by earlier action in December. This week all Conservative MPs voted for the second reading of a bill that could be used to quell every protest, and trusting the police to use these powers well has been undermined by the heavy-handed treatment of the Sarah Everard vigil.
Much has been said about how Ministers who mislead the Commons would have resigned in the past – even Johnson himself has condemned lying to the House (but before he was a minister!). Bullying too, let alone gross incompetence. Is there anything that would lead the Prime Minister to sack a minister?
Populist governments usually confuse self-interest with the public-interest, not unrelated to the notion of ‘trickle-down economics’. I think almost all members of governments in the UK and many of our allies want to be respected, and pretend to themselves that they are doing what’s right for the country, even if they also enjoy the benefits of their own decisions. I suspect this Government has convinced itself, as Trump did, that popular opinion is, in effect, democracy, that if the people like it, it must be right.
However, this is to reduce democracy to the latest opinion poll, abandoning principle and shame.
Such people have the ‘Swing-o-Meter’ as their moral compass.

October 19th: Our new students have been registering over the past couple of weeks, and started formal teaching today. There’s been much talk of whether it’s fair to them or the community moving so many young people around the country just now, then restricting what they can do. But with no jobs, no gap-year opportunities, and reduced socialising, it’s not surprising that most wanted to ‘go to uni’ anyway. Until a few weeks ago, our plan was to teach mostly on-line, with limited personal contact, then that was stopped too (except for labs and similar).
It’s hard to get to know a group, or for them to know us, without being able to judge the body-language, and without (in my case) being able to stride round the room (large, 300+ students), using my movement, waving my arms, to demonstrate things to engineers but especially to engage and animate them. It’s hard too, to set the pace of study without the routine of lectures. Moreover, the lecturing staff have had to adapt to new technology, new approaches to learning, new ways of relating to and monitoring students. I’m not after sympathy here, but recognition that everyone’s new to this and there will be glitches (some already this morning!).
Some people have queried universities’ motives, but we have to pay our bills too, and the Government prefers not to bail us out! And we do care about our students and want to put on a good course for them and support them as they explore. There are some horror stories about hungry and stranded students, but the sudden rise in new cases is partly because of lots of new testing and is already dropping, and I’m proud that my university is doing good things to support those in lockdown (an immediate £50 food voucher, for example). I think our students will have a less exciting, but still worthwhile, time, provided our inept, arrogant and stubborn government allows testing and tracing to be run locally as they should have done in the first place!

April 20th: Our Prime Minister stirs like the Kraken. Is it to fly into Belfast and try to reduce tension and find a way forward (out of the mess he created, of course)? No! Is it to deal with the inconsistency the police have reported between Government laws and Government guidelines on Covid? No! Is it to quarantine every arrival from India, rather than wait until the (as always, announced) deadline on Friday? No! Or about the growing miasma of sleaze, corruption and cronyism around government contracts with unqualified companies they happen to play golf with? Certainly not!
It’s about football, something he admits (in a rare bout of honesty) that he doesn’t support or even watch. This sport, which Bill Shankly famously described as ‘not a matter of life and death, it’s more important than that’, dominates the news. Leading politicians denounce ‘greed’ (unlike that of Cabinet ministers and their mates, of course). Of course it’s important to discuss something that is so popular, but is it really the Government’s business, if at all, and particularly when there’s so much else that they should be sorting out?
I’m pleased to hear of the imminent commitment by the UK Government (and the US Government too) to stringent targets for greenhouse gas reductions, and heartened to read of specific initiatives in the UK and elsewhere, but targets aren’t good enough, and announcing an announcement, plus the football kerfuffle, does look like an attempt to distract from the ‘cronyism’ and NI border rows.

March 2nd: Our inept Prime Minister, shackled to an almost hysterical right-wing, and facing electoral oblivion, makes a public speech about extremism and ‘mob rule’. I’ve said before that the thing I have most hated about the Governments we’ve had since 2016 (i.e. Johnson, May, Truss, Sunak) is that they have created, encouraged, even stoked, division between people, between communities, between countries.
Surely one of the most important functions of leadership – true for managing a department or even being a parent, as well as in politics – is to reduce suspicion and hostility, to build trust, to try to bring people together in a common vision? Obviously simplistic nationalism isn’t what I mean (such as Modi’s BJP in India), but a common vision that everybody, if possible, can see the point of and feel that they or their children and friends might find good in wellbeing if not in material wealth.
