This evening, the House of Commons voted to remove ‘no-deal’ from any options for Brexit. Minutes later, the Government applied a three-line whip to its MPs to vote against this amended motion, i.e. to retain the possibility of a ‘no-deal’ Brexit, and failed. The Government was in disarray, with Ministers ignoring their leader’s instructions.
‘N0 deal’ should be described as ‘scrap all deals’, as 40+ trade deals would vanish, the proposed zero tariffs would destroy many businesses, and we’d spend 5-10 years negotiating new deals from a position of weakness.
I’ve always been strongly opposed to Brexit, whilst recognising the faults of the EU, but I hope many people now realise that leaving is complicated and brings many disadvantages, though ‘sovereignty’ and ‘control’ sound good. If the promises had been kept, then maybe it could have been justified. Those included:
Vote Leave offical statement: ‘We will negotiate the terms of a new deal before we start any legal process to leave.’ – but the legal process was started immediately.
Jacob Rees-Mogg: ‘We could have two referendums. As it happens, it might make more sense to have the second referendum after the renegotiation is completed.’ – but Brexiters have fought hard against this.
Apart from broken promises (and notice that those ‘promises’ are no longer used to justify Brexit, only the statement that ‘it’s the will of the people’), there were outright lies too:
Leave campaign: ’80 million Turks would be entitled to enter the UK once Turkey joins the EU.’ – but there was no prospect of Turkey joining for many years.

August 10th: Riots and crime for over a week, with hundreds of arrests, including some for on-line posts. There’s always been rumours, and wild statements made to mates in the pub, but social media spreads those like wild-fire, and it’s impossible to retract a rumour. Some Conservative politicians and commentators, and some from Labour too, have tried to argue that the riots were protests about ‘legitimate concerns’, and even tried to draw parallels with the pro-Gaza and climate protests, but those were predominantly peaceful and even the more extreme elements kept to verbal attacks in almost all cases. These were riots, led by thugs, and incited by some who want chaos and hate democracy.
However, it’s also clear that poverty, poor or non-existent housing, long waiting lists, etc. have given many people a feeling of being ignored and neglected, and that probably contributed to the larger numbers giving tacit encouragement to those with a violent agenda. Again, those grievances have been amplified by some who have contributed to the problems now being articulated, ironically under a new Labour government that’s far more likely to address these.
I’m not a paid-up Starmer supporter, but it’s absurd to label him a failure after a month of the new regime. Yes, he’s already made some mistakes, but he’s clearly more honest, more competent, more serious than his several predecessors, and it’s only fair to suspend judgement until he’d had a few months to demonstrate what his priorities really are. What is clear though is that people will want to see at least signs of progress on housing, waiting lists and some other costs before too long, and such signs will also help tackle the scapegoating of migrants.

Thursday 5th. The Liberal Democrats have always said that Brexit would be bad for the economy. The ‘experts’ that the Conservatives like to quote are really just Patrick Minford, who cheerfully admits that Brexit will damage UK industry and agriculture, presumably arguing that growth elsewhere will compensate. But the Economist magazine has endorsed the Lib Dems, the CBI have said we’re the party of business, and the Institute of Financial Studies has commended our realism and honesty about the need for tax rises.

April 3rd: Mounting cases, mounting numbers of deaths, confusion in Government (though with a little welcome honesty yesterday!), but some positives too. Our quiet street is developing a sense of community spirit. A Green/Red flag scheme so people can signal a need is in place, maybe not revealing needs if they are already under control, but showing a keen desire to look after each other. A WhatsApp group to share experiences and wants, whether a birthday, information about mail-order, or a wish for cheese or tofu! A nurse was isolated with her family for a few days, only to find her positive was a false positive and she’s back in the front-line. A seven-year-old’s birthday was marked communally with singing and music, including my own accordion in the street outside and my wife’s violin. We’ve already been booked for the proposed street-party at the end of lock-down.
Will this community spirit continue when it’s all over? Obviously we don’t know, but at least we know more names and faces. Maybe this time will awaken people to what’s really important in life (beauty and friendship, rather than possessions), to the people they depend on who are often badly-paid and insecure, to the risks of unlimited foreign travel. I hope so.

December 30th: Parliament has just passed the EU deal, opposed on principle by Lib Dems, Greens, SNP, opposed on grounds of the NI border by DUP, and supported reluctantly by Labour, fearful of seeming indecisive. In the House of Commons, the PM has too much control of business, and allowed so little time for debate that no amendments were taken at all. But this is not ‘liberation from EU control’ at all, it’s a dog’s dinner of a deal, with huge amounts of ‘blue tape’ bureaucracy, minimal provision for our services sector, and the loss of facilities and privileges including criminal databases and travel rights.
Meanwhile, the UK reaches a record number of new Coronavirus cases and a near-record number of deaths today. Premature relaxation of controls in early December, unrealistic promises about Christmas that Johnson didn’t think he could retract, and a new variant virus takes us rapidly towards serious breakdown of hospital services. No-one wants a full lockdown, but most of us recognise that it would be better than the on-off approach we’ve been offered.
Our PM hates regulations, and hates disappointing people, so he dithers, makes unrealistic promises, then is forced into belated decisions that fail in their objectives. Coupled with his penchant for saying what he thinks pleasing or funny, and a reluctance to have people of real ability around him, he is absolutely not the leader we need at this time.
But there are always good things to see, do and hear about …..

July 9th: It’s getting really tense! On Sunday we’ll see if England can ‘bring home’ a major football success, whilst in ten days we are likely to see a major reduction in Covid-19 regulations. Excitement – justified for the one, dangerous for the other if it means uncontrolled infections, especially amongst the young.
Johnson is really expert at painting himself into a corner, though this sad process was started by Cameron (promising an advisory referendum without planning) and made worse by May (suddenly announcing no Single Market or Customs Union). Through his relentless optimism and empty promises, he’s exacerbated both expectations and hostility, meaning he then finds it even harder to enforce any reasonable plan. He has an adolescent mentality: act on impulse, trusting that any problems will either just recede, or be sorted out by parents and/or money.
Johnson’s (and Frost’s) experience of treaties has not gone much beyond the staff coffee-club, it seems, and his patience with the hard detail of policy and a crisis is almost non-existent.

July 16th: What a result! 72 Liberal Democrat MPs, with all but one target seats won and some others beside! Of course it’s disappointing that so few are in the North, but the strategy of targeting in the South and South-East was hugely successful, and we can wait for a bit longer. For months I’ve been saying that with more MPs we’ll get more coverage and resources, and now Labour is in government, they’ll get more criticism. Put all that together and we’re likely to get more support, more enthusiasm, and more votes in the North East.
Meanwhile, I believe the new Government will be much better than what came before, and we should see some action on poverty, the environment, social care. I’m not an unequivocal Labour supporter, but we share some concerns, and in any case this new lot appear to be much more competent and much more honest – a good start for any government!

Tuesday 12th: I visited one of our active local Lib Dem branches, meeting in Morpeth, to hear what matters to them and areas beyond Tyneside. Northumberland is the most sparsely-populated county in England, and most of the people in the North of Tyne area are concentrated in the South-East corner, namely Newcastle, North Tyneside, plus Ashington and Blyth. Balancing the needs of this much wider area with the cities and large towns is a challenge I’d have to meet as Mayor. My discussions with the NE Chamber of Commerce revealed low membership of rural businesses.
Moreover, Brexit, in any form, would hit agriculture, not just manufacturing. In fact, Jacob Rees-Mogg’s favourite economist, Patrick Minford, said Brexit would be good for the UK but would decimate industry and agriculture – was that what people voted for?

November 18th: What a horror show! We already knew our Prime Minister was lazy, self-centred, dishonest, and favoured close associates (I think he has few friends) over others who can be relied on. But he’s been stupid as well this past couple of weeks, exacerbating a problem that was only bubbling along close to the surface. On the whole, I’m very glad he’s done this, as it seems to be finally penetrating into the public consciousness – that we have a Prime Minister who doesn’t mean what he says, who will let you, me, everyone down, and has led us into a series of disasters that were made much worse even if not avoidable.
Let’s hope that people will now scrutinise the Government’s performance more closely, ask hard questions about what they were promised, start to look more closely at alternative parties and politicians who might do rather better. That scrutiny might also increasingly come from backbench Conservative MPs who have been loyal so far, but see themselves made ridiculous and are receiving increasing cries of hardship and betrayal from their constituents.
If Johnson were to go, what would happen? Sunak and Truss are apparently popular amongst Conservative Party members, Raab is Deputy Prime Minister, but I’d have no confidence any could even begin to handle the mess Johnson has left (though blame is shared by all those who have gone along with things, including all these three). The only leading Conservative MP with any credibility as a caretaker Prime Minister is, I would think, Jeremy Hunt, on the grounds that he did come second in their last leadership contest, is experienced, is courteous to others and might build some consensus. He has much to answer for in failing to maintain the UK’s preparedness for a pandemic, but would be so much better than Johnson!
Of course, I’d hope that a change at the top would help the UK, but I’d also hope it wouldn’t make people trust in such a dodgy party, which has really sacrificed its credibility in the past few years. We need a real change, likely to be a minority Labour government with significant but selective support from Lib Dems and SNP. Let’s hope!

April 22nd: When politics comes up in conversation, it usually focusses on one or two principal events or policies, that someone either likes or dislikes, or on politicians – commonly ‘they’re all the same’ or ‘they’re only in it for themselves’. It’s much less common to hear people’s comments on what a politician, or a council or a government is able to do. Comments are also expressed in black/white terms (‘the railways are bad’ or ‘our money is wasted’) when what’s probably meant is more about how bad, or how much (‘my train has been late three times this week’ or ‘that was a waste of money’).
It’s worth considering what Politics is actually concerned with. Here’s some questions we can ask:
– What is best done collectively, and what individually?
– What is best done by the state, and what by private companies?
– What’s the right balance between regulation for the general good and individual and corporate freedom?
– What’s best done locally, regionally, nationally or internationally?
– What is the right balance of short-term and long-term needs?
– What’s the balance: high gain and high risk, vs. lower gain and risk?
These aren’t the only questions, but they do cover much of the political ground.
I think most people would recognise these as valid questions, and almost no-one would adopt either extreme for each example, except possibly the second question for some ideologues of the Left or the Right. A typical Conservative voter would probably say ‘more to the right’ for the first three questions, and a typical Labour voter would probably say ‘more to the left’ for all three. A typical Liberal Democrat position would probably be fairly central on the first two questions, slightly to the right on the regulation/freedom axis, but with a strong emphasis on the fourth question – making decisions at the right level.
Another aspect of government is that, in my view, there is no perfect and stable state to be achieved. At any time, one can only say ‘the balance is wrong’, and try to shift it. That’s because we are a complex society with many individual views and needs, and external factors too. Even in small organisations, there will be periods when collective action and benefit seems the right priority, and other periods when individual benefits and freedoms need to be addressed.

June 3rd: With a Conservative Party announcing ever more unbelievable policies, and the conviction of Trump, what’s the future for populism? In the UK, we’re certain to have a Labour government, but we don’t yet know how Starmer and his acolytes will work, having shown real ruthlessness both in reforming the party and in managing candidate selection and messaging. With statements on immigration and on nuclear defence in recent days, we must hope they haven’t gone too far in saying what people want to hear.
In the US, there’s some hope that swing voters and reasonable Republicans (of whom some still exist) will be put off Trump even if they don’t welcome Biden. But in France it looks likely Macron will struggle to keep any kind of centrist government, and there are populist movements in other countries too.
When people are frustrated or struggling with life they seem more likely to vote for parties with simple messages, rather than those who seem to have promised improvements that are slow to come or seem to benefit others. Surely greater realism should help – being honest that problems will take time to solve without damping down all hope. I think, but I’m not sure, that much of Starmer’s approach is just this – under-promise then over-deliver – but we won’t know for a while yet.

April 16th (updated 20th): The Covid-19 deaths recorded in UK hospitals appear to be declining slightly, following a slight drop in new cases, and also a very small drop in numbers of cases being treated in hospitals. Although early, this is very good news – the early exponential growth (doubling numbers of deaths every three days!) has been brought under control, or at least dragged back from the brink of overwhelming the NHS. Social distancing seems to be working, but in some form it’s likely to be with us for many months to come.
The details of the statistics are, no doubt, the subject of careful analysis by epidemiologists in universities and within the NHS and Civil Service. My own analysis started by ‘fitting’ a curve to the data (using the 5-day average to reduce daily irregularity) to see whether the growth was slowing. As the pattern has become more complex, it’s clear that no single curve (or formula, or model) should be used over the whole crisis, as different factors come into play. From March 25 to April 4, an exponential model fitted the data very closely (and has a good theoretical basis). Since then, the pattern is more complex, and prediction would be very rash until we have more data and more understanding. When teaching my engineering students, I emphasise that no curve should be fitted to data without some idea whether it’s justified, and whereas ‘interpolation’ might be possible, extreme caution should be applied to any prediction (or extrapolation) without an underlying theoretical model. May 11th: The Government has a really difficult job. If they had been chosen for competence not just loyalty, and if they could admit problems and errors, they might do better. As it is, confusion and dissent reign – Cabinet ministers disagreeing with each other and with the PM!
All the focus so far has been on ‘distancing’, with some people we pass anxiously leaving 3m or more. Yet how long we spend close to others, and whether we’re indoors or out, must be as important. This article is the first I’ve seen to cover this properly, but it’s much what I’ve been saying for weeks, ever since I heard that Singapore’s tracing was of everyone who’s been in close contact for 30 minutes or more. Hence, parties, cinemas and pubs, indoor work, and public transport are the big risk areas, not walking or shopping.
https://www.erinbromage.com/post/the-risks-know-them-avoid-them
It is a hugely difficult job and I don’t envy them. It would make me feel much more empathetic though if they rlied on people who understand the issues and were more honest in their approach.

Thursday 12th: Polling day, though many will have already posted their votes. Turnout in marginal seats is reportedly high. By about 10.15pm we’ll have some idea of the overall picture, but the count of seats will depend on those marginals.
In the past week, my personal team of three has delivered about 2,250 leaflets in one of our constituencies. We might not win, but it’s important to let people know what we stand for, to signal to other candidates and parties that not everyone agrees with either, to add to the national vote share, and, I believe, to demonstrate a positive attitude to the best in other parties and people.
On Tuesday evening, I was filmed answering a local-knowledge quiz (three of the five Tynemouth candidates participated). I didn’t do as well as the sitting MP, but he has lived here much longer than I have! Watch it at: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=99DLsJDMRu0
I’ll be up tonight until about 4 a.m. to hear my own result, but luckily I don’t have to work tomorrow. I don’t yet know whether I’ll be fairly cheerful or rather depressed – the latter if Brexit is confirmed (i.e. the very first stage of a lengthy process!), but I expect we’ll all have some time off before renewing our commitment to making the UK a better, more welcoming, and more sustainable country. We believe a majority would now support Remain, and a definite majority say that the Referendum shouldn’t have been held. What a waste of time, effort, anguish, to achieve a poorer result, and certainly a weakening of Britain’s reputation for pragmatism, civility and moderation.

April 29th: We’re near the end of the current round of elections – local, mayoral, PCC, plus a by-election in Hartlepool. In North Tyneside, the Elected Mayor chooses the whole Cabinet and oversees the budget – too much power for one individual, in my view, though while the position exists, I think I could do it well.
This morning BBC Radio Newcastle aired short interviews with all five Mayoral candidates at 7.20am and 9.43 am: https://www.bbc.co.uk/sounds/play/p09dlwkk. As always, my interview lasted 10-15 minutes, then about 30 seconds of that was broadcast! What did we all say?
Norma Redfearn (incumbent Labour mayor) focussed on regeneration at Whitley Bay (what about other areas?). Steven Robinson (Conservative) would cancel the 4.9% increase in Council Tax, but claimed the £4M hole in the budget could be filled by cutting £160k from councillors’ allowances and selling the Mayoral car!. I focussed on the Street Environment – better for health, more pleasant, and for the climate. Penny Remfry (Green) spoke well about improving housing. Jack Thomson (UKIP) wanted more cooperation between parties.
For more information about all five, see the official booklet delivered to every elector. (I noticed that I am the only candidate describing my relevant experience, also the only one giving contact details, which has led to dozens of contacts!). I had spoken also of the massive effect Brexit is having and will have on the North-East, hitting our regional shellfish exports (cut to zero!), moving jobs abroad, increasing bureaucracy, but that didn’t make it into the final brief broadcast.
And might we be nearing the end of Boris Johnson’s ‘reign’? He’s certainly embarrassed by ‘Curtains for Cash’, but the real scandal is in giving contracts to mates, and on ventilators and PPE, using firms with no experience and failing to use those who know how to make and provide vital equipment. We’ll see!

October 11th: Boris Johnson likes to pretend that everything’s fine, and that doubters are mean-spirited pessimists. He’s good at enthusing people, but has no real interest in the job of building and managing an effective team, making decisions, and accepting consequences. If he’s in denial, then it’s because he always has been – an adolescent talking big, leaving parents or other adults to sort out any messes he makes. Right now there is a fuel crisis (both supply and price), a food and materials supply crisis, a looming crisis of industrial shutdown, a virtual cessation of exports in many goods, a serious staff shortage in nursing and care, and he’s gone on holiday again whilst stoking a trade war with the EU and a dispute with France! To be honest, if he weren’t in denial, he’d probably have to resign, as the list of problems is formidable and he, and his Cabinet, just don’t have the ability and honesty to sort it all out.
In the end, Johnson’s inexhaustible belief in his own importance is being shown increasingly for what it is. Why then do opinion polls still show the Conservatives ahead of Labour and with other opposition parties also languishing? Maybe much of the UK population are also in denial – to doubt the Government is to accept their votes for Brexit and for this government were wrong, and people hate to admit that, but probably will in time. For Labour and Lib Dems, up to now talking about the failure of Brexit was seen as sour grapes; far easier to address once the public admits, as they increasingly do, that Brexit is going badly.

April 20th: Our Prime Minister stirs like the Kraken. Is it to fly into Belfast and try to reduce tension and find a way forward (out of the mess he created, of course)? No! Is it to deal with the inconsistency the police have reported between Government laws and Government guidelines on Covid? No! Is it to quarantine every arrival from India, rather than wait until the (as always, announced) deadline on Friday? No! Or about the growing miasma of sleaze, corruption and cronyism around government contracts with unqualified companies they happen to play golf with? Certainly not!
It’s about football, something he admits (in a rare bout of honesty) that he doesn’t support or even watch. This sport, which Bill Shankly famously described as ‘not a matter of life and death, it’s more important than that’, dominates the news. Leading politicians denounce ‘greed’ (unlike that of Cabinet ministers and their mates, of course). Of course it’s important to discuss something that is so popular, but is it really the Government’s business, if at all, and particularly when there’s so much else that they should be sorting out?
I’m pleased to hear of the imminent commitment by the UK Government (and the US Government too) to stringent targets for greenhouse gas reductions, and heartened to read of specific initiatives in the UK and elsewhere, but targets aren’t good enough, and announcing an announcement, plus the football kerfuffle, does look like an attempt to distract from the ‘cronyism’ and NI border rows.

August 12th: The public don’t trust politicians – nothing new there! However, this lack of trust seems to have become widespread, and to extend from political parties to official statistics, the BBC, authorities in general. Social media has amplified this through its ‘echo chambers’ or ‘bubbles’, but it could have happened anyway. What’s happened, what benefits might there be, and what drawbacks?
Half a century ago, most people probably trusted most of what they heard from authorities – the government, the Church, the Headmaster, the Vice-Chancellor, etc. They also mostly trusted teachers, sports coaches, parents, friends. The good side? Parents and teachers could do their jobs, most of life carried on more-or-less comfortably, and change was slow and infrequent anyway. The bad side? The rich (the elite) carried on with their privileged wealth and opportunities (who you know, not what you know), significant change was ridiculed, and, worse, abuse of authority and power covered up abuse of children, women, blacks and other disadvantaged groups. And young people from poorer backgrounds were discouraged from ambition and vision, even from speaking out about specific abuse or dishonesty.
It’s good that we can challenge authority when it’s smug, abusive or corrupt. Changes are always needed, and although new ideas need challenge and scrutiny, everyone has a right to propose improvements and to be heard in some forum or other.
However, it’s not good at all if we can’t trust experts most of the time, on vaccines, diet or climate. Experts in education are needed to avoid simplistic or reactionary notions. Criminal justice is more complex than the public mostly realises, with some ‘solutions’ making the problems worse. Right now, scepticism on vaccination and on climate are hugely dangerous to the whole population.
Another issue of lack of trust is that a change proposed from ‘top down’ can seem out of touch, and consultation is often ineffective at influencing proposals or building trust. I’ve seen this with proposals in my own department and the wider university, in the Church of England, and in local and national politics. Those ‘in power’ can see the need for quite radical changes, and believe there isn’t time to develop policy from bottom-up, so they make a proposal and ‘consult’ on it. The trouble is, most consultation is either too early (a blank sheet, eliciting too many incoherent or inconsistent ideas) or too late (a ‘fait accompli’), breeding cynicism amongst ‘the public’ and the ‘managers’ alike. Effective consultation should either be fairly early and general/strategic (‘which amongst these areas should be our priorities?’) or later but amongst feasible alternatives (‘we’ve set out three possible plans with pros and cons – which would you prefer?’).
A lack of trust, and ineffective consultation, plus the ‘management’s’ conviction that they must make things happen, lead to a general sense of ‘we’re being ignored’, ‘the elite are out of touch’, ‘too many resources are being kept at the centre’, etc. But the ‘too much centralisation’ argument often implies that everything would be fine ‘if we were left alone’ or ‘if we could come up with our own solutions’. The trouble with that is that people and communities are often slow to perceive problems and have their own inertia and/or vested interests, so ‘leaving them alone’ can mean decline. This is a particular conflict in the Church of England right now.
On Climate, on Covid, on Church decline, there really is no alternative to involving people, but also being frank that action is needed. That is, questions must be posed in a context of: ‘Change is needed, here are some initial thoughts of how, which do you think is best?’

August 12th: The public don’t trust politicians – nothing new there! However, this lack of trust seems to have become widespread, and to extend from political parties to official statistics, the BBC, authorities in general. Social media has amplified this through its ‘echo chambers’ or ‘bubbles’, but it could have happened anyway. What’s happened, what benefits might there be, and what drawbacks?
Half a century ago, most people probably trusted most of what they heard from authorities – the government, the Church, the Headmaster, the Vice-Chancellor, etc. They also mostly trusted teachers, sports coaches, parents, friends. The good side? Parents and teachers could do their jobs, most of life carried on more-or-less comfortably, and change was slow and infrequent anyway. The bad side? The rich (the elite) carried on with their privileged wealth and opportunities (who you know, not what you know), significant change was ridiculed, and, worse, abuse of authority and power covered up abuse of children, women, blacks and other disadvantaged groups. And young people from poorer backgrounds were discouraged from ambition and vision, even from speaking out about specific abuse or dishonesty.
It’s good that we can challenge authority when it’s smug, abusive or corrupt. Changes are always needed, and although new ideas need challenge and scrutiny, everyone has a right to propose improvements and to be heard in some forum or other.
However, it’s not good at all if we can’t trust experts most of the time, on vaccines, diet or climate. Experts in education are needed to avoid simplistic or reactionary notions. Criminal justice is more complex than the public mostly realises, with some ‘solutions’ making the problems worse. Right now, scepticism on vaccination and on climate are hugely dangerous to the whole population.
Another issue of lack of trust is that a change proposed from ‘top down’ can seem out of touch, and consultation is often ineffective at influencing proposals or building trust. I’ve seen this with proposals in my own department and the wider university, in the Church of England, and in local and national politics. Those ‘in power’ can see the need for quite radical changes, and believe there isn’t time to develop policy from bottom-up, so they make a proposal and ‘consult’ on it. The trouble is, most consultation is either too early (a blank sheet, eliciting too many incoherent or inconsistent ideas) or too late (a ‘fait accompli’), breeding cynicism amongst ‘the public’ and the ‘managers’ alike. Effective consultation should either be fairly early and general/strategic (‘which amongst these areas should be our priorities?’) or later but amongst feasible alternatives (‘we’ve set out three possible plans with pros and cons – which would you prefer?’).
A lack of trust, and ineffective consultation, plus the ‘management’s’ conviction that they must make things happen, lead to a general sense of ‘we’re being ignored’, ‘the elite are out of touch’, ‘too many resources are being kept at the centre’, etc. But the ‘too much centralisation’ argument often implies that everything would be fine ‘if we were left alone’ or ‘if we could come up with our own solutions’. The trouble with that is that people and communities are often slow to perceive problems and have their own inertia and/or vested interests, so ‘leaving them alone’ can mean decline. This is a particular conflict in the Church of England right now.
On Climate, on Covid, on Church decline, there really is no alternative to involving people, but also being frank that action is needed. That is, questions must be posed in a context of: ‘Change is needed, here are some initial thoughts of how, which do you think is best?’

July 3rd: Wednesday morning, 460 emails answered, four hustings, some people have even read my leaflet (and a few said it persuaded them)! The Conservatives sounding increasingly desperate, Labour trying not to sound complacent, and Ed Davey making a real splash!
The only prediction I’m making is this: Labour will win, Conservatives will lose loads of seats, Lib Dems will gain MPs. I’m really hoping for at least 30, and we might get over 50. That would actually mean our seat share was similar to our vote share, for the first time, at 10-12%. We won’t be formally part of the Government, but we will get greater representation on committees and more chances to influence things.
In the unlikely event we beat the Conservatives (in seats), we’d be the official Opposition. That would mean all sorts of benefits. Six questions each week at PMQs. Several days each year to put our own business before the HoC. Security briefings. LOTO to be on the Privy Council. More staff. More BBC coverage. The Conservatives would fade into the background much of the time!
Tomorrow night I’ll be up until 2am or 3am, but Tynemouth might declare earlier than usual, as the boundary changes mean that our local council has only one constituency to count and declare. Better in any case than 2010, when a badly-organised count kept me there until 6.30am.

John’s Manifesto, Letterbox leaflet and Official booklet entry
I want to see the North of Tyne area flourish
This is a great area to live and work in, with lively cities and towns, lovely countryside, great people (famously friendly), and a rich heritage of innovation – but it’s often seen as ‘too far away’ by southerners. We need to see this area, and the whole North East, thriving, in the lead, known to all.
As Mayor, John would DEMAND BETTER:
- Better Devolution – putting decisions at the right level, in the hands of those most affected and most knowledgeable
- Better Environment – to look at, to work in, and helping preserve a wonderful place for our children and grandchildren
- Better Education – getting more young people (and older people) into education, better jobs, more satisfaction
Experience
John has been a Newcastle councillor as part of a Liberal Democrat administration, Head of a large Engineering School (£14M budget, 140 staff, 900 students), charity trustee, union branch president, school governor, and serves on local and national church committees.
Pragmatism
I don’t have dogmatic ideas – trying to make the same solution fit every problem, but I’m willing to pick the best and ask advice. The other parties have their strengths, but tend to assume one size fits all. I’m a Liberal Democrat, believing in local decision-making but with an international outlook, but I’ll work with all partners. Let’s see what works!
A critical friend of Europe
The UK has benefited from a close relationship with Europe, from beneficial trade deals, people both highly-skilled and transient, higher standards on food, workers’ rights and the Environment, and greater influence in an interconnected world.
The EU has its faults – bureaucracy, weakness in managing disagreement, areas where it wants more power (but hasn’t usually got it!). But walking away is the wrong answer – throwing away deals, relationships, influence – and thinking we can bargain better on our own with the giant US and China.
Any form of Brexit will hit the North East hardest. But my Labour and Conservative opponents can’t give a straight answer on the biggest issue facing North of Tyne.

March 10th, 2025: North Tyneside has an election coming up for Elected Mayor – an important post managing a difficult situation of inadequate funding in a region that feels left behind, yet with great features and massive potential. I’ll be setting out my priorities here, and in the booklet circulated to 100,000 households, in the next few weeks.
The national picture was already bleak before the past couple of weeks. The Government has a difficult job to make good the mess left behind by fourteen years of dogmatic and unwise austerity, coupled with incompetence and, of course, damage from Brexit. However, Starmer’s and Reeves’ determination to appear tough on budgetting and other long-term issues, means people still feel they have a government that doesn’t care about them. And the latest cut to foreign aid is both tragic and foolish, as our security and trade are helped by development, and migration can only get worse without action on climate and conflict.
And now we have a madman in the White House, aided by billionaires who are greedy and apparently stupid too. We do need to increase defence spending, yet so much has been wasted equipping our forces to ‘fight the last war’, with faulty and under-armed aircraft carriers, tanks never likely to be used, and far too little anti-cyber technology, drones, and soldiers.
Back to local issues, though they’re all linked to national and international pressures and finance. We need to do all we can to build and preserve a great environment for health, leisure and for our young people. We need to ensure best value-for-money for the limited resources we have. And we need to make a strong case for more funding and powers to be devolved to our region.
And in all these, we need to be sure that the frequent ‘consultations’ do really reflect the true balance of public opinion, not merely the voices of those who shout loudest.
As Mayor, these would be my priorities: Environment, Value for Money, Public voice.
More details in the next few weeks!

May 27th: The Sue Gray report is out – enough there to destroy any normal Prime Minister, but perhaps not this one. Rumblings from discontented backbenchers and former ministers, but nervousness that an attempt to unseat him will fail and make things worse. He should never have been shortlisted for the membership to vote on a leader, just as Corbyn shouldn’t have been for Labour, giving the electorate an invidious choice in 2019. It’s nonsense to think there’s no suitable replacement, though some talented and (more) principled MPs might be reluctant to spend two years mopping up only to lose a General Election and share some of the blame.
And a huge £15bn support package, whilst essential, looks like both an attempted distraction and a complete contradiction of what’s been said and believed by this Government. Their MPs were whipped only a few days ago to vote against a windfall tax, which Labour are now crowing about, but which in fact was called for by the Lib Dems some months earlier!
May 19th: The Met Police were reluctant to investigate lockdown parties at no. 10, presumably thinking they’d be accused of political interference whatever their findings. They were eventually persuaded to look into twelve events, and investigated eight of them, finally issuing Fixed Penalty Notices to 126 people. But Boris Johnson received just one £50 fine, despite at least ‘dropping in’ to several parties, apparently on the flimsy basis that no. 10 is his home and so he was working in most cases. However, junior civil servants who cooperated initially with the Sue Gray internal report have been issued with many of the fines, possibly partially as a result of their confessions. They are reportedly furious!
Durham police are, meanwhile, investigatingone event that Keir Starmer was at. If they find Starmer guilty of an offence (for which he’s promised to resign), that would seem grossly unfair, as there was clearly no culture of negligence in his case, at most a marginal misinterpretation of the rules. I trust that their investigation is to demonstrate political neutrality, knowing that the Government was under investigation.
Maybe the Sue Gray report will strengthen the case that the Government, and Johnson in particular, were careless, negligent, dismissive, arrogant. I do hope that the public will continue to grow in their distrust of this selfish, arrogant and dishonest man, so that either he’s forced out of office or that he leads his party to a truly dreadful result in the General Election that must come by 2024.
May 9th: A huge shock for the Government, losing 487 council seats, consistently down in the polls, and with Labour more trusted than them on almost every criterion. But bigger still, they are threatened in their heartlands, particularly the South and South-West, by the Liberal Democrat surge, gaining 222 seats and 3 councils (returning to the same number of controlled councils as c. 2010). After Chesham & Amersham and North Shropshire, there are two tasty by-elections coming up too. The Government is finally looking very vulnerable.
May 4th: Many Conservative councillors are distancing themselves from their own party in government, with slogans such as ‘Local Conservatives’ and, even further, ‘Don’t punish local Conservatives for the mistakes made in Westminster’. The North Tyneside group have published pseudo-Green leaflets aiming to get some Labour voters to switch and save a few marginal Tory councillors. A tiny imprint has ‘NTCF’ (Conservative Federation), but for most people they look like Green Party leaflets, which they’re not! After all, it was local Conservative members who voted in Johnson as leader and hence Prime Minister, when his character and history were well-known.
This distancing is not new. During the Coalition years (whatever you think of that period), many local Lib Dem councillors lost their seats owing to general unhappiness with the national policies and compromises, and some campaigned with the designation ‘Focus Team’ and no mention of ‘Liberal Democrat’. I doubt this is effective and might even be counter-productive.
By Friday morning, we’ll see if there is indeed a substantial national swing in seat numbers, but it will be measured against 2018, when Theresa May’s government was already unpopular. Locally, the Lib Dems have a strong challenge in Weetslade ward, and the Greens in Whitley Bay. We share some aims (environment, and the need for scrutiny and challenge to this Labour ‘one-party state’), but remain distinct parties, especially at national level, where the Greens try to defend their ‘leave NATO’ policy – not at all sensible at this time!
April 19th: Desperate to displace headlines about lawbreaking at Number 10, and to shore up their ’base’, this dreadful Government have proposed an appalling plan for refugees – condemned by almost everyone who’s thought about the issue at all. The Civil Service are constrained, but have said it’s unclear whether it will be effective and hence value for money. It’s dishonest in that the UK takes a relatively small number of refugees, most of those crossing the Channel are genuine, and alternative safe and legal routes have been closed. It’s ineffective, as a deterrent works only if it’s known. It’s illegal, as it fails to deal properly with refugees. And it’s unethical and cruel. Perhaps most bizarre of all, Rees-Mogg asserts that it’s ’redemptive’. My view is much as Pope Francis’.
April 11th: Rishi Sunak impressed the public with his charm, confidence and ‘generosity’ with public spending. Many (including him!) thought he might be the next Prime Minister, but I always wondered – we knew nothing of any vision for the UK, ability in managing the executive decision-making or skill in building and managing a team. We did know that he’d been a hedge-fund manager, good at making money from insubstantial investments and manipulation of markets. In the past few weeks, his fall from grace has been spectacular – a budget that failed to address the cost-of-living crisis, apparent opposition to sensible energy/climate plans, and then his wife’s non-dom status for her fantastic wealth. Then, on top of all that. questions about his US and UK status.
On Thursday I was visiting Richmond in North Yorkshire, his constituency, and was by chance interviewed by an ITV team seeking the views of local residents. They featured my views at some length: https://twitter.com/ITVNewsPolitics/status/1512098733554610187 Some of the comments following the clip are hilarious! I was quite honest with them about who I was but they evidently thought the clip worth keeping. The whole tweet was re-tweeted by Wes Streeting (Shadow Cabinet), so it had lots of views!
April 6th: Today the National Insurance increase is implemented. On top of huge rises in energy costs, and a continuing squeeze on benefits and local authority budgets, times will be hard for many families. Yes, it’s possible to manage on less, and people used to know more about how to do that, but life wasn’t very good for many in those ‘nostalgic times’, and in any case, why should ordinary families be told to put up with things by people who don’t have to? When coupled with a casual and hypocritical attitude to the pandemic rules by Downing street, it’s clear that this Government is seriously out of touch. Many people remain to be convinced that Labour is ready for government, but increasingly they (and the Liberal Democrats) are seen as a serious party who cares.
The Government is also out of touch on other issues. Most people oppose the selling off of Channel 4 – pointless except as a piece of dogma. Most people are supportive of more on-shore wind turbines and against fracking, yet the Government is against one and favours the other. People support more Ukrainian refugees, but the Home Office makes that very difficult. They appear to be completely wrapped up in their own rhetoric. It’s to be hoped that they lose power sooner rather than later!
The immediate prospect of a challenge to the Government will come on May 5th in the local elections. Although primarily about local issues, and distorted to some extent by dissatisfaction that results from national funding but which impinges on other parties, it seems likely that many usual Conservative voters will stay at home, whilst opposition voters will turn out with greater enthusiasm. In North Tyneside, there are prospects of more opposition councillors from the Lib Dems and the Greens, who both had impressive gains in target wards. Although the overall political ‘colour’ of the two is very different, we share the aims of addressing the climate change, holding the local council to account, and scrutinising plans and decisions to set better priorities and ensure value for money.
March 14th: I’ve just watched short videos of arrests in Russian cities – one of a protestor with a card saying, literally, ‘two words’, and the other with a card that was completely blank. The Russian government is afraid of criticism. Much of its attitude is even more rooted in the past than Britain’s current nostalgia of ‘Dad’s Army’ and ‘Britannia rules the waves’.
But it’s also true that our governments have failed to tell the truth, in the sense of both words and actions. The belief that economic engagement would convert Russia, China and other autocracies to our liberal democracy was naive. Of course engagement, and particularly educating foreign students, is part of what’s needed, but sterner stuff must also be shown when such trust is clearly abused, as in Salisbury, Crimea, Syria, and substantial dependence on Russian energy supplies was a real risk, especially coupled with inadequate storage.
At the same time, our governments have failed to be honest with us about the need to pay our way – in taxes sufficient to provide the services we value, and in balancing our trade so that foreign investment can be selective rather than uncritical. The ‘golden visa’ scheme was always a terrible idea (actually introduced under Gordon Brown!), but should at least have had safeguards, notably a restriction on political donations for an initial period.
It’s commonplace to say ‘they’re all liars’ about our politicians, whilst expecting unrealistic things to be done, and voting for the best promises rather than the honest but more mundane ‘we’ll do what we can’. Vision is great, exaggerated promises are not.
February 8th: I decided some years ago that I hate dogma. That’s not a particular dogma, just all of it! There might be a very few exceptions, but these would be a few ‘truths’ for me, such as statements about the importance of truth itself, honesty, the value of human beings, the need to look after the world for the sake of our children and grandchildren, etc.
Dogma means (to me) an explicit statement of a belief that the holder is unwilling to question. I have no objection to strong beliefs, strongly argued, it’s the closed-mindedness that’s the problem, the ‘black-and-white’ view of the subject or the world. Just now, it’s party politics that’s at the forefront of my mind, but I will mention one other area.
Boris Johnson shouldn’t be Prime Minister. Increasingly, that’s a view held by many Conservative voters and MPs, as well as almost all others. It’s commonly said that by continuing to support him in post, those people are ‘putting party before country’, or ‘putting their own careers before principles’. I don’t think it’s so simple, though I’m not excusing it. It’s clear to me that for many of these MPs (and voters), there is a strong conviction that a Conservative government is best for the country, certainly in the longer-term and probably in the medium-term too. That is, even with doubts and problems at present, they continue to think that a Labour government will be worse for the country overall than almost any conceivable government by ‘their’ party. In this sense, they might believe they are putting country before anything else. Of course, an element of personal career is relevant, but the argument extends easily to: ‘I’ll be a better MP for my constituency than my opponent, because of my core values.’
Whilst I understand this mentality up to a point, it’s dangerous, as it can lead incrementally to acceptance, even advocacy, of bad policy, bad behaviour, bad management, etc. Surely most Conservative MPs would not have supported Johnson so willingly in 2019 if they’d known in advance how he might behave, how little he valued them, their opinions, their values.
A dogmatic position that says, in effect: any Conservative government, however bad, is always better than any Labour government, however good, is not a rational position, it’s a black-and-white dogma and should be called out and given no power. Of course, the same would be true for the converse.
Here’s my other example: When I was young, homosexuality was unknown, then weird, then a joke, then strange, then gradually more a fact of life. However, until I was about 25-30, I wasn’t wholly comfortable with this, whilst trying hard to be accepting. What finally brought me ‘off the fence’ was this: To hold the traditional view (of heterosexual lifelong marriage) was, in effect, to judge that any traditional marriage relationship, however bad, was automatically better than any other form of relationship, however good. That is, a dogmatic traditional position was clearly wrong and untenable for me. Thereafter, I accepted the validity and value of all good, committed, respectful relationships, hetero- or homo-sexual, whilst still rejecting any relationship that didn’t meet those values, or didn’t try hard to. I could add other rejected dogmas to these two, but that’s enough for today!
January 23rd: Boris Johnson is on the ropes, by all accounts and appearances. Parties (in no.10, in the garden, in his flat), threats to MPs, Islamophobia, on top of general dishonesty and incompetence, factional strife in his Party, and a growing cost-of-living crisis contribute to, at last, public opinion that he should resign or be sacked, with someone competent and honest in his place. Will it happen? Yes! Will it happen this week? Unclear.
Who would replace him? Sunak is front-runner, but we have no idea of his vision or competence, just his manner, and he has apparently little sympathy for the poor or the environment. If he takes over, then I hope the many problems are not shrugged off by him as ‘not his fault’, as any incoming PM must be seen to do something to alleviate them. I hope too that he doesn’t take over soon enough to get the benefit of the doubt in the May elections, but late enough for his competence to be as yet unclear.
PM is a job I’ll never have and couldn’t do, as my skin isn’t thick enough even if I had the ability! However, I sometimes think of what my first priorities might be in that position. Top of the list would be to reduce hostility and polarisation in Parliament, in the UK, with our European neighbours and beyond, for without that little effective governance is possible. I’d stop the hostility to asylum-seekers, but maybe process some in France if possible, with a clearer legal route otherwise to minimise the ‘boats’ problem.
I’d maintain masks in most indoor places to slow the pandemic, and slow the NHS vaccination deadline just a little to get more acceptance. I’d have a windfall tax on energy companies to offset the recent price rises and/or other costs on the poor.
For NI, I’d agree an SPS deal to ease the customs and border issues, and with the EU fix collaborations on Euratom, Horizon, and the musicians visa scheme. I’d revisit the Australia trade deal if possible to reinstate welfare and environmental standards.
There’s lots more! Much of the above doesn’t bring massive costs, but increases cooperation and trust, and partially tackles several crises. Good governance is more about the mundane than the dramatic, but honesty, trust and steady, small steps are usually the best way forward.

Although primarily about local issues, and distorted to some extent by dissatisfaction that results from national funding but which impinges on other parties, it seems likely that many usual Conservative voters will stay at home, whilst opposition voters will turn out with greater enthusiasm. In North Tyneside, there are prospects of more opposition councillors from the Lib Dems and the Greens, who both had impressive gains in target wards. Although the overall political ‘colour’ of the two is very different, we share the aims of addressing the climate change, holding the local council to account, and scrutinising plans and decisions to set better priorities and ensure value for money.
March 14th: I’ve just watched short videos of arrests in Russian cities – one of a protestor with a card saying, literally, ‘two words’, and the other with a card that was completely blank. The Russian government is afraid of criticism. Much of its attitude is even more rooted in the past than Britain’s current nostalgia of ‘Dad’s Army’ and ‘Britannia rules the waves’.
But it’s also true that our governments have failed to tell the truth, in the sense of both words and actions. The belief that economic engagement would convert Russia, China and other autocracies to our liberal democracy was naive. Of course engagement, and particularly educating foreign students, is part of what’s needed, but sterner stuff must also be shown when such trust is clearly abused, as in Salisbury, Crimea, Syria, and substantial dependence on Russian energy supplies was a real risk, especially coupled with inadequate storage.
At the same time, our governments have failed to be honest with us about the need to pay our way – in taxes sufficient to provide the services we value, and in balancing our trade so that foreign investment can be selective rather than uncritical. The ‘golden visa’ scheme was always a terrible idea (actually introduced under Gordon Brown!), but should at least have had safeguards, notably a restriction on political donations for an initial period.
It’s commonplace to say ‘they’re all liars’ about our politicians, whilst expecting unrealistic things to be done, and voting for the best promises rather than the honest but more mundane ‘we’ll do what we can’. Vision is great, exaggerated promises are not.
February 8th: I decided some years ago that I hate dogma. That’s not a particular dogma, just all of it! There might be a very few exceptions, but these would be a few ‘truths’ for me, such as statements about the importance of truth itself, honesty, the value of human beings, the need to look after the world for the sake of our children and grandchildren, etc.
Dogma means (to me) an explicit statement of a belief that the holder is unwilling to question. I have no objection to strong beliefs, strongly argued, it’s the closed-mindedness that’s the problem, the ‘black-and-white’ view of the subject or the world. Just now, it’s party politics that’s at the forefront of my mind, but I will mention one other area.
Boris Johnson shouldn’t be Prime Minister. Increasingly, that’s a view held by many Conservative voters and MPs, as well as almost all others. It’s commonly said that by continuing to support him in post, those people are ‘putting party before country’, or ‘putting their own careers before principles’. I don’t think it’s so simple, though I’m not excusing it. It’s clear to me that for many of these MPs (and voters), there is a strong conviction that a Conservative government is best for the country, certainly in the longer-term and probably in the medium-term too. That is, even with doubts and problems at present, they continue to think that a Labour government will be worse for the country overall than almost any conceivable government by ‘their’ party. In this sense, they might believe they are putting country before anything else. Of course, an element of personal career is relevant, but the argument extends easily to: ‘I’ll be a better MP for my constituency than my opponent, because of my core values.’
Whilst I understand this mentality up to a point, it’s dangerous, as it can lead incrementally to acceptance, even advocacy, of bad policy, bad behaviour, bad management, etc. Surely most Conservative MPs would not have supported Johnson so willingly in 2019 if they’d known in advance how he might behave, how little he valued them, their opinions, their values.
A dogmatic position that says, in effect: any Conservative government, however bad, is always better than any Labour government, however good, is not a rational position, it’s a black-and-white dogma and should be called out and given no power. Of course, the same would be true for the converse.
Here’s my other example: When I was young, homosexuality was unknown, then weird, then a joke, then strange, then gradually more a fact of life. However, until I was about 25-30, I wasn’t wholly comfortable with this, whilst trying hard to be accepting. What finally brought me ‘off the fence’ was this: To hold the traditional view (of heterosexual lifelong marriage) was, in effect, to judge that any traditional marriage relationship, however bad, was automatically better than any other form of relationship, however good. That is, a dogmatic traditional position was clearly wrong and untenable for me. Thereafter, I accepted the validity and value of all good, committed, respectful relationships, hetero- or homo-sexual, whilst still rejecting any relationship that didn’t meet those values, or didn’t try hard to. I could add other rejected dogmas to these two, but that’s enough for today!
January 23rd: Boris Johnson is on the ropes, by all accounts and appearances. Parties (in no.10, in the garden, in his flat), threats to MPs, Islamophobia, on top of general dishonesty and incompetence, factional strife in his Party, and a growing cost-of-living crisis contribute to, at last, public opinion that he should resign or be sacked, with someone competent and honest in his place. Will it happen? Yes! Will it happen this week? Unclear.
Who would replace him? Sunak is front-runner, but we have no idea of his vision or competence, just his manner, and he has apparently little sympathy for the poor or the environment. If he takes over, then I hope the many problems are not shrugged off by him as ‘not his fault’, as any incoming PM must be seen to do something to alleviate them. I hope too that he doesn’t take over soon enough to get the benefit of the doubt in the May elections, but late enough for his competence to be as yet unclear.
PM is a job I’ll never have and couldn’t do, as my skin isn’t thick enough even if I had the ability! However, I sometimes think of what my first priorities might be in that position. Top of the list would be to reduce hostility and polarisation in Parliament, in the UK, with our European neighbours and beyond, for without that little effective governance is possible. I’d stop the hostility to asylum-seekers, but maybe process some in France if possible, with a clearer legal route otherwise to minimise the ‘boats’ problem.
I’d maintain masks in most indoor places to slow the pandemic, and slow the NHS vaccination deadline just a little to get more acceptance. I’d have a windfall tax on energy companies to offset the recent price rises and/or other costs on the poor.
For NI, I’d agree an SPS deal to ease the customs and border issues, and with the EU fix collaborations on Euratom, Horizon, and the musicians visa scheme. I’d revisit the Australia trade deal if possible to reinstate welfare and environmental standards.
There’s lots more! Much of the above doesn’t bring massive costs, but increases cooperation and trust, and partially tackles several crises. Good governance is more about the mundane than the dramatic, but honesty, trust and steady, small steps are usually the best way forward.

July 22nd: A suggestion for the Government’s next 3-word slogan, but one they’d keep to themselves! They must know, surely, that they are incompetent, but can’t admit any problems or any errors, they see it as vital to ‘keep up the morale of the troops’ in the spirit of wartime propaganda. I think they’re in a blind panic, much of the time. Cummings’ evidence is convincing on this point at least!
Two days ago I had a new experience – a tweet that went viral, with around 300,000 hits. Cummings reported the PM as saying, in effect, that the deaths of over 80s didn’t matter too much, or were at least overdue. My tweet simply said this: “Stanley Johnson will be 81 in August. Will the PM tell him not to waste a doctor’s time if he’s ill?” Maybe Johnson doesn’t like his father, but I was pointing out that people aren’t statistics; every death is personal.
In the past 24 hours, we have another example of incompetence, not just technical incompetence but political incompetence too. The 3% pay award for NHS staff (excluding junior doctors and care workers) has been announced only very grudgingly and under extreme pressure, and has created yet more resentment and the threat of industrial action. Had they made that offer earlier and willingly, it might have been more acceptable under the circumstances. As it is, the Gov’t now has lost support from vital workers, and has a major funding problem too. It’s just like the issue of Free School Meals, of Afghan interpreters, etc. where delayed concessions under pressure are the worst of both worlds for a government.
In the book ‘Paddy Clarke: Ha, Ha, Ha!”, the boy has been having a bad time, but finds a more secure identity in being rejected by everyone. It feels at the moment as though this is the aim of Johnson and Frost and co – to be reviled by every other major country for being rude and dishonest, just doubling down on a secure feeling of being together with their most dogmatic supporters.
The adolescent Johnson no doubt found that problems would go away if left for long enough, or if adults sorted it out or paid the bills. It’s clear that he thought the Northern Ireland Protocol could be changed later, believing, or at least claiming, that it was normal to sort out details later on. But it’s only normal to deal with detail later, not substantive issues – something an experienced negotiator knows well. In this case, he denied the substantive issue, or did he actually think a united Ireland was inevitable and this would hasten it? Whatever the truth, he will not be able to deny this for much longer, with US opposition, food shortages, and growing domestic dissatisfaction with hypocrisy, selfishness and economic woes.

May 28th: The Government has announced its new Contact and Trace system, though it’s unclear whether it’s really ready, or whether there’ll be enough compliance to make it work. Both this, and the wider issue of virus transmission, have been seriously undermined by the behaviour of Dominic Cummings and the PM’s defence of it. The details of his trip are not really the important bit, nor his logic in maintaining that he didn’t have any close contacts. It’s the principle, firstly, that he acted in a way forbidden to others, secondly that he might have made close contacts if anything hadn’t gone to plan.
Overall, it’s clear that his own attitude of not caring what others think means that he is also blissfully unaware of the concept of setting an example. Our lazy, arrogant and incompetent PM follows the pattern of elites down the ages – one rule for the people, but exceptions for us. Since I was a student (and I still work with students), I’ve been sickened by an attitude I’ve seen that, for example, students trashing a restaurant but paying for it is ‘letting off steam’, whilst vandalism on estates is ‘hooliganism’.

April 17th: I am the Lib Dem candidate for Northumbria Police & Crime Commissioner. Whilst our policy is to replace these posts by Police Boards, I believe I’m the best candidate to do the post whilst it’s there! Here’s my brief manifesto:
I’ll be doing a BBC interview, as well as Hexham local TV, speaking at a hustings on women’s issues, and responding to many email contacts. Issues so far include: safer transport, hunting and wildlife, motorcycle theft, inclusion (of disabled and others).

January 2019 – things started to happen! Working with experienced colleagues, and based on my own experience and passions, we produced the Manifesto you can see on my Home page – demanding Better Devolution, Better Environment, Better Education.
Early on, I made arrangements to see key leaders in this area, to understand their perspectives and to begin to build the relationships I shall need if elected. That included the Vice Chancellors of both Newcastle and Northumbria Universities, and the Bishop of Newcastle.
Both Vice Chancellors want to increase take up of Higher Education in this area, to continue to work with Newcastle City Council on strategic initiatives, and to maintain international links – UK Higher Education is one of our best ‘exports’.
The Diocese of Newcastle covers almost exactly the same area as the new Authority, and we discussed, amongst other things, the need to attend to the huge rural hinterland, where transport is often difficult, services cost more and are harder to access, and educational courses are often inconvenient to get to.

May 4th: Many Conservative councillors are distancing themselves from their own party in government, with slogans such as ‘Local Conservatives’ and, even further, ‘Don’t punish local Conservatives for the mistakes made in Westminster’. The North Tyneside group have published pseudo-Green leaflets aiming to get some Labour voters to switch and save a few marginal Tory councillors. A tiny imprint has ‘NTCF’ (Conservative Federation), but for most people they look like Green Party leaflets, which they’re not! After all, it was local Conservative members who voted in Johnson as leader and hence Prime Minister, when his character and history were well-known.
This distancing is not new. During the Coalition years (whatever you think of that period), many local Lib Dem councillors lost their seats owing to general unhappiness with the national policies and compromises, and some campaigned with the designation ‘Focus Team’ and no mention of ‘Liberal Democrat’. I doubt this is effective and might even be counter-productive.
By Friday morning, we’ll see if there is indeed a substantial national swing in seat numbers, but it will be measured against 2018, when Theresa May’s government was already unpopular. Locally, the Lib Dems have a strong challenge in Weetslade ward, and the Greens in Whitley Bay. We share some aims (environment, and the need for scrutiny and challenge to this Labour ‘one-party state’), but remain distinct parties, especially at national level, where the Greens try to defend their ‘leave NATO’ policy – not at all sensible at this time!

The Northern Powerhouse dates from about 2012, with various projects in Manchester and elsewhere, then devolution deals with Elected Mayors announced in 2015. Manchester’s first Mayor was elected in 2017.
The North East was going to have a larger Combined Authority, but only the ‘North of Tyne’ authorities continued with the plan, so that’s what we have! There were public consultations in early 2018, though in my view the public (those who attended, including me) were not really asked the right questions, so the actual level of public support for this new plan is unclear.
The ‘Newcastle upon Tyne, North Tyneside and Northumberland Combined Authority’ was set up in Autumn 2018 with an Interim Mayor, and with the first Elected Mayor from May 2019.
The powers of the Authority and Mayor are fairly limited, coordinating and promoting the area, with £20M per year for investment, control of the Adult Education budget, and a combined voice on the existing Transport Authority for Tyne & Wear.
