March 28th: Between 2004-2011, the Liberal Democrats ran Newcastle City Council. We brought the finances under control and provided value for money (Council Tax rises at or below inflation), doubled recycling rates, and strengthened communities instead of the previous focus on the City Centre. This week the Newcastle LD group launch their manifesto for the May local elections. I was happy to join them for a presentation and discussion, with just a mention of the North of Tyne Mayoral election and, of course, Brexit (sigh!).
John’s blog on current issues
A fishy tale
29th March: Brexit discussions in chaos in London, but I had a good morning visiting the Fish Quay at North Shields, meeting Nik Hanlon (managing director) and Adam Riley to hear about their exciting plans to refurbish the quay, develop more processing facilities, and expand visitor attractions. This project has the potential to maintain and perhaps expand jobs, as well as to promote the heritage of the Tyne and increase tourism. Moving the ferry landing (likely to happen) will also help bring people to the Fish Quay, some straight off the North Sea ferries?
Sustainable villages
27th March: The North of Tyne area includes busy cities and large towns, mostly in the south-east of the area, but Northumberland is the most sparsely-populated county in England, with huge areas of beautiful countryside, villages, farms and hills. A real challenge for the Mayor will be to balance the needs of all these areas, and to help sustain rural life and industry.
Last weekend I was knocking on doors in Longframlington, with local Liberal Democrats, finding out what the residents are most bothered about in their area. It’s not the most isolated of communities, with some people commuting into Morpeth, and with some shops and cafes, but its needs are not the same as the major towns.
The next generation
22nd March: This morning I talked to Year 12 students at Duke’s Secondary School in Ashington. I explained some of the background and aims of the new North of Tyne Authority, and why I was standing for Mayor. Also why the South of Tyne authorities had been doubtful, linked to why powers here will be limited for now.
The students asked some good questions – about Environment, Transport, Brexit, Education, Representation, and why they should trust what I said! On trust, I said I’d always be honest if I didn’t know an answer, if the problem would take a long time to solve or was outside my powers, and I’m always willing to credit other individuals and parties for good policies and actions. I also said that representation, whether a school council, a Citizens’ Assembly (which I favour for setting local and regional priorities) or any other level, had to give real influence, not just cosmetic.
100,000 strong
March 19th: A very good meeting with representatives of the Federation of Small Businesses (FSB). Issues that particularly concern these often quite small companies include cash-flow, owing to late payment by larger organisations, and the difficulties of competing in procurement for public works. We talked about how information and support might be improved to help people who often haven’t time or expert knowledge. I was amazed to discover that there are 100,000 sole-trader/self-employed businesses in the North-East, generating around £4 billion in economic activity. They are also interested in how to contribute to a carbon-neutral economy, and in improving skills training for staff.
Town Centres fit for the Future
March 17th: Conference debates this important issue, summarised by the LD spokesperson:
“The crisis we are witnessing in our town centres is clear to us all. Whilst Brexit is partly responsible, at the root of the issue is our broken business rates system.
“It is only right we welcome the benefits of the 21st century economy, but we cannot ignore the plight of our high streets and all those affected. As more and more individuals switch to online retail, businesses are struggling and thousands of jobs are being lost.
“Business rates should be replaced with a land value tax that encourages businesses to invest, whilst we must also empower local areas by reforming planning and supporting entrepreneurs. It is not to late to save our town centres and these measures would do just that.”
Demanding better
Sunday 17th: Another day at the LibDem conference in York. Wholehearted resolutions to improve air quality by reducing petrol and diesel vehicles and avoiding idling engines, and another to reinstate adequate legal aid and access to justice.
Also a new Supporters Scheme to engage those with similar values but who don’t want to commit too far.
But like most conferences, the best bit is meeting people. And, as a bonus, my B&B proprietor turned out to be a former professional footballer (Man City, York, etc) who gave me a signed copy of his memoirs!
York – LibDem Conference
March 15th: The Libdems are gathered, energised about the possibility of a People’s Vote, still angry that people were so misled about Brexit. Why shouldn’t people get to vote on the actual plan? Why shouldn’t views change in 3 years? Strike ballots are invalid after 6 months – Conservative legislation!
Borderlands funding – good news!
The Chancellor’s Spring Statement included some good news, which, with the Scottish Government, means more funding for the ‘Borderlands’ initiative – a collaboration between English and Scottish councils including Northumberland.
The Press Release (full document below) includes this section:
Borderlands Partnership welcomes Governments’ funding commitment.
The Borderlands Partnership has welcomed the commitment in the Spring Statement and the announcement of a £345 million deal from the UK and Scottish Governments, describing the news as a ‘game changer’. The multi-million-pound funding stream comes just six months after the Borderlands Inclusive Growth Deal proposal was presented to the two Governments. And it will mean thousands of new job opportunities, millions of extra tourists to the area, improved digital connectivity and unlocking investment in towns across the region generating a predicted £1.3bn return on the Governments’ investment.
What on Earth – Government Brexit meltdown!
This evening, the House of Commons voted to remove ‘no-deal’ from any options for Brexit. Minutes later, the Government applied a three-line whip to its MPs to vote against this amended motion, i.e. to retain the possibility of a ‘no-deal’ Brexit, and failed. The Government was in disarray, with Ministers ignoring their leader’s instructions.
‘N0 deal’ should be described as ‘scrap all deals’, as 40+ trade deals would vanish, the proposed zero tariffs would destroy many businesses, and we’d spend 5-10 years negotiating new deals from a position of weakness.
I’ve always been strongly opposed to Brexit, whilst recognising the faults of the EU, but I hope many people now realise that leaving is complicated and brings many disadvantages, though ‘sovereignty’ and ‘control’ sound good. If the promises had been kept, then maybe it could have been justified. Those included:
Vote Leave offical statement: ‘We will negotiate the terms of a new deal before we start any legal process to leave.’ – but the legal process was started immediately.
Jacob Rees-Mogg: ‘We could have two referendums. As it happens, it might make more sense to have the second referendum after the renegotiation is completed.’ – but Brexiters have fought hard against this.
Apart from broken promises (and notice that those ‘promises’ are no longer used to justify Brexit, only the statement that ‘it’s the will of the people’), there were outright lies too:
Leave campaign: ’80 million Turks would be entitled to enter the UK once Turkey joins the EU.’ – but there was no prospect of Turkey joining for many years.

March 28th: Between 2004-2011, the Liberal Democrats ran Newcastle City Council. We brought the finances under control and provided value for money (Council Tax rises at or below inflation), doubled recycling rates, and strengthened communities instead of the previous focus on the City Centre. This week the Newcastle LD group launch their manifesto for the May local elections. I was happy to join them for a presentation and discussion, with just a mention of the North of Tyne Mayoral election and, of course, Brexit (sigh!).
John’s blog on current issues
A fishy tale
29th March: Brexit discussions in chaos in London, but I had a good morning visiting the Fish Quay at North Shields, meeting Nik Hanlon (managing director) and Adam Riley to hear about their exciting plans to refurbish the quay, develop more processing facilities, and expand visitor attractions. This project has the potential to maintain and perhaps expand jobs, as well as to promote the heritage of the Tyne and increase tourism. Moving the ferry landing (likely to happen) will also help bring people to the Fish Quay, some straight off the North Sea ferries?
Sustainable villages
27th March: The North of Tyne area includes busy cities and large towns, mostly in the south-east of the area, but Northumberland is the most sparsely-populated county in England, with huge areas of beautiful countryside, villages, farms and hills. A real challenge for the Mayor will be to balance the needs of all these areas, and to help sustain rural life and industry.
Last weekend I was knocking on doors in Longframlington, with local Liberal Democrats, finding out what the residents are most bothered about in their area. It’s not the most isolated of communities, with some people commuting into Morpeth, and with some shops and cafes, but its needs are not the same as the major towns.
The next generation
22nd March: This morning I talked to Year 12 students at Duke’s Secondary School in Ashington. I explained some of the background and aims of the new North of Tyne Authority, and why I was standing for Mayor. Also why the South of Tyne authorities had been doubtful, linked to why powers here will be limited for now.
The students asked some good questions – about Environment, Transport, Brexit, Education, Representation, and why they should trust what I said! On trust, I said I’d always be honest if I didn’t know an answer, if the problem would take a long time to solve or was outside my powers, and I’m always willing to credit other individuals and parties for good policies and actions. I also said that representation, whether a school council, a Citizens’ Assembly (which I favour for setting local and regional priorities) or any other level, had to give real influence, not just cosmetic.
100,000 strong
March 19th: A very good meeting with representatives of the Federation of Small Businesses (FSB). Issues that particularly concern these often quite small companies include cash-flow, owing to late payment by larger organisations, and the difficulties of competing in procurement for public works. We talked about how information and support might be improved to help people who often haven’t time or expert knowledge. I was amazed to discover that there are 100,000 sole-trader/self-employed businesses in the North-East, generating around £4 billion in economic activity. They are also interested in how to contribute to a carbon-neutral economy, and in improving skills training for staff.
Town Centres fit for the Future
March 17th: Conference debates this important issue, summarised by the LD spokesperson:
“The crisis we are witnessing in our town centres is clear to us all. Whilst Brexit is partly responsible, at the root of the issue is our broken business rates system.
“It is only right we welcome the benefits of the 21st century economy, but we cannot ignore the plight of our high streets and all those affected. As more and more individuals switch to online retail, businesses are struggling and thousands of jobs are being lost.
“Business rates should be replaced with a land value tax that encourages businesses to invest, whilst we must also empower local areas by reforming planning and supporting entrepreneurs. It is not to late to save our town centres and these measures would do just that.”
Demanding better
Sunday 17th: Another day at the LibDem conference in York. Wholehearted resolutions to improve air quality by reducing petrol and diesel vehicles and avoiding idling engines, and another to reinstate adequate legal aid and access to justice.
Also a new Supporters Scheme to engage those with similar values but who don’t want to commit too far.
But like most conferences, the best bit is meeting people. And, as a bonus, my B&B proprietor turned out to be a former professional footballer (Man City, York, etc) who gave me a signed copy of his memoirs!

May 5th: An exhausting couple of days on Friday and Saturday as I attended the Count for NE Mayor, local ward councillors, and for Police & Crime Commissioner. I was reasonably pleased to come a ‘good third’ with 17% overall, and in second place in the Newcastle and Gateshead areas. Here’s the full results:
As well as the Independent, the successful candidate agreed verbally with me that ‘This shouldn’t really be a party-political position’, but in her speech of acceptance, mentioned the Labour Party about five times! In fact, I’m against direct election of any senior position, as voting by party or by quality of public speaking neglects the qualities often needed to do the actual job. The same problem occurred with Johnson and Corbyn – both popular in the constituencies that voted for them, and neither remotely suitable to do the full job of leadership.
However, I do wish Susan Dungworth well and I’m sure she’ll work hard. I hope it works out well.
Somewhat separately, a good few days for the Liberal Democrats, with over 100 councillors gained and high hopes for the long-awaited General Election. And as well as that interesting result to come, what’s going to happen in the Conservative Party? Will it fracture? Will it unite but further Right?

April 22nd: I had a very useful and informative meeting today with the Chief Constable, her deputy, and the Chief of Staff for the Office of the PCC, also the Financial Officer for both. Over the past few years there’s been a serious squeeze on budgets, offset to some extent recently by an allowance for additional officers (who must be trained and equipped, of course).
Northumbria Police are more dependent on their central Government grant than other forces, with the local ‘precept’ (addition to Council Tax) not much above half of the level of most police regions, so the recent 7% rise isn’t really much in that context. It’s very demanding to run an effective force with this level of support, and to deliver on the aims of trust in the police (not as good as we’d like), reducing and combatting crime, and maintaining standards at an outstanding level. They deserve our support, and we should base any views on what’s happening here, not stories from London and elsewhere!
Amongst other things, we discussed coverage of the huge rural areas of Northumberland, and women’s confidence and safety. One year into her role, the Chief Constable also explained the way they are restructuring to give greater continuity and confidence to the public by giving officers a broader role throughout investigations, avoiding the ‘silo’ approach of different officers doing each stage.
Lots to take in, lots to learn, lots to discuss before making too many suggestions, but my priorities are crime prevention, working with youth, support for victims, and liaison with probation and the justice system to provide effective remedies and reduce re-offending.

April 25th: Many of us have been frustrated that frequent stories of Boris Johnson’s lies, and the favouring of cronies by him and other ministers, haven’t made this Government unpopular. In fact, it’s further ahead of Labour than a few months ago, with the Lib Dems also polling poorly. Why is this? The answer is probably that people voted for Johnson and the Conservatives because (a) they rather liked him, and (b) they were suspicious of Corbyn, for his ‘friends’ and the worries about anti-semitism (unfair in that racism in the Conservative party hasn’t had the same attention).
The terrible death-toll of the pandemic, and the economic slow-down due to that and Brexit, should also count against Johnson. The death-toll might have been half or two-thirds what it was, and the economic hit less severe, if he’d been willing to act more quickly on lockdowns as advised, and if guidance and example could have been more consistent.
So the dishonesty and cronyism was ‘priced in’ (as it was for Trump), and the worries about the pandemic seem to have been assuaged by the success of the vaccine roll-out (better than the EU!). It’s hard for Labour and the Lib Dems to make a sufficiently different case when deaths are falling, when people are looking forward to fewer restrictions, and the Government is splashing the cash.
That will change. Money will become tight. Jobs will be lost. And now the trickle of stories of dishonesty and corruption are turning into a flood, partly because Johnson foolishly accused his Svengali (Cummings) of betrayal, and that evil genius is striking back. Maybe as yet the public haven’t changed their views – they don’t want to admit they were wrong in 2016 and 2019, and they’re not yet convinced Labour are reformed – but Johnson is certainly losing what credibility he had amongst his own Cabinet and inner circle. And the Conservative party is notorious for removing its leader when that leader no longer looks like a winner.
The May 6th elections might not be bad for the Conservatives, and they might get a boost in the Hartlepool by-election, but before long, corruption, incoherence, and bad economic and employment figures will count against them. Politics is so often a waiting game!

March 2nd: Our inept Prime Minister, shackled to an almost hysterical right-wing, and facing electoral oblivion, makes a public speech about extremism and ‘mob rule’. I’ve said before that the thing I have most hated about the Governments we’ve had since 2016 (i.e. Johnson, May, Truss, Sunak) is that they have created, encouraged, even stoked, division between people, between communities, between countries.
Surely one of the most important functions of leadership – true for managing a department or even being a parent, as well as in politics – is to reduce suspicion and hostility, to build trust, to try to bring people together in a common vision? Obviously simplistic nationalism isn’t what I mean (such as Modi’s BJP in India), but a common vision that everybody, if possible, can see the point of and feel that they or their children and friends might find good in wellbeing if not in material wealth.
February 12th 2024: The general mood right now for most people seems to be ‘Anything but this!’ For many, that means voting for the candidate most likely to unseat a Conservative, even if that individual has behaved (mostly) honourably. For many others, it means ‘I’m not voting for them, nor for any of the others!’. This is not a healthy situation.
Keir Starmer is evidently a cautious person. He’s very conscious of what happened in 1992, when Labour had a fair lead in the polls, yet John Major and the Conservatives won. The margin in the polls is far larger now, but he clearly doesn’t want to take things for granted, and also doesn’t want to promise what he can’t deliver, in case he leads a one-term government.
However, it would be good to have more of a sense of vision and hope, instead of dull competence, even though that’s what’s more important in getting our society back on track as a functioning and civil country. He no doubts wants to be radical on the climate too, but has managed to give a very confused message on that. If the markets can accept Labour’s initial plans and track record, I really hope he’ll revive that necessary huge investment before long.
But I can’t pretend that a majority Labour government is my preferred option. I’d like the Lib Dems to get 30-50 seats, return to being the third largest party (2nd largest is too much to hope, I think), and have a real share in decision-making. Let’s see.
August 4th: Why does our Government continue to do things that seem irrational and counter-productive? Why not join the Horizon programme? Why license new oil and gas fields? Why announce that shoplifters will go to jail? Why don’t they seem to care about sewage in our rivers, and doctors and teachers leaving their professions in huge numbers, or whether we are taken seriously by our international partners? Are they stupid? Are their advisers all stupid too? Are their civil-servants not pointing out the ineffectiveness (at best) of these disjointed, erratic and naive policties?
Is it just that it makes more profit for their rich mates? I think not. No doubt they are so used to spending time with other privileged people that their judgement is affected. We’re all more inclined to trust those like us, our friends and those of a type we know. We flatter ourselves that we understand them and they us, that they are more likely to deliver what we intend than anonymous corporations. This surely underlies to a large extent the system of patronage over the years in promotions etc. Not all purely selfish, but also unconscious bias.
But there is another, quite different, rationale. In 2019, Johnson perceived that UKIP might contest many existing Conservative seats, and others he hoped to win, not by winning them, but by splitting the conservative vote. He tacked to the right, and UKIP stood down in all seats held by Conservatives that supported Brexit.
For the 2024 General Election, the Conservatives must surely know that they’re likely to lose, and by a substantial margin. They could easily drop to 200 seats (as Labour has now). But if Reform (ex-UKIP) contests many seats, that 200 could instead be 50-100 – a near wipe-out for the party. That’s what terrifies the Conservative Party. If they try to appear more moderate, they might regain some votes from the centre-ground, but they might lose far more seats through that split vote.
I think our inept, unimaginative and corrupt government has realised it’s going to lose badly next year, and its strategy is to avoid a wipe-out. I really find it hard to believe there’s any other rationale for continuing to adopt such stupid policies.
June 19th: A day to remember – the House of Commons debating the Privileges Committee report into Boris Johnson’s deliberate misleading of the House, and his subsequent rubbishing of the process and the individuals bravely producing the report. A bad day – that it was necessary, and that many Conservative MPs stayed away (very few opposed the report). A good day – that the HoC could be honest about the shenanigans of Johnson’s regime and his personal unsuitability to be Prime Minister.
And, this week, a ‘stolen’ video displaying the carelessness and contempt for the public and for shared mores as Shaun Bailey’s Mayoral team at CCHQ partied on the same day we were instructed to return to social restrictions.
Honesty in politicians means avoiding deliberate untruths or grossly misleading statements, as a minimum, but also means not promising things that there is no realistic chance of delivering. One shortlisted candidate for the expanded North-East Mayor says they’ll ‘eliminate child poverty’ – a laudable but impossible aim. They should really say ‘reducing child poverty is my principal aim’ and perhaps ‘we should be able to eliminate child poverty, and I’ll do my best to reduce it substantially in my five year term’.
It’s generally understood that Cameron promised a referendum that he thought he’d be forced to drop in a hung parliament, that Clegg promised no student fee increase as he didn’t expect to be in power, and that Johnson urged a Brexit that he didn’t believe in. Only the last was a complete falsehood, but the others were rash at least, and came back to haunt us all.
May 2nd: I get on fine with reasonable members of major parties, Labour, Conservative, Green (I don’t meet many SNP members, but probably them too). I do not get on with those who hold dogmatic positions, defying logic, ignoring facts, being insulting to others.
People should vote quite separately for local and parliamentary elections, as the issues are often different and the individuals too. A local council might be doing well despite being the same party as a bad government, or vice versa. Of course there’s going to be some overlap – local parties and national parties are likely to have related priorities and assumptions about the mix of private and public, individual and state, both with respect to responsibilities and to economic mechanisms. But I respect those who vote for an excellent candidate even where that party isn’t their ‘usual’ one.
However, at present this Government is so bad, so dishonest, so incompetent, that I’d rather they got a clear signal this week that it’s time for them to acknowledge defeat and give way to others with energy, ideas and integrity.
February 14th: I’m often accused of being too charitable to those who seem corrupt or crazy. Perhaps I am. But my experience is that people are often less corrupt and/or less crazy than they first appear. Moreover, in the case of politics, those who vote for what seem stupid or malign policies are unlikely to be convinced by our viewing those representatives in the worst possible light. So this is an attempt to ‘defend’ a significant minority of Conservative MPs who continue to vote with the Government even though they seem decent enough as people. This is not any defence of the policies, nor a full justification for their continuing support.
Traditional, one-nation Conservatism, and moderate, democratic Socialism, can have constructive discussions with each other, with a fair amount of consensus on what’s acceptable both to the public and in parliamentary processes. They also agree that change must happen gradually.
They agree on a mixed economy, but disagree about the mix, the balance between public and private finance, and between individual and collective responsibility.
The Cabinet (most of them) must know that Brexit has been hugely damaging, that leaving the ECHR would be insane, that scrapping EU laws without discussion or replacement would be disastrous. The only (sane) reason for these proposals at all is that they know they’re going to lose the next General Election, badly, but think their only hope of avoiding huge losses (resulting in < 100 seats?) is to keep sufficient core voters who might support Reform. Any attempt to appeal to swing Con/Lab or Con/LD voters could cost far more than it would gain.
Meanwhile, the ‘sensible’ Conservative MPs want their party to regain its pragmatism and caution. They know they’ll lose many seats at the next General Election, but hope that they can retain enough to form a substantial Opposition, and then re-form a parliamentary group capable of governing. But if they rebel now, they might fail to prevent whatever policy it is, create even more of an impression of incompetence, and feed the populist appetite leaking votes to Reform. They might also be de-selected (as in 2019). Thus they continue to conform, hoping to keep their own seats and a future, sensible Party.
Some Ministers might feel similarly, though they’re deeper in the collective insanity of making enemies, damaging trade, reducing Britain’s influence, weakening our universities, etc. But maybe a few (like one or two of Trump’s lieutenants?) think that the UK would be even worse off without their moderating voice in Cabinet.
Of course, I might be wrong. Many MPs are just in the habit of voting with their own Government, and fearful of losing their seats, even if they’re not personally corrupt.
November 16th: Common UK views have moved from ‘In God we trust’ through ‘With Truss, “Oh my God!”‘ to a weary fatalism now Rishi Sunak holds the reins – ‘God knows what’s coming next!’.
Back in the Spring, Sunak’s wife’s non-dom status became known, and by chance I was interviewed in his constituency of Richmond as if I were a resident (but I did tell ITV!). The comments after this clip are hilarious! It got extra coverage when re-tweeted by a member of the Shadow Cabinet!
I haven’t changed my views since the early days of ‘Dishy Rishi’, when I said we knew nothing about his vision or skills – now both clearly lacking – although he does seem more decent and a bit more honest than some of his colleagues. HIs judgement though – Braverman and Williamson and Raab. How long can he last?
October 18th: What a summer! My last entry, on 18th July, ended with this: “Whoever is chosen might get a small ‘bounce’, and might genuinely be a bit more honest than Johnson, but it is to be hoped that currently greater trust in Keir Starmer won’t evaporate, and that our new PM won’t adopt really stupid policies, rashly hoping for some populist revival of support.”
Well, our new PM got no ‘bounce’ at all, but maybe at least isn’t an inveterate liar. In fact, she tried to enact roughly what she promised to those few Conservative members, whereas most of us assumed she’d be more moderate in practice once she’d got the job! She did indeed ‘adopt really stupid policies’, but perhaps not primarily to get populist approval but because she’d fallen hook, line and sinker for ‘Minfordnomics’.
Patrick Minford argued that Brexit would benefit the UK, but was quite open about his view that it would lead to decline in UK farming and industry. I think his logic was, if it can be produced more cheaply elsewhere, let that happen, whilst we do what we’re best at. This of course ignores the fact that much of our trade was with Europe, now more difficult and costly. It also ignores the security of home production (very obvious now with increased conflict) and the dignity and pride of things done at home. Moreover, this ‘purely logical’ approach to economics is of the kind that argues full employment can be achieved if the wage levels are appropriate, ignoring the fact that those levels might be below starvation level.
Hunt has his limitations, but is more mature and able than the PMs and chancellors we’ve had for some years. I hope he can save the UK from misery, but I also hope the Conservatives lose lots of seats at a General Election soon and learn from that!
July 18th: Boris Johnson got rid of most of the most talented moderates in his parliamentary party, demanding all candidates in 2019 and all MPs since should show total loyalty to him and the Brexit project. That meant many, less courageous, MPs swallowing their pride and principles to defend the indefensible, such as lies about ‘forty new hospitals’ and ‘Northern Ireland’s economy lagging behind the rest of Britain’, trashing our reputation for integrity and reliability, and adopting populist but ineffective policies such as increased prison sentences and the appalling Rwanda policy.
Finally forced out by his dishonesty and irresponsibility over ‘Partygate’ and the Pincher affair, Johnson leaves behind a sorry state of both UK policy and economy, and of possible successors. The debates on TV, in the press and on Twitter have brought us little honesty, few ideas, and much mud-slinging about the candidates’ own involvement and about each other. The third TV debate has been cancelled as two leading candidates could see these pubic viewings were just making them all look bad. Recall that Johnson refused to participate in all but one TV debate in 2019 and also swerved the hardest interview experienced by the other leaders in the 2019 General Election.
Whoever is chosen might get a small ‘bounce’, and might genuinely be a bit more honest than Johnson, but it is to be hoped that currently greater trust in Keir Starmer won’t evaporate, and that our new PM won’t adopt really stupid policies, rashly hoping for some populist revival of support.
June 21st: Rail strikes today, and the Government tries to blame this on Labour, who haven’t been in power for twelve years! It’s very probable that the unions have been obstructive to new practices in some ways, and certain that the railways must find economies as fewer people commute. Nonetheless, rail companies make large profits at public expense, and it probably suits the Government to milk the situation to get a few more votes in the by-elections this week.
The ‘Boris tried to get his lover a job’ story is very curious. Trying to suppress an almost certainly true story seems pointless, but is probably a panic reaction, calculating that some core Tory voters in Tiverton and Honiton are more likely to be influenced by paper copies of their favourite newspapers than by the commentary. Why would the Times and Mail withdraw the story? What have they been promised? Is Johnson seriously considering a General Election once the by-election results are known, and in that case, has he offered the Times and Mail an exclusive?
I’m an optimist, but the country does seem to be out of control at present. I don’t envy any new government trying to address so many difficulties – inflation, staff shortages, trade, Northern Ireland, the pandemic, Ukraine, but building trust and cooperation must be at the centre of any programme of government right now, and at any time. Labour isn’t to blame for most of the current crop of problems, but they do need some courage in projecting a vision that’s positive for people. That does seem to be lacking, and if the Tories do dump Johnson and find a more decent and competent leader, it might be hard for Starmer to be seen as the better choice.

May 19th: The Met Police were reluctant to investigate lockdown parties at no. 10, presumably thinking they’d be accused of political interference whatever their findings. They were eventually persuaded to look into twelve events, and investigated eight of them, finally issuing Fixed Penalty Notices to 126 people. But Boris Johnson received just one £50 fine, despite at least ‘dropping in’ to several parties, apparently on the flimsy basis that no. 10 is his home and so he was working in most cases. However, junior civil servants who cooperated initially with the Sue Gray internal report have been issued with many of the fines, possibly partially as a result of their confessions. They are reportedly furious!
Durham police are, meanwhile, investigating one event that Keir Starmer was at. If they find Starmer guilty of an offence (for which he’s promised to resign), that would seem grossly unfair, as there was clearly no culture of negligence in his case, at most a marginal misinterpretation of the rules. I trust that their investigation is to demonstrate political neutrality, knowing that the Government was under investigation.
Maybe the Sue Gray report will strengthen the case that the Government, and Johnson in particular, were careless, negligent, dismissive, arrogant. I do hope that the public will continue to grow in their distrust of this selfish, arrogant and dishonest man, so that either he’s forced out of office or that he leads his party to a truly dreadful result in the General Election that must come by 2024.

However, junior civil servants who cooperated initially with the Sue Gray internal report have been issued with many of the fines, possibly partially as a result of their confessions. They are reportedly furious!
Durham police are, meanwhile, investigating one event that Keir Starmer was at. If they find Starmer guilty of an offence (for which he’s promised to resign), that would seem grossly unfair, as there was clearly no culture of negligence in his case, at most a marginal misinterpretation of the rules. I trust that their investigation is to demonstrate political neutrality, knowing that the Government was under investigation.
Maybe the Sue Gray report will strengthen the case that the Government, and Johnson in particular, were careless, negligent, dismissive, arrogant. I do hope that the public will continue to grow in their distrust of this selfish, arrogant and dishonest man, so that either he’s forced out of office or that he leads his party to a truly dreadful result in the General Election that must come by 2024.

May 5th: Most people dislike the mud-slinging of politics, the exaggeration (even when it doesn’t spill over into outright lies), the unwillingness to cooperate (at least in public). Most people say they want a fairer voting system, whilst remaining cautious about any particular proposal. Most politicians say the ‘other side’ are the problem, either in campaigning, or in governing. The outstanding example of a failure to cooperate in government is on social care, where an agreed plan is vital, but both sides have seen electoral advantage, or feared it for the others, in any concrete plans.
Negative campaigning includes describing the worst examples of failures by other parties or candidates, predicting disasters, focussing on examples of incompetence, dishonesty or simply gaffes. I believe this style is more likely to depress your opponent’s vote than to increase your own. If everyone does it, then it increases cynicism and disengagement in the electorate.
What can be done, about honesty and about cooperation? Well, it’s a long-term view, but I believe it’s essential to start here, and model what we way we, and the public, want. That is, to be honest about the difficulties of solving major problems (‘it’s complex and will take a long time’) whilst having some definite plans for the immediate future (‘this is what we’ll do first….’).
Cooperation can be demonstrated in hustings and materials (‘The xxxx policy on yyyy is a good one, which we’d be happy to adopt/collaborate on.’), and in taking the risk, when elected, of agreeing to a joint policy that might redound more strongly to others – but this doesn’t stop all parties publicising the efforts and outcomes.
What about electoral pacts? Pacts agreed in advance have real drawbacks, as votes for all parties come from more than one area of policy. If in the UK, Lib Dems and Greens made a pact, some LD supporters would revert to Conservative because of the Greens’ social and financial policy, and some Greens would revert to Labour because they perceive LD policy to be too ‘establishment’ or business-oriented. However, an approach of non-aggression (not campaigning seriously where the other party has a much better chance) can and does happen. Voters know that each party has distinctive aspects but also things they don’t like, but they have a better ‘feeling’ for what they’re voting for. PR systems allow and require more cooperation after the election, but it’s right to see some distinctiveness when voting. However, for voters to feel they haven’t been ignored, all parties should have a few things they won’t compromise on in any coalition, so their voters know for sure that will be part of any agreeement.
By Saturday afternoon, we’ll know the result of local, mayoral (local and regional), PCC, and Scottish and Welsh assembly elections. I hope there won’t be too much for Johnson and his cronies to crow about, but it’s clear that the biased and wasteful awarding of contracts, and personal dishonesty, hasn’t yet moved swing voters very far against him. I think it will in time, but probably only when more austerity and unemployment makes their incompetence clear.

April 18th: This morning I participated in an on-line hustings organised by ‘Represent Women’ with the other three PCC candidates. 25-30 women joined in, with questions from about nine of them. Some great questions, and good points made by all four candidates, none of whom were ‘party political’ (except that the independent asserted, wrongly, that our three parties were too influenced by funding from big tech etc.).
Questions were on trust in police, routes to reporting, timely and sympathetic reaction needed, safety on transport, impact of shoplifting on retail workers, on-line sexting, grooming, etc, sexual offenders who are also police officers, domestic violence, separation of children from women (both those at risk and from women who are offenders, and who are often victims too).
Main conclusions I took from the hustings: need to collaborate with women’s groups, educate boys and young men, root out sexism amongst police officers, ensure training of police is thorough, take all crime seriously and ‘nip it in the bud’, building a good public realm with greater use of and public participation in transport and services. Note that better use of public transport fits well with the Mayoral priorities, and would help the Environment (see picture below)!
I also recorded a short interview with BBC Radio, to be edited and broadcast next week. My main points were: 1. We should focus particularly on crime prevention, and on timely justice, rather than level of punishments. 2. We need to listen to and support victims, with a special focus on deprived areas and women’s issues. 3. We need to ensure efficient use of police time and effort.
And last, but not least, as I already have a good occupational pension, I’d take only half of the allotted salary, and give 50% to projects that help keep young people out of crime.
(As soon as I have links to the recording of the hustings and to the radio interview, I’ll post them here.)

September 18th: The UK is doing badly in this pandemic, though we’ve dropped to only seventh-worst in the World, and might drop further as things go on. What could be done better?
The only countries doing well, apparently, in this crisis, are those with a high level of social conformity (far-eastern), isolation exploited quickly (NZ), brilliant organisation (Germany), extreme localism (Kerala in India), young, dispersed populations (parts of Africa?).
What would I do differently from the Gov’t right now on the pandemic?
- Be open about mistakes, problems, statistics.
- Be careful and consistent with instructions and ‘messages’.
- Engage local authorities and health authorities fully in both local rules and tracing.
- Separate: who to test and where, swabbing, analysis, dissemination of results, and logistics, and ensure allocation of resources for each.
- Stop assuming that private contractors work best, costing huge sums yet still failing.
- Integrate with other regional health needs.
None of this would ‘solve’ the problem, but right now the Gov’t is increasingly not trusted on this or almost every other issue, and with their dogmatic Brexit making it all worse. Without a trustworthy government, all outcomes are likely to be worse.

July 7th: Has Boris Johnson gone too far this time? He seems to have followed a deliberate strategy (like Trump, and influenced by Lynton Crosby) of saying plausible things openly, and anticipating that his personality, a largely uncritical press (until recently!), and his status as Prime Minister will get his messages across, whilst rebuttals won’t get the same coverage. In any case, it’s been shown that, once someone ‘knows’ something, attempts to refute it often strengthen the conviction that it was right. Difficult, therefore, to change people’s minds, and argument doesn’t generally do it.
However, this week he’s stated, publically, that care homes didn’t follow procedures, and implied, at least, that the 20,000+ care-home deaths were a consequence. Since they mostly followed Gov’t advice, took in probably infected people, made use of underpaid staff who were not advised against multiple sites, and lacked necessary PPE, they are not to blame. Already he’s had to ‘clarify’ what he meant, but I anticipate that this one will run and run, and most of the press will be very unsympathetic.
His timing seems poor too. I think the rumour of 20,000 fewer troops is a ‘dead cat’ distraction, designed to take our attention off the Covid-19 crisis, the economy, and Brexit, but criticising care homes brings back dismay at the Government. On Brexit, there is talk of a collaboration with the EU over vaccine development, whilst our Galileo (GPS) substitute looks like a debacle. Maybe more Brexit U-turns are likely. Even a Leave-EU posting is worried about no-deal (though they’re trying to blame this on the delay they say was caused by Remainers, not the ERG). With more frequent criticism of the Gov’t, and Johnson in particular, in the Mail, the Telegraph and elsewhere, how long can he last?

August 28th: The feast of St Augustine of Hippo, who changed his views mid-life and had a profound effect on Christian belief, including the concept of Original Sin. Questionable, maybe, but addressing the question of why we all fail to live to our own ideals. I wrote a song for the Cranmer Hall revue in 2006, to the well-known Flanders and Swann tune:
The St Augustine of Hippo Song
An old theologian was seated one day, in his cold, Carthaginian cell.
Whilst neatly illuminating capital J, he heard a quite ear-splitting yell.
Was Carthage attacked by the Romans again, or was it some novices’ fight?
Was evil invasive, or God not pervasive? He suddenly had it just right:
Chorus: Sin, sin, Original Sin, You can’t get it out, it is always within.
But for Salvation, eternal damnation, is ours when we wallow in Original Sin.
As Adam in Eden did wander with Eve, ‘neath the trees with their apples and pears,
Their blissful obedience was quickly aggrieved, by the serpent, which gave itself airs.
“Why not taste this apple”, the creature enquired, “and gain knowledge of wrong and of right?”.
With minimal caution, they each had a portion, then fled from that place of delight. Chorus
Our Lord God Almighty was peering below, from his comfortable seat on a cloud,
At famine and harvest, at sun, rain and snow, when he heard someone groaning aloud.
The priest, with an unfinished sermon in hand, was visibly feeling contrite.
In sudden compassion, our Lord, feeling rash, in-carnated and put it all right. Chorus

March 28th: Between 2004-2011, the Liberal Democrats ran Newcastle City Council. We brought the finances under control and provided value for money (Council Tax rises at or below inflation), doubled recycling rates, and strengthened communities instead of the previous focus on the City Centre. This week the Newcastle LD group launch their manifesto for the May local elections. I was happy to join them for a presentation and discussion, with just a mention of the North of Tyne Mayoral election and, of course, Brexit (sigh!).
Category: Uncategorized
A fishy tale
29th March: Brexit discussions in chaos in London, but I had a good morning visiting the Fish Quay at North Shields, meeting Nik Hanlon (managing director) and Adam Riley to hear about their exciting plans to refurbish the quay, develop more processing facilities, and expand visitor attractions. This project has the potential to maintain and perhaps expand jobs, as well as to promote the heritage of the Tyne and increase tourism. Moving the ferry landing (likely to happen) will also help bring people to the Fish Quay, some straight off the North Sea ferries?
Sustainable villages
27th March: The North of Tyne area includes busy cities and large towns, mostly in the south-east of the area, but Northumberland is the most sparsely-populated county in England, with huge areas of beautiful countryside, villages, farms and hills. A real challenge for the Mayor will be to balance the needs of all these areas, and to help sustain rural life and industry.
Last weekend I was knocking on doors in Longframlington, with local Liberal Democrats, finding out what the residents are most bothered about in their area. It’s not the most isolated of communities, with some people commuting into Morpeth, and with some shops and cafes, but its needs are not the same as the major towns.
The next generation
22nd March: This morning I talked to Year 12 students at Duke’s Secondary School in Ashington. I explained some of the background and aims of the new North of Tyne Authority, and why I was standing for Mayor. Also why the South of Tyne authorities had been doubtful, linked to why powers here will be limited for now.
The students asked some good questions – about Environment, Transport, Brexit, Education, Representation, and why they should trust what I said! On trust, I said I’d always be honest if I didn’t know an answer, if the problem would take a long time to solve or was outside my powers, and I’m always willing to credit other individuals and parties for good policies and actions. I also said that representation, whether a school council, a Citizens’ Assembly (which I favour for setting local and regional priorities) or any other level, had to give real influence, not just cosmetic.
100,000 strong
March 19th: A very good meeting with representatives of the Federation of Small Businesses (FSB). Issues that particularly concern these often quite small companies include cash-flow, owing to late payment by larger organisations, and the difficulties of competing in procurement for public works. We talked about how information and support might be improved to help people who often haven’t time or expert knowledge. I was amazed to discover that there are 100,000 sole-trader/self-employed businesses in the North-East, generating around £4 billion in economic activity. They are also interested in how to contribute to a carbon-neutral economy, and in improving skills training for staff.
Town Centres fit for the Future

Demanding better
Sunday 17th: Another day at the LibDem conference in York. Wholehearted resolutions to improve air quality by reducing petrol and diesel vehicles and avoiding idling engines, and another to reinstate adequate legal aid and access to justice.
Also a new Supporters Scheme to engage those with similar values but who don’t want to commit too far.
But like most conferences, the best bit is meeting people. And, as a bonus, my B&B proprietor turned out to be a former professional footballer (Man City, York, etc) who gave me a signed copy of his memoirs!
York – LibDem Conference
March 15th: The Libdems are gathered, energised about the possibility of a People’s Vote, still angry that people were so misled about Brexit. Why shouldn’t people get to vote on the actual plan? Why shouldn’t views change in 3 years? Strike ballots are invalid after 6 months – Conservative legislation!
Borderlands funding – good news!
The Chancellor’s Spring Statement included some good news, which, with the Scottish Government, means more funding for the ‘Borderlands’ initiative – a collaboration between English and Scottish councils including Northumberland.
The Press Release (full document below) includes this section:
Borderlands Partnership welcomes Governments’ funding commitment.
The Borderlands Partnership has welcomed the commitment in the Spring Statement and the announcement of a £345 million deal from the UK and Scottish Governments, describing the news as a ‘game changer’. The multi-million-pound funding stream comes just six months after the Borderlands Inclusive Growth Deal proposal was presented to the two Governments. And it will mean thousands of new job opportunities, millions of extra tourists to the area, improved digital connectivity and unlocking investment in towns across the region generating a predicted £1.3bn return on the Governments’ investment.
What on Earth – Government Brexit meltdown!
This evening, the House of Commons voted to remove ‘no-deal’ from any options for Brexit. Minutes later, the Government applied a three-line whip to its MPs to vote against this amended motion, i.e. to retain the possibility of a ‘no-deal’ Brexit, and failed. The Government was in disarray, with Ministers ignoring their leader’s instructions.
‘N0 deal’ should be described as ‘scrap all deals’, as 40+ trade deals would vanish, the proposed zero tariffs would destroy many businesses, and we’d spend 5-10 years negotiating new deals from a position of weakness.
I’ve always been strongly opposed to Brexit, whilst recognising the faults of the EU, but I hope many people now realise that leaving is complicated and brings many disadvantages, though ‘sovereignty’ and ‘control’ sound good. If the promises had been kept, then maybe it could have been justified. Those included:
Vote Leave offical statement: ‘We will negotiate the terms of a new deal before we start any legal process to leave.’ – but the legal process was started immediately.
Jacob Rees-Mogg: ‘We could have two referendums. As it happens, it might make more sense to have the second referendum after the renegotiation is completed.’ – but Brexiters have fought hard against this.
Apart from broken promises (and notice that those ‘promises’ are no longer used to justify Brexit, only the statement that ‘it’s the will of the people’), there were outright lies too:
Leave campaign: ’80 million Turks would be entitled to enter the UK once Turkey joins the EU.’ – but there was no prospect of Turkey joining for many years.

Category: Uncategorized
A fishy tale
29th March: Brexit discussions in chaos in London, but I had a good morning visiting the Fish Quay at North Shields, meeting Nik Hanlon (managing director) and Adam Riley to hear about their exciting plans to refurbish the quay, develop more processing facilities, and expand visitor attractions. This project has the potential to maintain and perhaps expand jobs, as well as to promote the heritage of the Tyne and increase tourism. Moving the ferry landing (likely to happen) will also help bring people to the Fish Quay, some straight off the North Sea ferries?
Sustainable villages
27th March: The North of Tyne area includes busy cities and large towns, mostly in the south-east of the area, but Northumberland is the most sparsely-populated county in England, with huge areas of beautiful countryside, villages, farms and hills. A real challenge for the Mayor will be to balance the needs of all these areas, and to help sustain rural life and industry.
Last weekend I was knocking on doors in Longframlington, with local Liberal Democrats, finding out what the residents are most bothered about in their area. It’s not the most isolated of communities, with some people commuting into Morpeth, and with some shops and cafes, but its needs are not the same as the major towns.
The next generation
22nd March: This morning I talked to Year 12 students at Duke’s Secondary School in Ashington. I explained some of the background and aims of the new North of Tyne Authority, and why I was standing for Mayor. Also why the South of Tyne authorities had been doubtful, linked to why powers here will be limited for now.
The students asked some good questions – about Environment, Transport, Brexit, Education, Representation, and why they should trust what I said! On trust, I said I’d always be honest if I didn’t know an answer, if the problem would take a long time to solve or was outside my powers, and I’m always willing to credit other individuals and parties for good policies and actions. I also said that representation, whether a school council, a Citizens’ Assembly (which I favour for setting local and regional priorities) or any other level, had to give real influence, not just cosmetic.
100,000 strong
March 19th: A very good meeting with representatives of the Federation of Small Businesses (FSB). Issues that particularly concern these often quite small companies include cash-flow, owing to late payment by larger organisations, and the difficulties of competing in procurement for public works. We talked about how information and support might be improved to help people who often haven’t time or expert knowledge. I was amazed to discover that there are 100,000 sole-trader/self-employed businesses in the North-East, generating around £4 billion in economic activity. They are also interested in how to contribute to a carbon-neutral economy, and in improving skills training for staff.
Town Centres fit for the Future
March 17th: Conference debates this important issue, summarised by the LD spokesperson:
“The crisis we are witnessing in our town centres is clear to us all. Whilst Brexit is partly responsible, at the root of the issue is our broken business rates system.
“It is only right we welcome the benefits of the 21st century economy, but we cannot ignore the plight of our high streets and all those affected. As more and more individuals switch to online retail, businesses are struggling and thousands of jobs are being lost.
“Business rates should be replaced with a land value tax that encourages businesses to invest, whilst we must also empower local areas by reforming planning and supporting entrepreneurs. It is not to late to save our town centres and these measures would do just that.”
Demanding better
Sunday 17th: Another day at the LibDem conference in York. Wholehearted resolutions to improve air quality by reducing petrol and diesel vehicles and avoiding idling engines, and another to reinstate adequate legal aid and access to justice.
Also a new Supporters Scheme to engage those with similar values but who don’t want to commit too far.
But like most conferences, the best bit is meeting people. And, as a bonus, my B&B proprietor turned out to be a former professional footballer (Man City, York, etc) who gave me a signed copy of his memoirs!
York – LibDem Conference
March 15th: The Libdems are gathered, energised about the possibility of a People’s Vote, still angry that people were so misled about Brexit. Why shouldn’t people get to vote on the actual plan? Why shouldn’t views change in 3 years? Strike ballots are invalid after 6 months – Conservative legislation!
Borderlands funding – good news!
The Chancellor’s Spring Statement included some good news, which, with the Scottish Government, means more funding for the ‘Borderlands’ initiative – a collaboration between English and Scottish councils including Northumberland.
The Press Release (full document below) includes this section:
Borderlands Partnership welcomes Governments’ funding commitment.
The Borderlands Partnership has welcomed the commitment in the Spring Statement and the announcement of a £345 million deal from the UK and Scottish Governments, describing the news as a ‘game changer’. The multi-million-pound funding stream comes just six months after the Borderlands Inclusive Growth Deal proposal was presented to the two Governments. And it will mean thousands of new job opportunities, millions of extra tourists to the area, improved digital connectivity and unlocking investment in towns across the region generating a predicted £1.3bn return on the Governments’ investment.
What on Earth – Government Brexit meltdown!
This evening, the House of Commons voted to remove ‘no-deal’ from any options for Brexit. Minutes later, the Government applied a three-line whip to its MPs to vote against this amended motion, i.e. to retain the possibility of a ‘no-deal’ Brexit, and failed. The Government was in disarray, with Ministers ignoring their leader’s instructions.
‘N0 deal’ should be described as ‘scrap all deals’, as 40+ trade deals would vanish, the proposed zero tariffs would destroy many businesses, and we’d spend 5-10 years negotiating new deals from a position of weakness.
I’ve always been strongly opposed to Brexit, whilst recognising the faults of the EU, but I hope many people now realise that leaving is complicated and brings many disadvantages, though ‘sovereignty’ and ‘control’ sound good. If the promises had been kept, then maybe it could have been justified. Those included:
Vote Leave offical statement: ‘We will negotiate the terms of a new deal before we start any legal process to leave.’ – but the legal process was started immediately.
Jacob Rees-Mogg: ‘We could have two referendums. As it happens, it might make more sense to have the second referendum after the renegotiation is completed.’ – but Brexiters have fought hard against this.
Apart from broken promises (and notice that those ‘promises’ are no longer used to justify Brexit, only the statement that ‘it’s the will of the people’), there were outright lies too:
Leave campaign: ’80 million Turks would be entitled to enter the UK once Turkey joins the EU.’ – but there was no prospect of Turkey joining for many years.

August 20th: One of the few things I approved of in Michael Gove’s time as Education Secretary was his determination to stop grade inflation, which has led to an ever-increasing proportion of high grades in school exams, and which is also true of university results. I think his solutions weren’t right (or followed through), but the aim was right. Maybe I should also say that as Environment Secretary he appeared willing to listen to experts. A real problem with Education is that everyone thinks they’re an expert, so every government messes about with the system!
Thus the intention not to produce grade inflation this summer in the results for A-levels,in particular, was good. The problem was that almost any formula, or any new system (Universal Credit? Bus fares? Promotions?) produces winners and losers, and it’s well-known that even if the proposed scheme is defensible, a transition period is needed, with a ‘safety-net’ to deal with serious anomalies.
We now hear that Gavin Williamson and Nick Gibb knew a while back of the implications of the algorithm being considered. Until the last moment, they had resolved (or Johnson/Cummings had instructed them) to hold the line, and then they caved in and adopted ‘Centre Assessed Grades’, knowing that there would be a significant uplift in passes and top grades. As politicians, ministers are not expected to be experts, but they should be good judges of what priorities to adopt, how to communicate them well, and what, in the end, can be delivered as acceptable to the country.
Thus, they could have required a safety-net at least. My suggestions would have been that no school would see a reduction in overall average across all its subjects relative to 2019. If that were not adopted, then at least a fall-back position could have been that no student would see a grade reduction of more than one grade. Either of these would have taken much of the sting out of the crisis and reduced appeals. Neither is my definitive view, more indications of a viable strategy.
And now universities must try to accommodate sudden changes in intake (some will see a sudden drop!), with even more difficulty in timetabling any ‘in person’ teaching (in the necessary small groups). We don’t know yet how students will get on with our move to on-line materials and testing, and limited real contact with staff in addition to reduced social contact. What a mess!

March 16th: The quick answer – I don’t know! There are lots of people arguing, and ‘scientists’ are quoted, though many are not epidemiologists. It seems to me that assumptions are being made by all sides. I think the UK policy is roughly this:
- It’s likely that almost everyone will get this virus sooner or later, within the next year before any reliable vaccine is available. In any case, a vaccine might be only partially effective (like all flu jabs), as the virus could mutate.
- More testing won’t necessarily achieve anything as such, if 1. is correct.
- If so, then how can the peak be lowered and timed to allow best management by the NHS? Answer: by accepting a growing number of cases, whilst minimising effects on the most vulnerable.
- Banning gatherings at an early stage might just postpone the peak, or be unsustainable and make it harder later. Closing schools in particular could lead to a greater shortage of medical and emergency personnel.
- Things that affect economic activity will have other effects, including poverty and hence other health problems.
What’s wrong with all this? Well, the point about general infection and vaccines might well be true, but time to build up equipment (ventilators) and expertise will reduce deaths. We don’t know to what extent that’s been considered (but a relative of mine in France is getting a novel treatment, so knowledge will increase).
If a good vaccine can be developed in a year or so, then maybe stricter restrictions that reduce overall infection rates would be worth the social costs, but we won’t know for months yet. Vaccine development might in any case be slower than this.
Assumption 1. is key. WHO policy, that many think should be followed here, is based, I think, on the different assumption that overall infection rates can be held at a lower level and the disease eradicated or prevented by vaccination. That was clearly appropriate for Ebola.
Where our Government is clearly in the wrong is, firstly, that intensive care beds are at a low level, and there are significant shortages of nurses – they are responsible for that over the past ten years. Brexit policy is likely to make staff shortages much worse. And secondly, they could have ordered more ventilators weeks earlier – that alone might save lives.

May 2nd: I get on fine with reasonable members of major parties, Labour, Conservative, Green (I don’t meet many SNP members, but probably them too). I do not get on with those who hold dogmatic positions, defying logic, ignoring facts, being insulting to others.
People should vote quite separately for local and parliamentary elections, as the issues are often different and the individuals too. A local council might be doing well despite being the same party as a bad government, or vice versa. Of course there’s going to be some overlap – local parties and national parties are likely to have related priorities and assumptions about the mix of private and public, individual and state, both with respect to responsibilities and to economic mechanisms. But I respect those who vote for an excellent candidate even where that party isn’t their ‘usual’ one.
However, at present this Government is so bad, so dishonest, so incompetent, that I’d rather they got a clear signal this week that it’s time for them to acknowledge defeat and give way to others with energy, ideas and integrity.

September 1st: I know people saying our new government is a failure, that they lied, that they’ve gone back on promises, etc, etc. I say, give them some time! I’m sure Starmer’s strategy is to underpromise and aim to over-deliver, to deal with unglamorous essential foundations before eye-catching superstructure. I think he’s probably over-cautious, and mustn’t overlook the need to enthuse people, as well as to build trust. If I can’t see some progress after six months, I’ll be disappointed, and if others don’t see progress, they’ll be less inclined to support necessary actions too. We’ll see.
Meanwhile, I’m much less depressed than I was about US politics, where Harris is getting a consistent lead in opinion polls, and probably growing slowly. I don’t think she’ll be the most inspiring President, but she appears to be tough and competent. But to get a fairly smooth transition to power, she needs not only a win, but a clear win, as some states are sure to hold up certification, and there’s the risk of violence too. Some time in the future, it would be good to change their system so that either the overall vote share is used for the election of the President, or at least that states allot their electoral college votes in rough proportion, as Nebraska and Maine already do.

May 28th: I shall once again be the Liberal Democrat candidate for the Tynemouth constituency – one that’s kept its name and most of the same area (Shiremoor removed, part of Riverside added). The other North Tyneside seat (called ‘North Tyneside’ too, confusingly) is split into three. One part returns to its old form as part of Newcastle East & Wallsend. Another section goes into Newcastle North, whilst the northern wards become part of Cramlington & Killingworth.
Why do I stand for election with little hope of winning (against a Labour MP with no ‘black marks’ as such!)? Firstly, to give people the opportunity to vote for our set of values and priorities. Secondly, to proclaim and articulate both party policies and my own values. Thirdly, because I always aim to use elections as a chance to model how I think politics should be done. That is, with courtesy, realism, honesty, the hope that I can ‘nudge’ things a little towards a better politics. If I am seen as positive, as respecting the efforts and some of the policies of my opponents, as being honest with the public about what can be done and where I’m ignorant, then maybe I’ve helped make it all a little better. Who knows?
My personal statement, and links to national policies, will appear here and on Facebook, shortly.

August 10th: Riots and crime for over a week, with hundreds of arrests, including some for on-line posts. There’s always been rumours, and wild statements made to mates in the pub, but social media spreads those like wild-fire, and it’s impossible to retract a rumour. Some Conservative politicians and commentators, and some from Labour too, have tried to argue that the riots were protests about ‘legitimate concerns’, and even tried to draw parallels with the pro-Gaza and climate protests, but those were predominantly peaceful and even the more extreme elements kept to verbal attacks in almost all cases. These were riots, led by thugs, and incited by some who want chaos and hate democracy.
However, it’s also clear that poverty, poor or non-existent housing, long waiting lists, etc. have given many people a feeling of being ignored and neglected, and that probably contributed to the larger numbers giving tacit encouragement to those with a violent agenda. Again, those grievances have been amplified by some who have contributed to the problems now being articulated, ironically under a new Labour government that’s far more likely to address these.
I’m not a paid-up Starmer supporter, but it’s absurd to label him a failure after a month of the new regime. Yes, he’s already made some mistakes, but he’s clearly more honest, more competent, more serious than his several predecessors, and it’s only fair to suspend judgement until he’d had a few months to demonstrate what his priorities really are. What is clear though is that people will want to see at least signs of progress on housing, waiting lists and some other costs before too long, and such signs will also help tackle the scapegoating of migrants.

March 7th: A fun quiz night with the Newcastle Lib Dem group, but tough questions and our team were in fifth place – miles behind the real experts! Could we identify all the cities marked on a World map that began with the letter ‘B’ ? We did well on that (thanks to an Ouseburn geography specialist), but it’s salutary to note that Britain is so small on the World map that Birmingham and Bristol almost merge into one.
The question our team got right, and no others did, was a bonus question: which are the only two world capital cities containing all five vowels? (Extra clue: one in South America, one in Central America.)

April 20th: Safe streets for cycling and walking are vital to health, leisure and environment. Today I joined the coastal #KidicalMassNE – 200 children and adults ‘advertising’ the cycle space we need. We finished at Tynemouth (this is me with the organiser from @NTStreetLife).

December 12th: Some people loved Boris. Some still love him, but not nearly as many. Many liked his style, even while disapproving of his personal life, his exaggeration, his’fibbing’. Some merely thought he was preferable to Corbyn. Some, even including some Remainers, desperately wanted the debate about Brexit to be over. But all this was a ‘bubble’ that if not bursting, is perishing and leaking increasingly fast.
Will the voters of North Shropshire overturn a 23,000 majority and elect a Liberal Democrat next Thursday? Maybe, the signs are looking good, and most Labour and Green voters will see the sense of voting tactically. At General Elections, people think of the government they’d like, and some who are sympathetic to the Lib Dems will vote Labour (or Conservative) to ‘stop the others getting in’. However, at a by-election it’s ‘safe’ to send a message, and on this occasion many Conservative voters will simply stay at home to show dissatisfaction, whilst at least some switch to the Lib Dems.
That’s pretty much what happened in Chesham and Amersham. In that seat there were many Remainers, also opposed to foreign aid cuts. In North Shropshire, those aspects wouldn’t have been nearly enough, but disgust at the hypocrisy of Number 10, on top of lots of sleaze, incompetence, carelessness, cronyism and corruption in spending public money, has apparently ‘cut through’ in a way the other things hadn’t up to now. A sign that the mood really has changed is seeing Ant and Dec mock the Prime Minister on ‘I’m a Celebrity’ – reaching millions of people who might not study politics most of the time.
If the Lib Dems win, might Johnson be forced out? And if so, what next? The pitiful Truss and the smooth Sunak are front-runners, but maybe this time the MPs will realise that they need someone who is seen as competent and honest first, and ‘presentable’ second. That should rule out Truss on competence, and no-one knows what Sunak stands for. My preference, amongst a bad bunch, would be Hunt (came second in their leadership contest) or Javid (working-class background, showed some mettle in resigning rather than be ruled by Cummings). However, there’s a huge mess to clear up, and the chances of Labour forming the nest administration have risen hugely in just the past couple of weeks.

March 6th: Any objective analysis of Boris Johnson’s record as Prime Minister (and Foreign Secretary too) must conclude he is one of the worst holders of the post ever, yet he and the Conservatives are riding high in the polls. How can this be?
Johnson is rude and vulgar, lazy, careless, dishonest, wildly unrealistic, greedy, has a sense of entitlement, trusts friends but no-one else. He wants to entertain, be loved, to be constantly forgiven. He hates restrictions in his private life, and can’t see why there should be any restrictions on any of us economically, personally, legally.
In his favour is that many people see him as likeable, funny, making an emotional link with his audiences. People see him as an appealing boyish character. They share some of his mistrust of the state and large organisations, and appreciate his optimism. Most people have no idea at all of the executive role of a Prime Minister, or indeed of the leader of any major organisation – they are sure they could do a better job than the boss, the England football manager, the Vice-Chancellor, etc. That’s partly why I am strongly opposed to direct election of presidents, mayors, etc, as this favours personal characteristics over competence and reliability. George W Bush and Trump benefitted from the same public perceptions, especially if facing an opponent seen as dull.
Right now, the success of the vaccine rollout is benefitting Johnson greatly, and people’s wish to look forward makes them surprisingly willing to forgive the unnecessarily high death rate in this pandemic (“he’s doing his best, it’s a difficult job!”). But Labour’s equivocation over Europe has translated into an equivocation over too many things, particularly when facing a government that’s happy to spend a lot of money, and Starmer, although clearly competent in the executive role, is not an inspiring speaker who can engender optimism. Davey, too, must find some better headlines than the Environment and Carers, vital and valuable as they are. I think the Lib Dems should strengthen their line on drugs reform, and could make a good argument out of ‘More police, less reoffending’ and perhaps ‘More troops, fewer prestigious weapons’ (I’ll expand on this in another entry).
I hope that in due course, people will gain a more balanced view of Johnson’s government – its incompetence and dishonesty, and the de facto corruption of awarding contracts to friends (more because of familiarity and trust than of direct benefit, in my view). Brexit problems will continue to mount, and even if the EU is seen as the villain, people will still want the problems addressed. And this week’s Budget plans cuts to the NHS – surely impossible for people to accept.

Most people have no idea at all of the executive role of a Prime Minister, or indeed of the leader of any major organisation – they are sure they could do a better job than the boss, the England football manager, the Vice-Chancellor, etc. That’s partly why I am strongly opposed to direct election of presidents, mayors, etc, as this favours personal characteristics over competence and reliability. George W Bush and Trump benefitted from the same public perceptions, especially if facing an opponent seen as dull.
Right now, the success of the vaccine rollout is benefitting Johnson greatly, and people’s wish to look forward makes them surprisingly willing to forgive the unnecessarily high death rate in this pandemic (“he’s doing his best, it’s a difficult job!”). But Labour’s equivocation over Europe has translated into an equivocation over too many things, particularly when facing a government that’s happy to spend a lot of money, and Starmer, although clearly competent in the executive role, is not an inspiring speaker who can engender optimism. Davey, too, must find some better headlines than the Environment and Carers, vital and valuable as they are. I think the Lib Dems should strengthen their line on drugs reform, and could make a good argument out of ‘More police, less reoffending’ and perhaps ‘More troops, fewer prestigious weapons’ (I’ll expand on this in another entry).
I hope that in due course, people will gain a more balanced view of Johnson’s government – its incompetence and dishonesty, and the de facto corruption of awarding contracts to friends (more because of familiarity and trust than of direct benefit, in my view). Brexit problems will continue to mount, and even if the EU is seen as the villain, people will still want the problems addressed. And this week’s Budget plans cuts to the NHS – surely impossible for people to accept.

Tuesday 12th: I visited one of our active local Lib Dem branches, meeting in Morpeth, to hear what matters to them and areas beyond Tyneside. Northumberland is the most sparsely-populated county in England, and most of the people in the North of Tyne area are concentrated in the South-East corner, namely Newcastle, North Tyneside, plus Ashington and Blyth. Balancing the needs of this much wider area with the cities and large towns is a challenge I’d have to meet as Mayor. My discussions with the NE Chamber of Commerce revealed low membership of rural businesses.
Moreover, Brexit, in any form, would hit agriculture, not just manufacturing. In fact, Jacob Rees-Mogg’s favourite economist, Patrick Minford, said Brexit would be good for the UK but would decimate industry and agriculture – was that what people voted for?
