October 18th: What a summer! My last entry, on 18th July, ended with this: “Whoever is chosen might get a small ‘bounce’, and might genuinely be a bit more honest than Johnson, but it is to be hoped that currently greater trust in Keir Starmer won’t evaporate, and that our new PM won’t adopt really stupid policies, rashly hoping for some populist revival of support.”
Well, our new PM got no ‘bounce’ at all, but maybe at least isn’t an inveterate liar. In fact, she tried to enact roughly what she promised to those few Conservative members, whereas most of us assumed she’d be more moderate in practice once she’d got the job! She did indeed ‘adopt really stupid policies’, but perhaps not primarily to get populist approval but because she’d fallen hook, line and sinker for ‘Minfordnomics’.
Patrick Minford argued that Brexit would benefit the UK, but was quite open about his view that it would lead to decline in UK farming and industry. I think his logic was, if it can be produced more cheaply elsewhere, let that happen, whilst we do what we’re best at. This of course ignores the fact that much of our trade was with Europe, now more difficult and costly. It also ignores the security of home production (very obvious now with increased conflict) and the dignity and pride of things done at home. Moreover, this ‘purely logical’ approach to economics is of the kind that argues full employment can be achieved if the wage levels are appropriate, ignoring the fact that those levels might be below starvation level.
Hunt has his limitations, but is more mature and able than the PMs and chancellors we’ve had for some years. I hope he can save the UK from misery, but I also hope the Conservatives lose lots of seats at a General Election soon and learn from that!

The Chancellor’s Spring Statement included some good news, which, with the Scottish Government, means more funding for the ‘Borderlands’ initiative – a collaboration between English and Scottish councils including Northumberland.
The Press Release (full document below) includes this section:
Borderlands Partnership welcomes Governments’ funding commitment.
The Borderlands Partnership has welcomed the commitment in the Spring Statement and the announcement of a £345 million deal from the UK and Scottish Governments, describing the news as a ‘game changer’. The multi-million-pound funding stream comes just six months after the Borderlands Inclusive Growth Deal proposal was presented to the two Governments. And it will mean thousands of new job opportunities, millions of extra tourists to the area, improved digital connectivity and unlocking investment in towns across the region generating a predicted £1.3bn return on the Governments’ investment.

Manifestly sensible!
Weds 20th: The Liberal Democrat Manifesto has been published today – see: http://www.libdems.org.uk/plan . This is an ambitious set of policies that are all possible – fully costed and not a spending spree like the Conservatives. They used to be the party of financial prudence, but seem to have fallen for the ‘magic money tree’ concept they previously ridiculed. In any case, it’s hard to believe anything said by this Prime Minister, who was twice sacked for lying in his newspaper articles. His most important lie just now is that it was Parliament who blocked Brexit and forced the General Election. In fact, it was firstly the ERG and DUP (and Johnson himself) not accepting Theresa May’s proposals (bad, but better than his own), and then Johnson not allowing Parliament time to scrutinise the amended proposals.
On reflection, the policies I proposed on this site when standing for Mayor of the ‘North of Tyne’ still largely apply to what’s needed in this region, but I’m very happy to embrace those in the national manifesto. Those include (apart from stopping Brexit!): ambitious plans to address the Climate Emergency, help schools and childcare, address the social care crisis, and invest in infrastructure including in the North. See also the BBC commentary, around 1pm today, from:
“The Liberal Democrat manifesto is out. I’ve read it! This thread gives a northern take on it, so I’ve picked the bits that I think have the most regional relevance. Overall there is an emphasis on increased regional investment, and more powers and resources for councils…” and follow the whole thread.
Teamwork in Berwick
Sun 17th: North Tyneside members set off for Lynemouth and Linton in Northumberland, not far from Ashington, to deliver leaflets on behalf of Tom Hancock and our Berwick constituency team. Berwick was held by Alan Beith (now Lord Beith) for forty years and he is fondly remembered there, but we lost the seat in 2015 as the Party was punished for (mostly) the austerity imposed by the Conservative government. With an arch-Brexiteer Tory MP there, we’re attracting lots of support from those who understand just how bad Brexit would be for this rural constituency, as well as the rest of the North-East.

The Race is on!
November 15th: Phew! My nomination papers were formally accepted yesterday, so I’m officially the Liberal Democrat candidate for Tynemouth constituency (for the third time, also standing here in 2010 and 2017). It’s always a bit tense, getting ten local people to sign (to say I’m honest and suitable) and many more bits of paper that must conform to the legal requirements. Not to mention the £500 deposit that we get back if we get over 5% of the vote. On recent polls, I’m very hopeful of much better than that! Chris Boyle (legal aid solicitor, former Newcastle Councillor like me) will be our candidate for the North Tyneside seat (confusingly having the same name as the overall borough!).
Things starting to happen (and to go wrong!)
Weds 6th November: Stop Brexit! Build a Better Future. This is the Lib Dem main message in this critical election. Brexit will, in any form, damage our economy, our influence, our international standing, our voice and effect in tackling climate change and in standing up to the mega-economies of the US and China. Our electric ‘battle bus’ is a metaphor for this.
The Conservatives are already in damage-limitation mode. In 24 hours they have:
- been strongly criticised for blocking publication of a report into Russian interference in our elections
- been stopped from using the Civil Service to attack the Opposition
- been told their Universal Credit adverts are misleading
- had to apologise for insensitive remarks about Grenfell
- the Welsh Secretary has resigned over his support for a former aide
- produced a doctored video of Sir Keir Starmer
- compared Jeremy Corbyn to Stalin
- gone back on a promise to give MPs a vote on extending the Transition period.
All that in one day!!
Here we go! The Election is on!
31st October. We seem to be still in the EU! No civil disorder, no ‘exploding Britain’, and no Prime Minister ‘dead in a ditch’.
Faced with a real prospect of being bullied into accepting Boris Johnson’s bad deal without proper scrutiny, or a no-deal crash, Parliament has reluctantly agreed to a General Election on 12th December 2019. The only real advantage right now is that we stop wondering about dates and parliamentary votes, but we must instead worry about how to get a sensible parliament and government to get us out of the horrible mess started by Cameron, made worse by May, worse again by Johnson, and with an ineffective Opposition. whether or not you agree with Lib Dem policies, at least we have been clear and consistent from the start!
Coming down
On Friday 3rd May Jamie Driscoll became the first Elected Mayor of North of Tyne. I wish him well, and hope he can work collaboratively with the three council leaders and the NELEP. His ambitious socialist programme will probably have to be scaled down a lot to fit what’s possible, what’s an allowable use of the funding, and to be agreeable to his cabinet partners.
I got 13% of the first-choice votes – not bad in a contest that also had a credible Independent candidate (who will have picked up much of the ‘neither of them’ vote). Over 23,000 people gave me their vote, and there were lots and lots of second choice votes for me too (people whose first choice was for the Independent or for Labour), so who knows what might have happened in a three-way contest! The campaign gave me a chance to put forward my realistic vision of what was possible, and to offer myself as an experienced and collaborative pragmatist. As usual, I was happy to commend people and policies from other parties where appropriate, whilst telling them, and the voters, when I thought they were wrong or unrealistic.
Thanks to all those who voted for me, and of course to my agent and the rest of the team who encouraged, funded, leafletted, consoled. But of course, a great day for Liberal Democrat councillors across the UK, with over 700 seats gained, including Gareth Kane in Ouseburn ward, Newcastle.
Now for some relaxation, and to catch up with my teaching work at Newcastle University (mostly marking of coursework and exams for the next month!). And my wife (who nearly tripled her vote in the local elections in North Tyneside) will be glad to hear less of politics at all hours.

Climate Emergency?
April 24th: Feeling tired today after four fixtures yesterday – BBC Radio, BBC TV, Chronicle/Journal hustings, then a hustings in Alnwick. The evening fixture was organised by Friends of the Earth and was focussed on the Environment – a subject I’ve featured and emphasised whenever I can in this campaign.
Some good questions included our support for declaring a Climate Emergency in line with the street protests and the amazing Greta Thunberg. I supported this call, as it’s such a massive issue and we should be grateful to young people in particular for insisting action is taken now. But I said, to audience agreement, that declarations aren’t much use unless we all take action, including examining our own lifestyles and sacrifices we might need to make. I already do what I can (I don’t own a car, buy second-hand and rarely fly) but maybe there’s more? Perhaps I could aim to eat only seasonal food to avoid heating, cooling and transport costs?
Another important issue raised was Biodiversity – important for the richness of our environment, for insect pollination, and for sources for new drugs.

May 9th: Johnson gets another boost with Hartlepool, over 200 council seats, a dozen councils, and almost entirely undeserved. Labour loses over 200 and several councils, but gains two more Mayoral positions. The SNP advances a bit, and opens the door to a contentious battle over a referendum. The clearest gainer is the Greens, still smallish, but advancing as the Environment becomes more important to more people. The Lib Dems hold fairly steady, some gains, some losses, but overall a 17% vote share, the best for some time.
In North Tyneside, we fielded twelve candidates (much better than 2019) plus myself for Mayor. With a Green Mayoral candidate this time, I knew I might lose a few votes, but actually got almost exactly the same number, though my share dropped from 6.7% to 5.7% (on an increased turnout). With the Greens on 6.9%, that made 13% of votes for strongly ‘environmental’ parties, which I welcome. We’ve pledged publicly to hold our Labour Mayor to her 2030 carbon-neutral pledge! Although we lost our one sitting councillor by a small margin, our most active member got a good third place from a standing start in a ward we’d not contested in years. Much potential there.
For Labour and Lib Dems it’s hard to cut through at the moment, as the Government profits from the vaccine bounce, the opening up, and the impression given of spending to solve problems (offsetting some of previous cuts, of course, and more cuts to come in many areas!). We need one or two really clear policy messages that we are known for (true not just now, but during the Coalition years!). Having a packed file of detailed policy is great for governing, less so for campaigning. And those two statements need to be ones that the public know are ours. They should be able to answer their own question: what do the Lib Dems stand for?
My own view is that making drugs a health problem not a criminal problem would be a good policy, and Environment should also feature. How about ‘strengthen our defences with troops, transport and cyber instead of prestige ships and planes’? ‘The party of small businesses’? May 9th: Johnson gets another boost with Hartlepool, over 200 council seats, a dozen councils, and almost entirely undeserved. Labour loses over 200 and several councils, but gains two more Mayoral positions. The SNP advances a bit, and opens the door to a contentious battle over a referendum. The clearest gainer is the Greens, still smallish, but advancing as the Environment becomes more important to more people. The Lib Dems hold fairly steady, some gains, some losses, but overall a 17% vote share, the best for some time.
In North Tyneside, we fielded twelve candidates (much better than 2019) plus myself for Mayor. March 2nd: Our inept Prime Minister, shackled to an almost hysterical right-wing, and facing electoral oblivion, makes a public speech about extremism and ‘mob rule’. I’ve said before that the thing I have most hated about the Governments we’ve had since 2016 (i.e. Johnson, May, Truss, Sunak) is that they have created, encouraged, even stoked, division between people, between communities, between countries.
Surely one of the most important functions of leadership – true for managing a department or even being a parent, as well as in politics – is to reduce suspicion and hostility, to build trust, to try to bring people together in a common vision? Obviously simplistic nationalism isn’t what I mean (such as Modi’s BJP in India), but a common vision that everybody, if possible, can see the point of and feel that they or their children and friends might find good in wellbeing if not in material wealth.
February 12th 2024: The general mood right now for most people seems to be ‘Anything but this!’ For many, that means voting for the candidate most likely to unseat a Conservative, even if that individual has behaved (mostly) honourably. For many others, it means ‘I’m not voting for them, nor for any of the others!’. This is not a healthy situation.
Keir Starmer is evidently a cautious person. He’s very conscious of what happened in 1992, when Labour had a fair lead in the polls, yet John Major and the Conservatives won. The margin in the polls is far larger now, but he clearly doesn’t want to take things for granted, and also doesn’t want to promise what he can’t deliver, in case he leads a one-term government.
However, it would be good to have more of a sense of vision and hope, instead of dull competence, even though that’s what’s more important in getting our society back on track as a functioning and civil country. He no doubts wants to be radical on the climate too, but has managed to give a very confused message on that. If the markets can accept Labour’s initial plans and track record, I really hope he’ll revive that necessary huge investment before long.
But I can’t pretend that a majority Labour government is my preferred option. I’d like the Lib Dems to get 30-50 seats, return to being the third largest party (2nd largest is too much to hope, I think), and have a real share in decision-making. Let’s see.
August 4th: Why does our Government continue to do things that seem irrational and counter-productive? Why not join the Horizon programme? Why license new oil and gas fields? Why announce that shoplifters will go to jail? Why don’t they seem to care about sewage in our rivers, and doctors and teachers leaving their professions in huge numbers, or whether we are taken seriously by our international partners? Are they stupid? Are their advisers all stupid too? Are their civil-servants not pointing out the ineffectiveness (at best) of these disjointed, erratic and naive policties?
Is it just that it makes more profit for their rich mates? I think not. No doubt they are so used to spending time with other privileged people that their judgement is affected. We’re all more inclined to trust those like us, our friends and those of a type we know. We flatter ourselves that we understand them and they us, that they are more likely to deliver what we intend than anonymous corporations. This surely underlies to a large extent the system of patronage over the years in promotions etc. Not all purely selfish, but also unconscious bias.
But there is another, quite different, rationale. In 2019, Johnson perceived that UKIP might contest many existing Conservative seats, and others he hoped to win, not by winning them, but by splitting the conservative vote. He tacked to the right, and UKIP stood down in all seats held by Conservatives that supported Brexit.
For the 2024 General Election, the Conservatives must surely know that they’re likely to lose, and by a substantial margin. They could easily drop to 200 seats (as Labour has now). But if Reform (ex-UKIP) contests many seats, that 200 could instead be 50-100 – a near wipe-out for the party. That’s what terrifies the Conservative Party. If they try to appear more moderate, they might regain some votes from the centre-ground, but they might lose far more seats through that split vote.
I think our inept, unimaginative and corrupt government has realised it’s going to lose badly next year, and its strategy is to avoid a wipe-out. I really find it hard to believe there’s any other rationale for continuing to adopt such stupid policies.
June 19th: A day to remember – the House of Commons debating the Privileges Committee report into Boris Johnson’s deliberate misleading of the House, and his subsequent rubbishing of the process and the individuals bravely producing the report. A bad day – that it was necessary, and that many Conservative MPs stayed away (very few opposed the report). A good day – that the HoC could be honest about the shenanigans of Johnson’s regime and his personal unsuitability to be Prime Minister.
And, this week, a ‘stolen’ video displaying the carelessness and contempt for the public and for shared mores as Shaun Bailey’s Mayoral team at CCHQ partied on the same day we were instructed to return to social restrictions.
Honesty in politicians means avoiding deliberate untruths or grossly misleading statements, as a minimum, but also means not promising things that there is no realistic chance of delivering. One shortlisted candidate for the expanded North-East Mayor says they’ll ‘eliminate child poverty’ – a laudable but impossible aim. They should really say ‘reducing child poverty is my principal aim’ and perhaps ‘we should be able to eliminate child poverty, and I’ll do my best to reduce it substantially in my five year term’.
It’s generally understood that Cameron promised a referendum that he thought he’d be forced to drop in a hung parliament, that Clegg promised no student fee increase as he didn’t expect to be in power, and that Johnson urged a Brexit that he didn’t believe in. Only the last was a complete falsehood, but the others were rash at least, and came back to haunt us all.
May 2nd: I get on fine with reasonable members of major parties, Labour, Conservative, Green (I don’t meet many SNP members, but probably them too). I do not get on with those who hold dogmatic positions, defying logic, ignoring facts, being insulting to others.
People should vote quite separately for local and parliamentary elections, as the issues are often different and the individuals too. A local council might be doing well despite being the same party as a bad government, or vice versa. Of course there’s going to be some overlap – local parties and national parties are likely to have related priorities and assumptions about the mix of private and public, individual and state, both with respect to responsibilities and to economic mechanisms. But I respect those who vote for an excellent candidate even where that party isn’t their ‘usual’ one.
However, at present this Government is so bad, so dishonest, so incompetent, that I’d rather they got a clear signal this week that it’s time for them to acknowledge defeat and give way to others with energy, ideas and integrity.
February 14th: I’m often accused of being too charitable to those who seem corrupt or crazy. Perhaps I am. But my experience is that people are often less corrupt and/or less crazy than they first appear. Moreover, in the case of politics, those who vote for what seem stupid or malign policies are unlikely to be convinced by our viewing those representatives in the worst possible light. So this is an attempt to ‘defend’ a significant minority of Conservative MPs who continue to vote with the Government even though they seem decent enough as people. This is not any defence of the policies, nor a full justification for their continuing support.
Traditional, one-nation Conservatism, and moderate, democratic Socialism, can have constructive discussions with each other, with a fair amount of consensus on what’s acceptable both to the public and in parliamentary processes. They also agree that change must happen gradually.
They agree on a mixed economy, but disagree about the mix, the balance between public and private finance, and between individual and collective responsibility.
The Cabinet (most of them) must know that Brexit has been hugely damaging, that leaving the ECHR would be insane, that scrapping EU laws without discussion or replacement would be disastrous. The only (sane) reason for these proposals at all is that they know they’re going to lose the next General Election, badly, but think their only hope of avoiding huge losses (resulting in < 100 seats?) is to keep sufficient core voters who might support Reform. Any attempt to appeal to swing Con/Lab or Con/LD voters could cost far more than it would gain.
Meanwhile, the ‘sensible’ Conservative MPs want their party to regain its pragmatism and caution. They know they’ll lose many seats at the next General Election, but hope that they can retain enough to form a substantial Opposition, and then re-form a parliamentary group capable of governing. But if they rebel now, they might fail to prevent whatever policy it is, create even more of an impression of incompetence, and feed the populist appetite leaking votes to Reform. They might also be de-selected (as in 2019). Thus they continue to conform, hoping to keep their own seats and a future, sensible Party.
Some Ministers might feel similarly, though they’re deeper in the collective insanity of making enemies, damaging trade, reducing Britain’s influence, weakening our universities, etc. But maybe a few (like one or two of Trump’s lieutenants?) think that the UK would be even worse off without their moderating voice in Cabinet.
Of course, I might be wrong. Many MPs are just in the habit of voting with their own Government, and fearful of losing their seats, even if they’re not personally corrupt.
November 16th: Common UK views have moved from ‘In God we trust’ through ‘With Truss, “Oh my God!”‘ to a weary fatalism now Rishi Sunak holds the reins – ‘God knows what’s coming next!’.
Back in the Spring, Sunak’s wife’s non-dom status became known, and by chance I was interviewed in his constituency of Richmond as if I were a resident (but I did tell ITV!). The comments after this clip are hilarious! It got extra coverage when re-tweeted by a member of the Shadow Cabinet!
I haven’t changed my views since the early days of ‘Dishy Rishi’, when I said we knew nothing about his vision or skills – now both clearly lacking – although he does seem more decent and a bit more honest than some of his colleagues. HIs judgement though – Braverman and Williamson and Raab. How long can he last?
October 18th: What a summer! My last entry, on 18th July, ended with this: “Whoever is chosen might get a small ‘bounce’, and might genuinely be a bit more honest than Johnson, but it is to be hoped that currently greater trust in Keir Starmer won’t evaporate, and that our new PM won’t adopt really stupid policies, rashly hoping for some populist revival of support.”
Well, our new PM got no ‘bounce’ at all, but maybe at least isn’t an inveterate liar. In fact, she tried to enact roughly what she promised to those few Conservative members, whereas most of us assumed she’d be more moderate in practice once she’d got the job! She did indeed ‘adopt really stupid policies’, but perhaps not primarily to get populist approval but because she’d fallen hook, line and sinker for ‘Minfordnomics’.
Patrick Minford argued that Brexit would benefit the UK, but was quite open about his view that it would lead to decline in UK farming and industry. I think his logic was, if it can be produced more cheaply elsewhere, let that happen, whilst we do what we’re best at. This of course ignores the fact that much of our trade was with Europe, now more difficult and costly. It also ignores the security of home production (very obvious now with increased conflict) and the dignity and pride of things done at home. Moreover, this ‘purely logical’ approach to economics is of the kind that argues full employment can be achieved if the wage levels are appropriate, ignoring the fact that those levels might be below starvation level.
Hunt has his limitations, but is more mature and able than the PMs and chancellors we’ve had for some years. I hope he can save the UK from misery, but I also hope the Conservatives lose lots of seats at a General Election soon and learn from that!
July 18th: Boris Johnson got rid of most of the most talented moderates in his parliamentary party, demanding all candidates in 2019 and all MPs since should show total loyalty to him and the Brexit project. That meant many, less courageous, MPs swallowing their pride and principles to defend the indefensible, such as lies about ‘forty new hospitals’ and ‘Northern Ireland’s economy lagging behind the rest of Britain’, trashing our reputation for integrity and reliability, and adopting populist but ineffective policies such as increased prison sentences and the appalling Rwanda policy.
Finally forced out by his dishonesty and irresponsibility over ‘Partygate’ and the Pincher affair, Johnson leaves behind a sorry state of both UK policy and economy, and of possible successors. The debates on TV, in the press and on Twitter have brought us little honesty, few ideas, and much mud-slinging about the candidates’ own involvement and about each other. The third TV debate has been cancelled as two leading candidates could see these pubic viewings were just making them all look bad. Recall that Johnson refused to participate in all but one TV debate in 2019 and also swerved the hardest interview experienced by the other leaders in the 2019 General Election.
Whoever is chosen might get a small ‘bounce’, and might genuinely be a bit more honest than Johnson, but it is to be hoped that currently greater trust in Keir Starmer won’t evaporate, and that our new PM won’t adopt really stupid policies, rashly hoping for some populist revival of support.
June 21st: Rail strikes today, and the Government tries to blame this on Labour, who haven’t been in power for twelve years! It’s very probable that the unions have been obstructive to new practices in some ways, and certain that the railways must find economies as fewer people commute. Nonetheless, rail companies make large profits at public expense, and it probably suits the Government to milk the situation to get a few more votes in the by-elections this week.
The ‘Boris tried to get his lover a job’ story is very curious. Trying to suppress an almost certainly true story seems pointless, but is probably a panic reaction, calculating that some core Tory voters in Tiverton and Honiton are more likely to be influenced by paper copies of their favourite newspapers than by the commentary. Why would the Times and Mail withdraw the story? What have they been promised? Is Johnson seriously considering a General Election once the by-election results are known, and in that case, has he offered the Times and Mail an exclusive?
I’m an optimist, but the country does seem to be out of control at present. I don’t envy any new government trying to address so many difficulties – inflation, staff shortages, trade, Northern Ireland, the pandemic, Ukraine, but building trust and cooperation must be at the centre of any programme of government right now, and at any time. Labour isn’t to blame for most of the current crop of problems, but they do need some courage in projecting a vision that’s positive for people. That does seem to be lacking, and if the Tories do dump Johnson and find a more decent and competent leader, it might be hard for Starmer to be seen as the better choice.

August 10th: Riots and crime for over a week, with hundreds of arrests, including some for on-line posts. There’s always been rumours, and wild statements made to mates in the pub, but social media spreads those like wild-fire, and it’s impossible to retract a rumour. Some Conservative politicians and commentators, and some from Labour too, have tried to argue that the riots were protests about ‘legitimate concerns’, and even tried to draw parallels with the pro-Gaza and climate protests, but those were predominantly peaceful and even the more extreme elements kept to verbal attacks in almost all cases. These were riots, led by thugs, and incited by some who want chaos and hate democracy.
However, it’s also clear that poverty, poor or non-existent housing, long waiting lists, etc. have given many people a feeling of being ignored and neglected, and that probably contributed to the larger numbers giving tacit encouragement to those with a violent agenda. Again, those grievances have been amplified by some who have contributed to the problems now being articulated, ironically under a new Labour government that’s far more likely to address these.
I’m not a paid-up Starmer supporter, but it’s absurd to label him a failure after a month of the new regime. Yes, he’s already made some mistakes, but he’s clearly more honest, more competent, more serious than his several predecessors, and it’s only fair to suspend judgement until he’d had a few months to demonstrate what his priorities really are. What is clear though is that people will want to see at least signs of progress on housing, waiting lists and some other costs before too long, and such signs will also help tackle the scapegoating of migrants.

On Friday 3rd May Jamie Driscoll became the first Elected Mayor of North of Tyne. I wish him well, and hope he can work collaboratively with the three council leaders and the NELEP. His ambitious socialist programme will probably have to be scaled down a lot to fit what’s possible, what’s an allowable use of the funding, and to be agreeable to his cabinet partners.
I got 13% of the first-choice votes – not bad in a contest that also had a credible Independent candidate (who will have picked up much of the ‘neither of them’ vote). Over 23,000 people gave me their vote, and there were lots and lots of second choice votes for me too (people whose first choice was for the Independent or for Labour), so who knows what might have happened in a three-way contest! The campaign gave me a chance to put forward my realistic vision of what was possible, and to offer myself as an experienced and collaborative pragmatist. As usual, I was happy to commend people and policies from other parties where appropriate, whilst telling them, and the voters, when I thought they were wrong or unrealistic.
Thanks to all those who voted for me, and of course to my agent and the rest of the team who encouraged, funded, leafletted, consoled. But of course, a great day for Liberal Democrat councillors across the UK, with over 700 seats gained, including Gareth Kane in Ouseburn ward, Newcastle.
Now for some relaxation, and to catch up with my teaching work at Newcastle University (mostly marking of coursework and exams for the next month!). And my wife (who nearly tripled her vote in the local elections in North Tyneside) will be glad to hear less of politics at all hours.

December 20th: When the Government is reduced to trying to justify its behaviour by reference to detailed wording, it’s lost the argument. In this case, whether or not a social for staff in the back-garden of no.10 was in breach of the rules in force in May 2020. That’s not the point at all. And of course we all understand the temptation to break rules occasionally, and feel aggrieved if we’re caught out in an occasional, slight breach, such as getting speeding points for 32mph. But the difference here is that almost everyone was trying hard to keep to a set of rules for public safety, they needed faith that it was worthwhile, and leadership includes setting an example, not rationalising elite behaviour (‘some animals are more equal than others’). And it wasn’t just one event, it was quite a few, and meanwhile individuals who in some cases had merely gone for a walk or met with a couple of others at a picnic were getting substantial fines.
The Prime Minister, who was never suitable for the job, has now lost almost all credibility. Described as ‘the trolley’ by Dominic Cummings, owing to his tendency to swerve erratically between directions, indecisive, mendacious, hypocritical, tactless, greedy, wasteful, obliging friends and acquaintances with indulgence and inappropriate contracts and appointments, and wedded to a grand plan (‘Get Brexit Done!’) that looks worse and worse by the month. No surprise then that his legendary vote-winning charisma didn’t work last week as the Lib Dem candidate swept away one of the largest Conservative majorities in the UK.
Johnson now looks like a ‘place-holder’ for the PM’s position, with little ability to shape events. He will surely go before long, but as well as the time required to select an alternative, there is real nervousness about taking on not merely a ‘poisoned chalice’ but a whole reservoir of filth. Sunak is a rich smoothie, whilst Truss seems vacuous. Javid has shown some ‘spine’ and does understand poverty, and Hunt is experienced – better one of these two if a good backbencher isn’t ready, such as Ellwood or Tugendhat.

August 4th: Why does our Government continue to do things that seem irrational and counter-productive? Why not join the Horizon programme? Why license new oil and gas fields? Why announce that shoplifters will go to jail? Why don’t they seem to care about sewage in our rivers, and doctors and teachers leaving their professions in huge numbers, or whether we are taken seriously by our international partners? Are they stupid? Are their advisers all stupid too? Are their civil-servants not pointing out the ineffectiveness (at best) of these disjointed, erratic and naive policties?
Is it just that it makes more profit for their rich mates? I think not. No doubt they are so used to spending time with other privileged people that their judgement is affected. We’re all more inclined to trust those like us, our friends and those of a type we know. We flatter ourselves that we understand them and they us, that they are more likely to deliver what we intend than anonymous corporations. This surely underlies to a large extent the system of patronage over the years in promotions etc. Not all purely selfish, but also unconscious bias.
But there is another, quite different, rationale. In 2019, Johnson perceived that UKIP might contest many existing Conservative seats, and others he hoped to win, not by winning them, but by splitting the conservative vote. He tacked to the right, and UKIP stood down in all seats held by Conservatives that supported Brexit.
For the 2024 General Election, the Conservatives must surely know that they’re likely to lose, and by a substantial margin. They could easily drop to 200 seats (as Labour has now). But if Reform (ex-UKIP) contests many seats, that 200 could instead be 50-100 – a near wipe-out for the party. That’s what terrifies the Conservative Party. If they try to appear more moderate, they might regain some votes from the centre-ground, but they might lose far more seats through that split vote.
I think our inept, unimaginative and corrupt government has realised it’s going to lose badly next year, and its strategy is to avoid a wipe-out. I really find it hard to believe there’s any other rationale for continuing to adopt such stupid policies.

Not everything I do is political!
On January 26th I was the caller for a Burns Night ceilidh in Heaton. Our band is called ‘The Last Straw’ and does occasional charity and church functions. This one was at Heaton Baptist Church, and was to raise money for a brilliant project in Thailand helping fund a rural school in a very deprived area. We’ve done this one three years running.
From February 20-23 I was in London for the General Synod of the Church of England. Lots of interesting presentations and debates, including Homelessness, Environment, Gambling advertising, Racism against the Gypsy, Roma & Traveller community, divisions in society, and various church business. Church of England bishops led the House of Lords debate and made other contributions to getting the maximum stake reduced on Fixed-Odds Betting Terminals – a major step in preventing exploitation of poor communities against initial Government resistance.

January 23rd: Last Wednesday, I was in tears! After four years of disbelief, horror, disgust, and actual fear two weeks ago, I was watching the return of honesty, decency and competence to the White House. I celebrated with many the success of an experienced, conscientious man and the excitement of his VP appointment, and feel hopeful that the US, and the World, might now find a better way forward.
Am I purely an optimist? No, there is too much to do, Joe Biden isn’t perfect, and his divisive and dishonest opponents will continue to work against sensible government. But his calm and bipartisan approach does have a good chance of tackling the crises of the pandemic, the economy, the climate and the soclal divisions bequeathed to him.
When a malign individual takes power, both recently in the USA, in several European countries and further afield, and on many occasions in the past, it’s easy to blame that individual. However, they would not gain power on their own, and wouldn’t retain it either. Those who supported Trump, even tacitly, because of their own vulnerability, of opportunism, or because they thought ‘this isn’t the time to kick up a row’, as well as those who did so knowingly or cynically, are culpable too. I don’t blame every politician every time for apparently putting their party ahead of their country, as they might genuinely believe that on balance their party is better for their country than the opposition, but I do blame them for setting no apparent limits to that support. This month, in the US, that extended to open support for insurrection – a disgrace for which some US representatives must be held to account.

Author: johnapplebyld
Manifestly sensible!
Weds 20th: The Liberal Democrat Manifesto has been published today – see: http://www.libdems.org.uk/plan . This is an ambitious set of policies that are all possible – fully costed and not a spending spree like the Conservatives. They used to be the party of financial prudence, but seem to have fallen for the ‘magic money tree’ concept they previously ridiculed. In any case, it’s hard to believe anything said by this Prime Minister, who was twice sacked for lying in his newspaper articles. His most important lie just now is that it was Parliament who blocked Brexit and forced the General Election. In fact, it was firstly the ERG and DUP (and Johnson himself) not accepting Theresa May’s proposals (bad, but better than his own), and then Johnson not allowing Parliament time to scrutinise the amended proposals.
On reflection, the policies I proposed on this site when standing for Mayor of the ‘North of Tyne’ still largely apply to what’s needed in this region, but I’m very happy to embrace those in the national manifesto. Those include (apart from stopping Brexit!): ambitious plans to address the Climate Emergency, help schools and childcare, address the social care crisis, and invest in infrastructure including in the North. See also the BBC commentary, around 1pm today, from:
“The Liberal Democrat manifesto is out. I’ve read it! This thread gives a northern take on it, so I’ve picked the bits that I think have the most regional relevance. Overall there is an emphasis on increased regional investment, and more powers and resources for councils…” and follow the whole thread.
Teamwork in Berwick
Sun 17th: North Tyneside members set off for Lynemouth and Linton in Northumberland, not far from Ashington, to deliver leaflets on behalf of Tom Hancock and our Berwick constituency team. Berwick was held by Alan Beith (now Lord Beith) for forty years and he is fondly remembered there, but we lost the seat in 2015 as the Party was punished for (mostly) the austerity imposed by the Conservative government. With an arch-Brexiteer Tory MP there, we’re attracting lots of support from those who understand just how bad Brexit would be for this rural constituency, as well as the rest of the North-East.
A local candidate
Friday 15th: I live in Whitley Bay, and I’ve lived in North Tyneside for eleven of the last thirteen years. The Labour MP and the Conservative candidate for Tynemouth also live in this constituency, and the Green candidate lives not far away and is locally active. But the Brexit candidate gives a home address in Australia! Does he have any interest at all in this area (he claims to have visited Tynemouth once)? It seems all of a pattern with another Brexit member, one of our MEPs, who lives in the South of France. They claim to care about Britain, but really! NB This featured on Tyne Tees news the same night!
The Race is on!
November 15th: Phew! My nomination papers were formally accepted yesterday, so I’m officially the Liberal Democrat candidate for Tynemouth constituency (for the third time, also standing here in 2010 and 2017). It’s always a bit tense, getting ten local people to sign (to say I’m honest and suitable) and many more bits of paper that must conform to the legal requirements. Not to mention the £500 deposit that we get back if we get over 5% of the vote. On recent polls, I’m very hopeful of much better than that! Chris Boyle (legal aid solicitor, former Newcastle Councillor like me) will be our candidate for the North Tyneside seat (confusingly having the same name as the overall borough!).
Things starting to happen (and to go wrong!)
Weds 6th November: Stop Brexit! Build a Better Future. This is the Lib Dem main message in this critical election. Brexit will, in any form, damage our economy, our influence, our international standing, our voice and effect in tackling climate change and in standing up to the mega-economies of the US and China. Our electric ‘battle bus’ is a metaphor for this.
The Conservatives are already in damage-limitation mode. In 24 hours they have:
- been strongly criticised for blocking publication of a report into Russian interference in our elections
- been stopped from using the Civil Service to attack the Opposition
- been told their Universal Credit adverts are misleading
- had to apologise for insensitive remarks about Grenfell
- the Welsh Secretary has resigned over his support for a former aide
- produced a doctored video of Sir Keir Starmer
- compared Jeremy Corbyn to Stalin
- gone back on a promise to give MPs a vote on extending the Transition period.
All that in one day!!
Here we go! The Election is on!
31st October. We seem to be still in the EU! No civil disorder, no ‘exploding Britain’, and no Prime Minister ‘dead in a ditch’.
Faced with a real prospect of being bullied into accepting Boris Johnson’s bad deal without proper scrutiny, or a no-deal crash, Parliament has reluctantly agreed to a General Election on 12th December 2019. The only real advantage right now is that we stop wondering about dates and parliamentary votes, but we must instead worry about how to get a sensible parliament and government to get us out of the horrible mess started by Cameron, made worse by May, worse again by Johnson, and with an ineffective Opposition. whether or not you agree with Lib Dem policies, at least we have been clear and consistent from the start!
Coming down
On Friday 3rd May Jamie Driscoll became the first Elected Mayor of North of Tyne. I wish him well, and hope he can work collaboratively with the three council leaders and the NELEP. His ambitious socialist programme will probably have to be scaled down a lot to fit what’s possible, what’s an allowable use of the funding, and to be agreeable to his cabinet partners.
I got 13% of the first-choice votes – not bad in a contest that also had a credible Independent candidate (who will have picked up much of the ‘neither of them’ vote). Over 23,000 people gave me their vote, and there were lots and lots of second choice votes for me too (people whose first choice was for the Independent or for Labour), so who knows what might have happened in a three-way contest! The campaign gave me a chance to put forward my realistic vision of what was possible, and to offer myself as an experienced and collaborative pragmatist. As usual, I was happy to commend people and policies from other parties where appropriate, whilst telling them, and the voters, when I thought they were wrong or unrealistic.
Thanks to all those who voted for me, and of course to my agent and the rest of the team who encouraged, funded, leafletted, consoled. But of course, a great day for Liberal Democrat councillors across the UK, with over 700 seats gained, including Gareth Kane in Ouseburn ward, Newcastle.
Now for some relaxation, and to catch up with my teaching work at Newcastle University (mostly marking of coursework and exams for the next month!). And my wife (who nearly tripled her vote in the local elections in North Tyneside) will be glad to hear less of politics at all hours.
Panel beating?
April 29th: Thursday saw the screening of both the BBC ‘Mastermind’ quiz and the ITV ‘quick-fire’ interviews. I scored 6 on the quiz – not too bad considering I was asked the area of the NoT (my answer: 3,000 sq.m., correct answer 2,000 sq.m.) and the meaning of ‘clamming’ (Geordie: means hungry). The ITV format worked quite well and I kept to time – strictly 20 seconds or 30 on each question.
You can see the ITV interviews in ‘Around the House’. https://www.itv.com/news/tyne-tees/2019-04-25/a-job-interview-for-the-north-of-tyne-mayoral-candidates-plus-extinction-rebellion-effective-or-just-disruptive/
On Friday all five of us were recorded at the BBC studios, screened on Sunday as the Politics Show. I don’t think I have the best ‘TV manner’ of the five candidates, but feel I came across as thoughtful and knowledgeable about detail. The Labour candidate set out his ambitious plans and was challenged on the realism of those. Did you see the programme? What did you think?
At the Environment hustings last Tuesday, Biodiversity was raised as an issue. As I said at the time, the dramatic fall in insect numbers (owing to chemical use and climate) threatens world food supplies, and reduced plant diversity could also make new drug discovery difficult.
Climate Emergency?
April 24th: Feeling tired today after four fixtures yesterday – BBC Radio, BBC TV, Chronicle/Journal hustings, then a hustings in Alnwick. The evening fixture was organised by Friends of the Earth and was focussed on the Environment – a subject I’ve featured and emphasised whenever I can in this campaign.
Some good questions included our support for declaring a Climate Emergency in line with the street protests and the amazing Greta Thunberg. I supported this call, as it’s such a massive issue and we should be grateful to young people in particular for insisting action is taken now. But I said, to audience agreement, that declarations aren’t much use unless we all take action, including examining our own lifestyles and sacrifices we might need to make. I already do what I can (I don’t own a car, buy second-hand and rarely fly) but maybe there’s more? Perhaps I could aim to eat only seasonal food to avoid heating, cooling and transport costs?
Another important issue raised was Biodiversity – important for the richness of our environment, for insect pollination, and for sources for new drugs.

At the Environment hustings last Tuesday, Biodiversity was raised as an issue. As I said at the time, the dramatic fall in insect numbers (owing to chemical use and climate) threatens world food supplies, and reduced plant diversity could also make new drug discovery difficult.
Climate Emergency?
April 24th: Feeling tired today after four fixtures yesterday – BBC Radio, BBC TV, Chronicle/Journal hustings, then a hustings in Alnwick. The evening fixture was organised by Friends of the Earth and was focussed on the Environment – a subject I’ve featured and emphasised whenever I can in this campaign.
Some good questions included our support for declaring a Climate Emergency in line with the street protests and the amazing Greta Thunberg. I supported this call, as it’s such a massive issue and we should be grateful to young people in particular for insisting action is taken now. But I said, to audience agreement, that declarations aren’t much use unless we all take action, including examining our own lifestyles and sacrifices we might need to make. I already do what I can (I don’t own a car, buy second-hand and rarely fly) but maybe there’s more? Perhaps I could aim to eat only seasonal food to avoid heating, cooling and transport costs?
Another important issue raised was Biodiversity – important for the richness of our environment, for insect pollination, and for sources for new drugs.
